## babaco
 
 <i>n.</i> A hybrid papaya, <i>Carica pentagona,</i> originating in Ecuador; with large yellow-skinned fruit up to 30 cm long and 10-12 in cross-section, with rather acid, almost white and distinctly fragrant flesh.

>  <b>BURCHFIELD</b> babaco /b |b k u/. N.Z. & Austral. [S. Amer. Sp. (Ecuador).] A bright yellow marrow-like fruit, C<i>arica heilbornii pentagona</i>, usu. about 30 cm. long, with a faceted exterior and with a texture like that of a coarse melon. <i>(1988,Lexicographical & Linguistic Studies,192</i>)

>  <i>Carica pentagona</i> is called `babaco' by the natives and is regarded as a great delicacy. <i>(1921,Arkiv for Botanik,XVII. XII.4</i>) [NOTES: O. HEILBORN]

>  Because of its large fruits .. and because of its habit of producng seedless fruits, the <i>babaco</i> is worthy of attention in other countries. <i>(1924,Contr. National Herbarium (US),XXV. V. 126</i>) [NOTES: W. POPENOE]

>  <b>T. TANAKA</b> <i>Carica pentagona</i> .., `Babaco'. The flesh of fruits are nearly white, acid; eaten cooked, preserved or used in sauce. Ecuador & adj. territory. <i>(1976,Tanaka's Cycl. Edible Fruits,135</i>)

>  Group three: Blueberries, feijoas, avocado, tamarillos, cherries, babaco, persimmon, Asian pears, macadamias, pepino etc. <i>(1981,Southern Horticulture (N.Z.),Spring 16/1</i>)

>  Babaco orchards will be limited to frost-free climate requirements. <i>(Mar 1981,Orchardist NZ,LIV. 61/1</i>)

>  <i>The babaco .. is a perennial shrub of the papaya family (Caricacae) indigenous to the subtropical mountainous regions of Ecuador</i>. <i>(1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,XXVI. 237/1</i>)

>  <i>Babaco</i>. Brought to Australia via New Zealand from Equador [sic]... It is a relation of the paw-paw and has been an exceptional crop in New Zealand. <i>(Jan 21, 1984,Weekend Australian,21-22 Jan. 9</i>)

>  Kay also uses babacos to make a "great fruit loaf" by adding them to her home made bread. <i>(Jun 1990,NZ Gardener,34</i>)

>  The babaco grows in the same climate range as the mountain pawpaw, but has much larger fruits, comparable in size with the tropical papaya. <i>(1974,Orchardist NZ,259</i>)

>  Of the high-altitude fruiting plants that are native of Ecuador, the Babaco is the most promising fruit to be introduced into New Zealand from that country. <i>(Feb 1978,Orchardist NZ,18</i>)

>  [Caption] First impression gained by visitors to this orchard of babacos has been : "Little green men from Mars." <i>(Mar 1974,Orchardist NZ,59</i>)

>  <b>BOLLARD</b> The babaco, which is grown in Ecuador, was introduced here in 1973. <i>(1981,Prospects for Horticulture,116</i>)

>  We tried babacos but they got too large and started falling over in their buckets. <i>(1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),55</i>)

>  The babaco story began in 1977 when Dick Endt, a nurseryman from Oratia, near Auckland, introduced the first privately grown species into New Zealand........ The babaco belongs to the Caricaceae family, more commonly known as the papaya family. <i>(May 1982,NZ Gardener,24</i>)

>  <b>BURTON</b> BABACO... is a hybrid between two papaya (pawpaw) species, <i>Carica pubescens</i> (mountain papaya) and <i>C. stipulata</i>. . . first brought to the attention of the rest of the world by the botanist Heilborn, who named it <i>Carica pentagona</i>, meaning five-sided. The Ecuadorian name babaco (pronounced as in banana) has been retained in New Zealand. <i>(1985,Delectable Fruits Cookery,41</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Babaco juice is a favourite beverage in Ecuador where it is served in hotels. <i>(Mar 1974,Orchardist NZ,61</i>)

>  The Babaco industry is now 10 years old. <i>(1990,Exotic Fruit Forum,12</i>)

>  A major love in his garden was his babaco plants, which he grew in a glasshouse. These tropical melon-like fruits were an object of his pride - and we didn't mind eating them. <i>(Aug 31, 2000,Evening Post,16</i>)

## bachelorise
 
 <i>v.</i>



 
 <i>v.</i> to live alone as a bachelor, to `do' for oneself (often in the temporary absence of a spouse); to share living quarters, domestic chores and expenses, usu. with a person of the same sex. Often bachelorise with. [also bach Hence bachelorising ppl. aj. and vbl. n.] (See [also bach](../A#also-bach))

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>(1883,Facts Relating to NZ,8</i>) [NOTES: [see bachelorising]]

>  <b>HOPEFUL</b> They [Chinese] of course live very cheaply, because these communities are composed of men [133] bachelorizing together, they have no wives or children to support, as women are not allowed to leave China. <i>(1887,Taken In,132</i>)

>  <b>ROBERTS</b> Whom should I see but Mr - from Timaru, with whom, in days gone by, I had bachelorised. <i>(1985,Diary,9</i>)

>  Single men [at Cross Creek] had either to bachelorise in their whares or board with one or another of the married men. <i>(Mar 10, 1906,NZ Truth,5</i>)

>  <b>BAUGHAN</b> So he's bachelorisin', and I'm keeping house for him. <i>(1912,Brown Bread,129</i>)

>  <b>EVANS</b> <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,43</i>) [NOTES: Evans Waikaka Saga 42 or 43 quoting earlier source]

>  <b>OLIPHANT</b> We had then been bachelorising, and it was decided to break up the establishment. <i>(1905,Bill the Namer,6</i>)

## back
 
 <i>adj.</i> remote

<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [backing dog or woolwalker] to scamper along the backs of sheep to unblock bottlenecks in races etc.

## back country
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the high country beyond S.I. river gorges, as opposed to front down and plains land in front of the gorges and ranges. (See [backblocks](../B#backblocks))

>  I left Christchurch in company with a sheep farmer, who owns a run in the back country, behind the Malvern hills. <i>(1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,47</i>) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> Backblocks or backcountry: In the South Island that country beyond the river gorges is termed back country, as differing from front country which consists of those hills through whose gorges the same rivers wend their way. Backblocks is the equivalent North Island term though the nature of the rivers does not define them so neatly. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,2</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> Back-country. Land extending beyond and including the foothills; land beyond the river gorges. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,94</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) remote country. (See [backblocks](../B#backblocks))

>  <b>THOMSON</b> In the heavy back-country, the soil was being swept off steep faces and down the big rivers [back-country] <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,15</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [attributive uses below]

 <i>n.</i> [The hinterland of settled districts: US 1746 (OED), AND 1802; of a part 1849; of a settled dist. or station 1887.] The remoter parts of a farm or other area, away from the sea or other means of access. Also called backblocks. Compare front country. a. Usu. with def art., a hinterland, beyond settlements, or sparsely settled, remote from coastal or other means of access, often regarded from the point of view of its farming use or potential. In Canterbury, country towards the Southern Alps (cf front country). In later use, backblocks. [a hinterland, beyond settlements, or sparsely settled, remote from coastal or other means of access, often regarded from the point of view of its farming use or potential. In Canterbury, country towards the Southern Alps (cf front country).] (See [up-country](../U#up-country),[cf. front country](../F#front-country))

>  <b>GUTHRIE</b> A good story is told by a friend who was going into the back country on a visit. <i>(1930,NZ Memories,111</i>)

>  <b>BUCK</b> This back-country [of Canterbury] was in all probability ...subject to severe winters. <i>(1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,178</i>)

## back to the mat
 
 <i>phr.</i> in phrases: return/go back to the mat, get back on/to the mat: of a Europeanised Maori, to figuratively resume Maori dress; to return to Maori customs and way of life; to go native (cf. go back to the bush, bush) [-] (See [mat](../M#mat))

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the process in block-grazing where stock are fenced from behind to protect the recently-grazed area, encouraging them to move forward.

>  Mr Handley believes that back-fencing is worthwhile to save damage to pasture and allow a quicker recovery. <i>(Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,03</i>)

>  Back-fencing helps to eliminate pugging by restricting stock movement. <i>(Dec 1964,NZ Journal of Agriculture,533</i>)

>  Benefits of Power fence systems .. make strip grazing and back fencing easy. <i>(1996,Gallagher Power Fence Manual,4</i>)

>  The Toplesses have also realised the benefits of backfencing ... [backfencing] <i>(Nov 9, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,17</i>)



## back-gifting
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Keep notes to prevent "back-gifting" - re-gifting to the person who gifted it to you. <i>(Dec 22, 2005,NZ Herald,D1</i>)



## back-graze
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to re-graze on crop or pasture previously grazed by the same stock.

>  <b>STEVENS</b> There have been cases when hoggets back-grazed over earlier-eaten breaks of supplementary feed have suffered severely from worm infestation. <i>(1958,Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,65</i>)



## back-land
 
 <i>n.</i> of a port rather than back-country;

>  I have most carefully examined every part of it, and although the back-land is rugged and precipitous there is a much larger portion of it level than I have yet seen in the Bay, and fully sufficient to afford space for a very pretty and convenient town. <i>(1842,GBPP,(No.569) 145</i>) [NOTES: 1840 Mathew to Hobson in GBPP 1842]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an out-lying area of a station, possibly supporting an out-station.

>  <b>EVANS</b> And so this couple settled down in this back-land home [out-station] and no doubt loneliness was a problem. <i>(1975,Silver Tussock, The,103</i>)



## back-legs
 
 <i>n.</i>



## back-load
 
 <i>v.</i> to carry on a return or `back' trip.

>  <b>HISLOP</b> But the usual thing for the Styx settlers so far inland was to back-load with a year's supply of good quality coal picked up at Waipiata railway yards ... <i>(1943,Pure Gold,117</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Sometimes our trips to the Bend were profitable for there were wool and hides to be taken out and fertilizers and general cargo to backload. <i>(1953,Golden Bush, The,76,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Bush rats at night sometimes made their way into our schooners when they were loaded with general merchandise, or back-loaded with small quantities of farm produce. <i>(1961,Friends in Chains,122</i>)

>  <b>PINNEY</b> They contracted [in 1881] to cart to Kurow for 34s 4d a ton, and to backload at 23s. Many of these backloads were of coal. <i>(1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,34</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a load or freight carried on the return journey from carrying a main load.

>  <b>BAINES</b> Reserving some 30lbs ... for my back-load home. <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,205</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> He would get two or three back-loads of manuka. <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,112</i>)

>  They contracted [in 1881] to cart to Kurow for 34s 4d a ton, and to backload at 23s. Many of these backloads were of coal. <i>(1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,34</i>)



## back-out
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an early design of cowshed, in which a cow must back out after milking [rather than walk out the front as in a walk-through.]

>  <b>POWDRELL</b> There are many types of cow-shed, for example the Race, the Double bail, the Single back-out, and the Walk-through type of shed. <i>(1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,22</i>)

>  <b>BELSHAW</b> In modern sheds the walk-through type of bail has completely superseded the old back-out type. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,456</i>)

>  Design of cowshed: back-out. <i>(2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB)</i>)



## back-scarf
 
 <i>v.</i> to scarf a tree on the side opposite the direction of intended fall. (See [cf. scarf v](../S#scarf-v))

>  He went out into the bush and backscarfed a big tree so that it would fall in one particular direction. <i>(1892,One Lady at Wairakei,36,1983 ed.</i>)

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> He will `belly-scarf' and `back-scarf' the lot, that is to say he will cut about one third through on the lower and upper sides [of the tree]. <i>(1928,Pioneering in Poverty Bay,38</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a scarf or cut so made (See [also back-cut](../A#also-back-cut))

>  <b>WILSON</b> If you go too deep [with the belly-scarf], the tree might split and fall before you put in the back-scarf; ... <i>(1955,Land of My Children,24</i>)



## back-set
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a stock carcass, arranged in a particular manner for display purposes.

>  Back-set: a carcass arranged to stiffen in a certain way so that it can be used for display purposes. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,3</i>)



## back-shunt
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  There the waggons and van would be left on the 'main' while the others were hauled out of the back-shunt and set back to rejoin the train... <i>(Dec 2002,NZ Memories,No. 39/54</i>)



## back-slack
 
 <i>v.</i> to answer back, to cheek, to back-chat

>  <b>SMYTH</b> Think I'm going to sit here and let this -- this farm labourer back-slack us. <i>(1929,Bonzer Jones,237</i>)



## back-slappy
 
 <i>adj.</i> hearty mannered

>  Given the ethnic background, the history and introverted nature of the society, it was obviously not a place of happy back-slappy outward-goers, like say some of the coal towns on the West Coast, but then of course, what are, or were? <i>(Nov 1986,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,74/79</i>)



## back-up
 
 <i>n.</i> retaliation, revenge.

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> It was rare for a dispute to take place without at least talk of a back-up (retaliation) afterwards, ... <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,79</i>)



## back-up colony
 
 <i>n.</i> a tool of animal population conservation

>  Another six chicks were taken to Moutohora (Whale Island) to start a back-up colony. <i>(Sep 7, 2005,NZ Herald,A14</i>)



## backblock
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a remote farming area.

>  The condition of some roads in the 'back-blocks' still calls out loudly for ameliorating action. <i>(Jan 8, 1905,Hawera Star,2</i>)

>  .. it is hoped to provide for the benefit of settlers in the backblocks, the government will be in as till better position to improve the lot of the primary producers ... <i>(Jul 1925,NZ Dairy Exporter,35</i>)

>  His research was helped by his wife, Diane, who comes from the backblocks of Hawke's Bay. <i>(Nov 8, 2001,Dominion,17</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> The pioneering father-figure of contemporary New Zealand imagination was man who went out to the back-blocks ( a term which originally referred to blocks of land purchased from the Maoris, but came to mean remote farming districts.). <i>(1951,History of New Zealand,149</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [South Island ranges] the mountainous farming land behind the river gorges.

>  <b>MCDONALD</b> The Merino provides good wool returns in its natural quarters - the mountainous back blocks. <i>(1915,NZ Sheepfarming,37</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> Backblocks or backcountry: In the South Island that country beyond the river gorges is termed back country .. Backblocks is the equivalent North Island term though the nature of the rivers does not define them so neatly. [back blocks; back-blocks] <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,2</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> sg. a (survey) block of land remote from the main station or homestead, or from the coast; also compounded as a collective, remote blocks of land.

>  The back Block here. <i>(1852,McLean Papers,10/156</i>)

>  The back Block here. <i>(1852,McLean Papers,10/156</i>)

>  <b>CHAMIER</b> [The house] was used as head-station for a sheep run, comprising several `back blocks' ... that extended for many miles over bleak and rugged country. <i>(1895,South Sea Siren,161</i>)

>  To facilitate the working of the station, there were three places where the hands resided. The Homestead, ... the chief one, was at the end of the station nearest civilisation. About eight miles further back was a cottage, known as the `Out-Station' ... [Further back] the Ruahine whare ... This whare was therefore the furthest back habitation ... It was erected for the accommodation of shepherds when mustering the back-blocks. <i>(Apr 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,48</i>)

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> The Merino provides good wool returns in its natural quarters - the mountainous back blocks. <i>(1915,NZ Sheepfarming,37</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> In the fifties he early became aware of the efforts of the runholding class to open up the backblocks. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,117</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a section of a farm or station, far from the homestead.

>  This whare was .. the furthest back habitation. It was erected for the accommodation of shepherds when mustering the back-blocks. <i>(1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,48</i>)

>  A party of six rabbiters, isolated by snow in backblocks of St Helen's Station, 30 miles behind Hanmer Springs, were supplied by air yesterday. <i>(Jul 4, 1947,Hawera Star,06</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. from the road it seems only a stone's throw across to that station's back block right under Arowhana itself. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,245</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Otairi had a second woolshed in its backblock and Alf got sick of toast and marmalade so he pinned a scone recipe to the inside of a cupboard of the cookhouse there. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,172</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> In jocular use, the farther suburbs of a city

>  [headline] Bus visits backblocks of Karori. <i>(Jun 16, 1987,Karori and Western Suburbs News,16</i>)



## backblock(s)
 
 <i>n.</i> the sparsely settled hinterland of more closely-settled districts (See [back country](../B#back-country),[boohai](../B#boohai),[sticks](../S#sticks))

>  He also brought a knowledge of the bush and back country that was invaluable to young field geologists such as myself and David Kerr, translated from urban England to work in the back-blocks of New Zealand. <i>(Mar 1994,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,103/87</i>)

>  <i>(Jan 16, 1890,Otago Witness,31</i>) [NOTES: We had listened reverently to an elderly stranger from the back-blocks, who took upon himself to explain to us that the men clad in calfskins and goatskins represented the tanners and curriers' trades.]

>  Upon the plains of Buenos Ayres, and into the furthest back-blocks of Australia and New Zealand the Waterbury Watch has found its way. <i>(Jun 2, 1890,Taranaki Herald,4</i>)

>  <b>MANSFIELD</b> We sleep tonight at the Rangataiki & then the plains & the back blocks. <i>(1907,Letters,1/32,1984 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WHEELER</b> Although living in the back-blocks, (North Islanders say `in the sticks', presumably referring to bush or scrub) station people seem to encounter more than their fair share of incident. <i>(1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,100</i>)

 <i>adj.</i> (Rural) characteristic of the back country, often conveying a meaning of undeveloped understanding or unworldliness. [aka back-block, back-blocks; [AND back-block 1868.] In early use usu. backblock; later backblocks.]

>  The backblocks woman looked at her very gravely.. <i>(Oct 26, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,Magazine Section 1</i>)

>  Waitress: "What will you take to drink, Sir - Tea or Beer?" Backblocks Bill (scathingly): "Now which do I look as though I'd take?" <i>(Nov 1, 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,159</i>)

>  The backblock settler's burden was out of proportion to his ability to pay. <i>(Jun 30, 1944,Hamilton Courier,2</i>)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> The first thing I had to do [on arriving at Wellington] was to get a new rig-out, as my backblock clothes were not in keeping with my important duties [as a civil servant]. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,55</i>) [NOTES: 1935 ed.]

>  The clean-limbed hard backblocks-men mustering in the river arm. <i>(1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,3/254</i>)

>  Choicest back-blocks Billingsgate. <i>(1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,8/128</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> [get cit] [Frequently throughout] any backblock editor. <i>(1909,Ballads about Business</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> His back-block talk he can never forget. <i>(1900,Wisps of Tussock,24</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> Lonely back-blocks country. <i>(1904,Tussock Land,35</i>)

>  Slowly perhaps, but surely, we hope the Back-blocks District Nursing Scheme is progressing... No back-block settler .. will be too far away to get help in their time of trouble. <i>(Jan 1910,Kai Tiaki,28</i>)

>  A real back-block race-meeting as you ever did see. <i>(1911,Kiwi on the Swag,6</i>)

>  I love the little backblock schools. <i>(Aug 1917,Princes Street,9</i>)

>  <b>DEVANNY</b> The apt cunning of Taihape's hotel-keeper, long inured to back-blocks men's customs.., saw to that. <i>(1926,Butcher Shop, The,86</i>) [NOTES: 1981 ed.]

>  <b>CLOKE</b> We will give our backblock brothers What the Lord to us imparts. <i>(1931,Songs of NZ,210</i>)

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> Each little group was dependent upon itself for amusement and entertainment, and visitors were a peg on which to hang some simple backblock festivities. <i>(1933,Tides of Youth,55</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> The traditional fare of the backblocks stations was the traditional colonial menu of tea, damper and mutton for breakfast. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,41</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> All the early runs and backblocks settlements could have much easier done without horses than without draught bullocks. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,41</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Several miles beyond this block, out across the rolling gumland hills .. lay a back-block section, a bush farm in the early stages of development. <i>(1956,Green Kiwi,38</i>) [NOTES: 1960 ed.]

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> I grew to awareness rejecting as alien our scrubby backblocks farm. <i>(1959,New Zealanders, The,10</i>) [NOTES: 1986 ed.]

>  <b>ELLIOTT & ADSHEAD</b> A little house still standing today in the backblock settlement of Apiti, about 28 miles north of Fielding. <i>(1967,Cowshed to Dog Collar,14</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSON</b> A simple phrase ... as he entered the dining-room would amuse the guests who probably wondered from what backblock country he had come. <i>(1970,Life's Vagaries,103</i>)

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> Well, it looked a mighty big town to my backblock eyes but you'd think it pretty quaint... `You can't go about the city looking like a little backblock Maori,' she said. <i>(1973,Brown Man's Burden,128</i>)

>  <b>MCKEE WRIGHT</b> But his back-block talk he can never forget, He's the same as he was on the station yet. <i>(1900,Wisps of Tussock,24</i>)

>  <b>WESTMACOTT</b> He certainly had not the backblocks temperament, and failed to enjoy sleeping on the floor that night. <i>(1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,159</i>)

>  <b>MARRIOTT</b> But when a townie is suddenly transplanted from the city to a real backblocks farm. <i>(1981,Life in the Gorge,9</i>)

>  <b>HINDMARSH</b> Bunny had had his taste of backblock farming and was able to sell his shares at a 350% increase in value. <i>(1997,Come Be a Pioneer,42</i>)

>  <b>HOLDEN</b> While Phil chatted, in a low-key backblocks fashion, his grey horse was keeping a surreptitious eye on me. [back-block/s] <i>(2001,Riding Country,53</i>)

## Balkan Tap
 
 <i>n.</i> a wartime condition of madness (facetious)

>  In this land two infections assail all comers and vie with one another for first place. These are known as Malaria and Balkan Tap respectively. On the first we need not dwell, but a little information about the latter may be of interest. A similar infection has been met with elsewhere, and in Gyppo Land is known as `magnune', whilst away in our own sunny island I think `dippy' about covered it. Here we have a more or less insidious form of the disease, and no one with six months' residence to his credit may hope to escape. There are two varieties of the disease, malignant and benign. In the latter form the symptoms are easily recognised, and are amenable to treatment; but with the malignant type the victims, quite unconscious of infection, blindly affirm their condition to be normal, This form of the malady has several unfortunate features and is incurable. The percentage in our unit is very high. <i>(Sep 15, 1918,Kia-ora Coo-ee,Second Series 3/12,1981 ed.</i>)

## ballast bag
 
 <i>n.</i> a gastrolith in a seal's stomach

>  <b>BEGG</b> At the Auckland Islands in 1864 Captain Thomas Musgrave noticed female sealions disgorging small pebbles which he thought must have been picked up inadvertently while catching fish on the sea floor. ... The practical sealers believed that the stones served to adjust the buoyancy of the animals and referred to the stone-filled stomach of the fur seal as the `ballast bag'. <i>(1979,World of John Boultbee, The,155</i>)

## ballies
 
 <i>n.</i> a ball-bearing used as a marble

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)



## balloon
 
 <i>n.</i> A metal object on a staff above the totalisator to indicate whether it was open for betting; the all ready signal for a race to begin: ? orig. a balloon hoisted.

>  However, the balloon is down for both stocks. In the days before modern communications at the races, a balloon signalled that the tote was open. When it went up it was a sign that the tote was closed and the horses were ready to race. And as very punter knew, when the balloon fell your money remained at risk until the race ended and the winner was declared. <i>(Mar 10, 2003,Dominion Post,C2</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a race is about to begin

>  <b>SARGESON</b> balloon: <i>The balloon came down.</i> The balloon is raised above the number-board by the finishing-post to indicate to the starter that the Tote is closed. It is lowered when the Tote is balanced to indicate that the race can begin. <i>(1964,Collected Stories,297</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (confused with the general sense associated with beginning).

## banded kokopu
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Whitebait are the juveniles of our migratory galaxiid fishes. These scaleless fish species include the inanga (around much of the country), banded kokopu (especially around Auckland) and koaro (especially in streams draining bush-covered and mountain areas. <i>(Apr 2005,National Waterways Project,18/1</i>)

>  <b>McDOWALL</b> Much less common is the banded kokopu (<i>Galaxias fasciatus</i>) sometimes known as Maori trout or native trout... Some whitebaiters refer to it as "golden bait". <i>IBid.</i> 49 Banded kokopu are also aggressive migrants, climbing high falls and penetrating substantial distances inland, reaching localities that seem inaccessible. <i>(1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The,13</i>)

>  Now they are once again an undisturbed habitat for such creatures as the banded kokopu. This native fish hides by day under overhanging bush, emerging at night to lie in wait for prey, typically the larvae of aquatic insects, or land invertebrates, such as caterpillars and spiders, that fall into the water. <i>(Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 60?50</i>)

>  Banded kokopu (<i>G. fasciatus</i>) and koaro (<i>G. brevipinnis</i>) constitute the bulk of remainder [sic], with very few giant kokopu and shortjaw kokopu being caught. <i>(2006,National Geographic Magazine,#77, Jan - Feb 2006, p31</i>)

>  The banded kokopu is another whitebait species reaching 26 cm. Its habitat is a pool in a small bush-covered stream which may be a considerable [73] altitude and distance from the sea. <i>(1983,Land of the Mist,72</i>)

>  <b>DENNIS</b> The juveniles of five species of galaxias make up the whitebait catch: inanga (<i>Galaxias maculatus</i>), koaro (<i>G. brevipinnis</i>), banded kokopu (<i>G. fasciatus</i>), giant kokopu (<i>G. argenteus</i>) and short-jawed kokopu (<i>G. postvectis</i>). <i>(1981,Paparoas Guide,187</i>)

>  The banded kokopu is another whitebait species reaching 26 cm. Its habitat is a pool in a small bush-covered stream which may be a considerable [73] altitude and distance from the sea. <i>(1983,Land of the Mist,72</i>)

>  <i>Banded kokopu Galaxias fasciatus </i>Widely distributed in forest streams and swamps. Small amber-coloured whitebait. <i>(1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,48</i>)

>  On the West Coast, the season runs from September 1 till November 14 to improve the minor late-running species' chance of reaching coastal wetlands for giant kokopu, or forest-covered streams for short-jawed and banded kokopu, and koaro. <i>(Nov 11, 2003,Dominion Post,A18</i>)

>  [caption] <b>Under water:</b> Native fish found in the region's [Wellington] rivers and streams are, clockwise from top left, inanga, redfin bully, torrent fish, banded kokopu, giant kokopu and kaoro. <i>(May 7, 2005,Natural History of Canterbury,A21</i>)

>  Inanga are the most common species, but whitebaiters may also capture the young of giant kokopu, koaro and banded kokopu. "Shortjaw and giant kokopu are described as threatened species. ..." <i>(Aug 17, 2005,Whakatane Beacon</i>)

## bandicoot

>  Jane Godfrey, My father used to tell (c 19..) us to bandicoot about a bit when he wanted us to dig out bits of earth (say around a post) with our hands, sort of pulling the earth towards the side of the hole, softening it, etc. <i>(1985,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: AC1898; nf W3]

>  Another was also proud of the growth of his potatoes but highly amazed and full of anger when upon digging them up he found virtually nothing underneath. He was unaware that some bright sparks had on one night bandicooted his spuds. ## banjo
 
 <i>n.</i> a shovel [f. the shape]; also attrib banjo shovel. [>ca1950s p.c. F.M. O'Brien Invercargill, <i>A banjo</i>: A shovel.]

>  He performed the herculean(?) [sic] task of turning the first sod of the Waihi-Tauranga railway, with a specially sand-papered and varnished `banjo' of rather less than the orthodox No. 5 size. <i>(Mar 22, 1912,Maoriland Worker,54/9/2</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> The use of the pick and `banjo' (as the long-handled shovel is termed) is very useful accomplishment. <i>(1913,Country Work,20</i>)

>  It's a long time since you handled a `banjo'. <i>(1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,105</i>)

>  A banjo: A shovel. <i>(1950,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: ca1950s p.c. F.M. O'Brien Invercargill,]

>  .. a part of the West Coast's heritage as a digger's pan or banjo shovel. <i>(Jul 4, 1973,Dominion,5</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> When Jimmy finally gave the mustering game away he took on a job with the local county council _ on the pick and shovel. ... Jimmy claimed that [is] old dog was so humiliated at seeing his boss using a `banjo' that he lay down and died. <i>(1973,Big Country,205</i>) [NOTES: 1977 ed.]

>  <b>HUNT</b> And they'd go down the mine, ... scrape the coal down and load it into the skips by hand with great big `banjo' shovels. Then there were the old `pit-spiders', steel hooks you'd jab into the mine wall and hang your lamp on. <i>(1981,Speaking a Silence,133</i>)

>  Not for me the noisy proline/ but the quiet of the auger and fang-spanner - / long tom and jim crow,/ strumming on the old banjo./ ... [fn] long tom: long blade used for placing measured amount of gravel under sleepers jim crow: large horseshoe-shaped tool, with screw, used for bending rails banjo: shovel <i>(Mar 1, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11</i>) [NOTES: David George `Euchre Weather']

>  <b>HOLLAND</b> He [NCO of Detention Camp, Field Punishment Centre] immediately ordered me to `grab a banjo' and go over and help fill sandbags. <i>(1919,Armageddon or Calvary,65</i>)

>  <b>BATTYE & EAKIN</b> banjo shovels special coal shovels with a large round blade. <i>Ibid.</i> 36 ... the gold miners enter ... carrying ... shovels. Their shovels are different from the `banjo' shovels of the coal-miners. <i>(1980,Shadow of the Valley,72</i>) [NOTES: Glossary]

>  See me in a dirty shirt, torn slacks (with red down the sides like a postman), sandbags for puttees and hobnail boots, without a wash or a shave for five days, swinging a pick or a long-handled 'banjo'. <i>(Feb 22, 1916,Hawera Star,4</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Ever use a banjo before?... I mean a shovel, chum. <i>(1971,Our Open Country,107</i>)

>  <i>banjo ... NZ & Austral. sl.</i> shovel. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,53</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; cf. 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 38]]

>  We were still wielding the old "Banjo" in good style. <i>(Aug 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,V/51 : 56</i>)

## bank and bank
 
 <i>phr.</i> of a river, in flood; cf. banker.

>  <b>BUTLER</b> Sometimes, perhaps half a dozen times in a year, the river is what is called bank and bank; that is to say, one mass of water from one side to the other. <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,vi/79</i>) [NOTES: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year vi 79]

>  I heard the Rakaia was bank and bank so I went to Harman's to see O.Brien. <i>(Jan 30, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,120,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <i>bank and bank</i>. A river runs bank and bank when all the streams join into one; i.e., when in high flood (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 73). Hence a banker. The expressions were probably introduced by the shagroons. [Morris Austral English] gives a banker as meaning a river full to the top of its banks. New Zealand rivers, of course, do not get as full as that. <i>(Sep 9, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

## Barber
 
 <i>n.</i> the prevailing Greymouth wind; a cold, cutting wind [ADD the vapour rising from the water on a frosty day: 1895: Can., NB, NS, Nfdland: DARE A winter storm in which frozen ice crystals are driven by fierce winds. 1832, 1889 Farmer (Cn.), 1889 St Laurence, Nova Scotia New England coast, 1982 strong wind that carries precipitation which freezes beard etc: DNfE 1. Cold mist or vapour arising from the sea on a frosty day; frost-smoke 1836 2. A sharp, stinging wind 1879: OED2 1c transf. Applied colloq. to a bitterly cold wind which seems to `cut' the face. Chiefly Can and NZ. Also = frost-smoke (cf Frost n 7c 1830 Can); 1933 NZ cf J Angus Gloss of Shetland Dialect: Barber, a haze which rises from the surface of the water with very keen freezing.] Often constr. with def. art., a keen, cutting wind (often with mist or fog). NZ orig. a West Coast, SI use, but by the 1950s fairly gen. in other parts of the SI, but not heard or recorded in the North: popularly derived from its being, e.g., `close cutting', `as keen as a razor', [ca1910 Havelock, W.H.B.Orsman, Usually refers to a keen or cutting, cold northerly, often blowing off the frost or off the water.]

>  <b>BARR</b> They have a prevailing wind at Greymouth called "The Barber" which sweeps down the Otira Gorge and smites the inhabitants hip and thigh... a keen biting wind which cuts like a sabre-thrust, nips like an ant, and stings like a whip-lash.`What do you think of `The Barber'?' in Greymouth is synonymous with `What do you think of our harbour?' in Sydney ... <i>(1908,With the British Rugby team,75</i>)

>  <b>94</b> The wind coming off the river was so sharp it was called The Barber, and it could shave off your hangover in brisk, terrible seconds. <i>(Mar 20, 2004,BLANK ENTRY</i>)

>  There is a wind in Westland.. so much colder than freezing point that they nickname it "The Barber". <i>(Jul 28, 1938,NZ Observer,8</i>)

>  The wind you get in Greymouth, the one they call the Barber, which slices along the Grey River and is so sharp that it can cure any hangover known to man. <i>(Jul 10, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94</i>)

>  A very bitter cold wind which blows down the gorge of the Mawhera and afflicts the river front, railway station, and adjacent streets of Greymouth. The miners and drovers used the word in the 'sixties, and it is still in use. (C.[1890-1910]) <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>PUGH-WILLIAMS</b> A very cold, slow-moving wind that comes down to Greymouth from the inland of a winter evening and then recedes the following day. It brings foggy conditions and is most unpleasant. I am unaware of its origin but locals inform me that it is nowhere as bad as some 20 years ago, their theory being that so much of the bush is cut out with the result that rain-saturated foliage is not exposed for fog-generating. <i>(1951,Letter</i>)

>  <b>PEARSON</b> This day was clear. There was a frost on the grass in the morning, and a `barber' - the keen wind and night mist blowing down from the Grey Valley - was pushing across Blakestown ... and disappearing over the sea. <i>(1963,Coal Flat,393</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> There are several local names for winds, the <i>doctor</i> in Perth, ... the <i>barber</i> in Greymouth, N Z, a very cuttng wind, the Canterbury <i>nor'wester</i> resembling the European <i>Fo[diereis]hn</i> wind, ... and the<i> three-day sou'wester </i> in New Zealand, a form of the <i>southerly buster</i>, a name used in both Australia and New Zealand, probably more often in the shortened form a [sic] <i>southerly. </i> <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,163</i>)

>  <i>Barber, the n.</i> Greymouth, N.Z. term for a bitter, cold wind. <i>(1969,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),3</i>)

## barracouta
 
 <i>n.</i> 1. <i>Thyrsites atun.</i> =manga [the <i>snoek, snook</i> of the Cape of Good Hope]. Freq. spg bar(r)acoota; also barac(o)uta, barrac(o)uda, benecoota, benecootoo, ?boracoota, ?paracuta . ## basic slag/slag
 
 <i>n.</i> a fertiliser [see slag]

>  Advt.] V.O.B. Basic Slag is cheaper this year. The value of Slag Top-Dressing need not be stressed. <i>(Dec 18, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,10</i>)

>  The relative merits of superphosphate and basic slag for pasture top-dressing are much discussed in certain districts, particularly North Taranaki and North Auckland. Many experienced farmers are firmly of the opinion that slagged pastures have better milk production and fattening capacities than ones treated with superphosphate. How much this may be due to a greater effect from slag, how much to some effect on the mineral content of the herbage, and how much due to management it is impossible to say. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,389</i>)

>  Mr E. M. Smith stated before the members of the Iron and Steel Institute, London, that the slag from the ironsand smelting was worth 15s per ton as a manure, and it was quite equal to the basic slag from the furnaces at Home. <i>(Aug 17, 1896,Taranaki Herald,3</i>)

## basket fungus
 
 <i>n.</i> an unpleasant-smelling fungus, <i>Ileodictyon cibarium</i>, that expands to release a latticed structure from a white sphere (also called devil's purse or stink egg, lattice or net fungus, paruwhatitiri, thunder-dirt). (See [paruwhatitiri](../P#paruwhatitiri),[net fungus](../N#net-fungus))

>  <b>CROWE</b> Basket fungus starts off growing rather like a puffball 3-4 cm wide, but later, when the ball bursts, a white basket-like shape breaks out... The Maori ate the thick gelatinous volva or outer shell when young and before it burst. <i>(1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,123</i>)

>  <i>Clathrus cibarius</i>, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,' `<i>tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua</i>,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand] <i>(1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/247</i>) [NOTES: Cunningham]

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>Matakupenga ... 3. Clathrus cibarium</i>, net or basket fungus. = <i>pukurau.</i> <i>(1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,188</i>)

>  The Maori treated unexpanded plants of the basket fungus as a great luxury. <i>(Oct 1959,Tararua Tramper,10</i>)

>  <b>MARTIN</b> ... the Phalloids to which belong such conspicuous fungi as the SCARLET STINKHORN (<i>Aseroe rubra</i>) and the BASKET FUNGUS (<i>Clathrus cibarius</i>). [40]The BASKET FUNGUS or LATTICE FUNGUS spreads its globular latticed network a conspicuous white, slimy structure with an unpleasant odour, that never fails to amaze its beholders. Its miraculous and sudden appearance caused the ancient Maori to term it `thunder dirt'. <i>(1929,Flora NZ,39,1961 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1961 ed.]

>  <b>MOORE & IRWIN</b> <i>Clathrus cibarius</i>, basket fungus. <i>(1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,12</i>)

>  [photo captions] (1) Honey mushroom (2) Red tobacco pouch fungus (3) Violet tobacco pouch fungi ... (5) Basket or lattice fungus. <i>(1983,Land of the Mist,64</i>)

>  In the home garden, a fairly common fungus found in potting mix, compost and bark mulch is the Ileodictyon cibarius white basket fungus. It has an eerie, skeletal appearance and is fascinating to watch grow. <i>(May 18, 2007,Nelson Mail,B15</i>)

>  At one stage of its growth, the open-look basket-fungus, Clathrus cibarius, is edible. <i>(Jun 8, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,64</i>)



## basket social
 
 <i>n.</i> a social event where food is raffled or sold to raise money

>  A well attended basket social was held at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. P. Maclean, Kelvin Road, Waimumu on Friday evening, ... <i>(Apr 11, 1921,Mataura Ensign</i>) [NOTES: in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 363]

>  Basket social: a1949 North Auckland. As I understood it a function for making money. People bring a `basket' (in the sense `Ladies, a basket') of food which is auctioned and often re-auctioned. <i>(Jun 7, 1952,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: R. Mason Letter]

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country), The way in which the bush people - the bushmen and their wives - stuck to one another is shown by the way they rallied round in the case of a family that was in need. A common method of raising money was called a `basket social'. A hall would be used for the function, and the people of the district would be invited to bring along baskets. Now these baskets were made of any material at all at hand, and it was remarkable the ingenuity and workmanship shown in making them. ... In the basket its maker put a supper, the food cooked at home ... [151] Now on the night of the basket social, all the baskets would be handed in ... They would then be auctioned, and the purchaser of the basket would have the pleasure and the honour of having supper with the provider of the basket. ... Now I've seen them pay twelve ... pounds in those days for a basket, just to make sure that the girl of the boy's choice saw that he really meant business. ... Every penny of that would go to the family in need ... <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,150</i>)

>  <b>BATISTICH</b> Basket socials were always a stir [in Northland c1920s]. ... Basket socials were the nearest we got to bacchanalia - tipsy cake in large doses could have strangely affecting results. The baskets were put up for auction just before the supper waltz; highest bidder got basket and girl - the girl, sometimes it turned out, for life. <i>(1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,146</i>)

>  <b>BOSWEL</b> And then the mill workers organized a big basket social for us, and with the money they arranged a grand picnic. <i>Ibid.</i> 153 [pre WW1, Northland bush], A basket social took the form of a dance, with an auction of supper baskets. Each girl would make a pretty basket and fill it with good things for supper. When supper-time came, the baskets were auctioned from the stage and keen was the rivalry and competition for some of the baskets, young blades emptying their pockets and often dipping into their bank accounts in trying to out-bid their rivals. <i>(1955,Dim Horizons,31</i>) [NOTES: Northland 1890's]

>  A basket social and dance.. for Maori soldiers.. turned out an unqualified success. <i>(Jul 18, 1918,Hawke's Bay Herald,5</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> A common method of raising money was called a 'basket social'... The people of the district would be invited to bring along baskets. Now these baskets were made of any material at all to hand... In the baskets, the maker put a supper... Nobody knew who was the owner of the basket. They would then be auctioned. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,150</i>)

## bastard
 
 <i>n.</i> fellow, chap, joker, or as a term of address for a friend, esp. old bastard [As an informal term of both kindly and unkindly ref. and address without suggestion of illegitimacy more associated with Aust. than NZ, though as common here since the late 19c. as in that larger place: see AND: 1. of persons 1892; 2. of anything considered disagreeable or unpleasant 1919.]

For instance he used the word bastard as the Americans use guy, and as we were then beginning to use bloke, to mean anyone about whom he was speaking ... <i>(1944,Moonshine,87</i>) [NOTES: [Context NZ-Irish community c1880's]]

 <i>n.</i> have a bastard on (with) somebody: to be angry with, or upset with, or angry towards, somebody [cf. to have a cob on ca1943 p.c. Donald A. Singe (Sep 1952)] (See [cf. to have a cob on](../T#to-have-a-cob-on))



 
 <i>adj.</i> as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants which resemble (but often cannot match qualities of) their namesakes; or occas. have displeasing or nasty (`bastardly') qualities (e.g. astard-grass): see birch; grass, bastard grass; pine, black; puriri, sandalwood; thistle, nodding; thistle, scotch [check that not deleted in editing]; totara.



 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> blow like a bastard. [of weather] to blow strongly

>  <b>HILGENDORF [& CALDER]</b> BATHURST BURR (<i>Xanthium spinosum</i>) `is not uncommon in warm and rich soils from the North Cape to the Waikato, rarer southwards to Wellington,' but occurs only on waste lands and corners of cultivated fields. ## batwing
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HARPER</b> Our camp has not yet been described, and ... it is the simplest and best form of shelter for a party of two, ... It is an invention of Douglas's, and we call it a `batwing'. In the ordinary course of camp life, survey parties can have their loads packed on horseback, and carry tent and fly, with a second smaller fly to pitch at the end of the tent to shelter the fire. We ... [51] could not afford to take such a weighty camp. We therefore pitch an ordinary 6 ft. by 8 ft. canvas tent, on a ridge pole, with an 8 ft. by 10 ft. fly six inches above it; and cut the tent in half along the ridge, and taking away one half, leave the other half standing. This is just large enough to allow two men to lie `heads and tails'. [The side left open, and one side of fly raised 4 ft. in middle, and under this the fire burns so have shelter in wet weather.] <i>(1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,50</i>)

## bayonet grass
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Aciphylla</i> spp., an old name for speargrass or taramea, contrast <i>A. squarrosa</i> a little later `soft leaved Spear grass', =spear-grass cf bayonet-plant. [[Could this have any priority over or connection with NZ Spaniard: the dating would suggest otherwise: phs from same metaphorical conception:]

Hence a `Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley, `Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ... <i>(1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,49</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> They formed with the gigantic <i>Aciphylla Colensoi</i>, the Spaniard or Bayonet grass, ... which ... most severely punished man and horse. <i>(1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,25</i>)

## be in
 
 <i>phr.</i> to join in; to get started; to be active in; take part in, or one's fair share of, whatever is going on; get stuck in. (Often an exclam. be in! as an invitation, or in expressions `You gotta be in (to win); you gotta be quick', that is, take your share or somebody else will get it.) [(often imper.)]

>  Temptation was placed in their way and they decided, to use a colloquialism, to `be in' [on a two-up school]. <i>(Nov 10, 1941,Evening Post,6/3</i>) [NOTES: Nov. 10 or Nov. 16?]

>  <b>SARGESON</b> We got Maggie to come and be in as well [sc. on a party]. <i>(1946,That Summer,85</i>)

>  <b>GASKELL</b> We got Maggie to come and be in as well [sc. on a party]. <i>(1947,Big Game,32</i>)

>  `Come in and get your share' (usually of food). I have heard it frequently among trampers. e.g. `Be in now or you may miss out.' <i>(1953,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: R. Mason]

>  <b>SLATTER</b> One for Herbie... Be in, it's ya birthday Herbie. And the man in the chair pushes through the mob with hands decked with glasses ... <i>(1969,Gun in My Hand, A,90</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> One for Herbie... Be in, it's ya birthday Herbie. And the man in the chair pushes through the mob with hands decked with glasses ... <i>(1969,Gun in My Hand, A,90</i>)

>  <b>HILLIARD</b> `The old girl just brought in the famous tray,' the girl said. `Come on, you better be in or the rest of them'll clean it up.' <i>(1960,Maori Girl,73</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> quoting Sargeson That Summer I was one of the first to be in. sc get stuck in <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,138</i>)

>  <b>HOOPER</b> `You coming along?' [19] `Yeah, I'll come,' I said casually. `Might as well be in.' <i>(1981,Goat Paddock,18</i>)



 
 <i>phr.</i> (as imperative) take one's full share of a round of drinks

>  Drinking on the West Coast has an etiquette of its own. It condones none of the `bob-in' touch of a city bar when a man will have the two drinks he wants and then leave. `Be in or be out', you will be told, is the motto on the Coast. <i>(1948,NZ Geographer,166</i>) [NOTES: Pascoe `Coal from Buller']



## be in it
 
 <i>phr.</i> to be in the race (lit. or fig.).

 <i>phr.</i> be in on (something, on a course of action) [P8 to have a share in ca 1919.] to have a part, or share, in.

 <i>phr.</i> be well off, comfortably placed

## be in to win
 
 <i>phr.</i> in various expressions: be in to win, be in like shags to a dead fish (1958 West Coast), be in like rats (ca1940), be in like maggots on a dead sheep [nf W3]. [ca1949 R. Mason, `They'll be in like ...' heard in Westland]

## be on a fuss
 
 <i>phr.</i> to be made a fuss of, be given special treatment

## be on the crosscut
 
 <i>phr.</i> to be angry, at odds, crossgrained (with a person).

## beach
 
 <i>n.</i> The seashore as a place for an outing.. -->1. [W3] In NZ not only the word for `the shore of the sea' (OED2 sb 3 citations connote a littoral and a literal meaning), but also the usual word for British seaside, the beach as a place of enjoyment or recreation (seaside has an unidiomatic, British association even in children's stories), cf beach cottage: in early days beach had commercial connotations: cf The Beach, beach trader. [Jim Cameron writes: The importance of the beach as a NZ icon suggests that there might be some distinctive NZE compounds. OED has <i>*beach bag, *beach ball, *beach buggy, *beach bum, beach flea, *beachfront, beach grass, beach plum, beach rock, *beachwear</i>. Macquarie 1981 has also <i>beach break</i> (a surfing term), <i>beach hut, beach inspector, *beach mat, *beach robe, beachworm</i> <i>*surf beach</i> - in NZPOD - and <i>*ocean beach</i>. As well I have seen <i>beach music, *beach picnic</i> and <i>beach volleyball</i> recently in overseas publications. [*Known to me as in NZ use or former use also]. <i>Beachfront</i> is tagged in OED as chiefly US, and all citations refer to places outside the UK. It has long been used in NZ. NZ citations?] (See [cf. beach cottage](../B#beach-cottage))

>  Note, In speaking of Mercury Bay I had forgot to mention that the Mangrove trees found there produce a resinous substance very much like rosin, something of this kind I am told is found in both the East and West Indias. We found it first in small lumps upon the Sea beach, but afterwards found it sticking to the Mangrove trees and by that means found out from whence it had come. <i>(Nov 16, 1769,Cook's Journals,I/204</i>) [NOTES: 1955 ed.]

>  <b>BELL</b> If the fishing is to be carried on by a shore party, the try pots and huts are erected on the beach ... The boats are sent out at daylight every morning, and when ... they kill a fish it is towed ashore and flinched and boiled upon the beach. <i>(Nov 1831,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days]

>  <b>BOULTBEE</b> The distance we had to go was about 20 miles, part of the way led through woods, and part along Sandy beaches. <i>(1835,Journal,72</i>) [NOTES: 1986 ed.]

>  landed 100 Cask and shooks on the beach - <i>(Feb 20, 1836,Piraki Log,28</i>)

>  My brother Peter was on the beach waiting for me. <i>(Feb 19, 1842,Letters from New Plymouth,7</i>) [NOTES: in 1843 Letters from New Plymouth (1968)]

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> Following this towards the coast ...; then descended to the shore, returning along the beach. <i>(Apr 19, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: in 1898 Hocken Contributions 208 [distinct from shore]]

>  Another day he would rush them all off ... down to the beach for a picnic and a swim. <i>(1934,Winds of Heaven,181</i>)

## beach claim
 
 <i>n.</i> [see wet claim, dredging claim, etc.]

 <i>n.</i> [goldmining] (See [contrast bank claim](../C#contrast-bank-claim))

>  Arrow Township, 10th July. - ... Huts, tents, wheels, sluice-boxes - everything on the beach and river claims have been swept off by the torrent, ... <i>(Jul 18, 1863,Otago Witness,7</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> The Dunstan gold workings were of two kinds - technically known as `beach claims' and `bank claims'. The latter were on the gravelly river banks which the miners sluiced away bodily for the golden grains ... The former were on the sandy margins of the river, and were often extended by means of `wing-dams' and other ingenious devices far into the rushing waters. In these claims the gold was found lodged in `pockets' or fissures formed by the slate bars ... <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk I iv 17</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> Collet's quicksilver plates rapidly became common on the beach-claims although they did not completely supplant the simpler cradle and sluice-box. <i>Ibid.</i> 244 It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,170,1962 ed.</i>)

## beachcomb
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>CRUMP</b> I remember when I was beachcombing up in the Bay of Islands ... What, just living off the beach, Son? ... Yeah. Bit of fishing and mussel-picking, sheep-stealing and garden-raiding when a man felt energetic or hungry. <i>(1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,61</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> [West Coast mining], For a considerable time [in 1860s] I was coasting and beach combing until Wakamarina rush took place. <i>(1914,Digger Stories,45</i>)



## beachcomber
 
 <i>n.</i> A prospector or miner who works black-sand beaches for gold, a new goldfields formation from beach n2. (cf beach claim), and comb @v and comber @n, (cf beacher); and perhaps associated with the older beachcomber 1. above. (See [blacksanding](../B#blacksanding))

>  <b>BATEMAN</b> The small quantity of gold under the boulders, which lie on the sandy beach [on the West Coast, South Island] is generally supposed by gold prospectors, otherwise termed `beach-combers', to be due to the lifting action of the surf. <i>(1881,Colonists,36</i>)

>  The beaches ... have now been worked for many years, but the yields are not so good. ... still, the `beach-combers' make fair wages. <i>(1887,Handbook NZ Mines,217</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [(Though by 1846 (Auckland), and 1849 (Canterbury) the word seemed derog. used throughout the colony, the first recorded use above has perhaps some reference to or colour from Wellington's main waterfront street of the 1840s, `The Beach'.)]

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> Idle, drunken vagabond ... he wanders about without any fixed object, cannot get employed by the whaler or anyone else, as it is out of his power to do a day's work; and he is universally known as the `beach-comber'. <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,1/338</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> Even the corrupt beachcombers and whalers of Kapiti would go out of their way to say a good word ... for Mr. Hadfield. <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,2/4</i>)

>  <b>POWER</b> ... a few half-drunken loafers (beach-combers, as they are called here [in Auckland]) hanging about the numerous pot-houses. <i>(Jul 29, 1846,Sketches in NZ,4,1849 ed.</i>)

>  Funds are running out and the evil consequences of employing beach-combers, escaped convicts and sailors [in pre-settlement Canterbury] are becoming every day more apparent. <i>(Dec 9, 1849,Torlesse Papers,117,1958 ed.</i>)

>  ... Lyttelton .... by all accounts is the receptacle of loose beachcombers and escaped lags and convicts, who have been employed in preference to honest and able men from the settlements. <i>(Feb 17, 1850,Torlesse Papers,131,1958 ed.</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> It was impossible that a community [Kororareka in 1838] composed of sailors ..., convicts, traders, beach-combers, sawyers, and New Zealanders could live together ... <i>Ibid.</i> 297The Pakeha Maori must not be confounded with the idlers and beachcombers who loitered about Kororareka. <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,285</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> It is a series of three islands with a climate varying from temperate to subtropical, a land of industry with no place for the beachcomber; ... <i>(1934,Children of the Poor,10,1949 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BUICK</b> During the remainder of the day [February 1840] a strong effort was made by the beachcombers and whisky sellers of Kororareka to spread dissension among the chiefs ... <i>(1936,Treaty of Waitangi,149</i>)

>  <b>SOLJAK</b> New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... <i>beachcomber</i>: first applied to deserting seamen and escaped convicts from Australia. Recorded before 1840 <i>(1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Several sealers lived permanently on the Chathams because there was no law there as the group only nominally belonged to England and was not yet a part of New Zealand. It was the home of escaped convicts, ne'er-do-wells and beachcombers from Australia chiefly, but those with the worst reputation came from Callao in Peru. <i>(1952,Chatham Islands,101</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> `The Beach', as Kororareka was called, was not that fabled `Beach' which the explorers had sought: the dissolute men known as `the beachcombers' found no gold nuggets; they made a living by preying on seamen in one way or another. <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,45</i>)

>  <i>beachcomber n.</i> man, often an outcast, making a precarious living on beach or remote place [N.Z. origin, first recorded in 1844. An earlier form was <i>beachranger</i>]. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),3</i>)

## beachcombing
 
 <i>n.</i> used to connote the irresponsibility associated with beach-combers n1..

>  While putting up a printing office [in Port Nicholson] I picked up two wanderers, who I engaged to saw ... I adopted them because they were shaved and clean. ... They appeared to me to contrast to great advantage [?with] the regular `beach comber'. I write the phrase large because I think it is [???new] to you. It is appropriate to the class. Its meaning I assume is evident. The `beach combing' class is large. The fellows are daring, dirty, requiring much excitement, accustomed to work on shore and on board, generally about the beach, and take what they find without any very strong sense of doing that which is improper. <i>(May 1840,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1840 May 15 S. Revans to H. Chapman [TS] Letters 42]

>  Except among the old whalers and the `beachcombing population' marriages with native women seldom take place. <i>(1853,New Zealand and Its Six Colonies</i>)

>  ... such political beachcombing vituperation as has been indulged in [by the <i>Petone Chronicle</i>]. <i>(Dec 21, 1912,Hutt Valley Independent,3</i>) [NOTES: [The reference here may be partly and snidely to the fact that Petone is a beachfront town.]]



 
 <i>n.</i> [Orsman database: (?ppl a) [nf OED, W3, P] A transferred use, derog. used to connote the irresponsibility associated with beach-combers n1..]

>  <b>CRUMP</b> I remember when I was beachcombing up in the Bay of Islands ... What, just living off the beach, Son? ... Yeah. Bit of fishing and mussel-picking, sheep-stealing and garden-raiding when a man felt energetic or hungry. <i>(1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,61</i>)

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> Generally the greater portion of the sand is removed, but in favourable spots, sheltered either by a slight indentation in the coast-line, or by some large pieces of drifted timber, its heavier particles remain; these consist [529] of black iron-sand (both magnetic and titaniferous oxide of iron) associated with small garnets and with gold. These black layers are often one or two inches thick, and repose upon coarse quartzose sands. As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfers' as they are called, examine the coastline near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient. <i>(1948,Julius Von Haast,528</i>) [NOTES: Quote from 1868]

## beacher
 
 <i>n.</i> A prospector or miner who works the blacksand beaches for gold; beach-comber 3. cf surfacer, surfacing. [West Coast goldmining]

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfacers,' as they are called, examine the coast-line near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient. <i>Ibid.</i> 364-365 In the descriptive part of this publication I have already alluded to the black-sand beachers, who watch the coast principally ... where small indentations favour the preservation of magnetic ... iron-sands <i>(1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,159</i>)

>  <b>ELDER</b> On this ... beach he found ... a number of miners who worked ... amid the black-iron [check] sands to be found on the beaches. In the early days of the gold-rush many of these `beachers' or `surfacers' had prospected the whole southern part [of the West Coast]. <i>(1930,Goldseekers and Bushrangers in NZ,155</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> BEACHER: a miner working a sea-beach claim. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,526</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> As soon as a stream has subsided, the "beachers" or "surfacers," as they are called, examine the coast-line near their houses. <i>(1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,159</i>)

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> Generally the greater portion of the sand is removed, but in favourable spots, sheltered either by a slight indentation in the coast-line, or by some large pieces of drifted timber, its heavier particles remain; these consist [529] of black iron-sand (both magnetic and titaniferous oxide of iron) associated with small garnets and with gold. These black layers are often one or two inches thick, and repose upon coarse quartzose sands. As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfers' as they are called, examine the coastline near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient. <i>(1868,Julius Von Haast,528</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> ?An old shore-whaler (?or f. naut. on the beach; cf beached. [Otago whalers']

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> At each place which I have visited, I have been assured that the Maories are dying rapidly - `perishing like rotten sheep,' these people often say; thus at Kurreroo or Molineux, where there are now half-a-dozen natives, they say that formerly, and at no remote period, about two generations previous to the present, there were above a thousand; and in many other places within the last sixteen years, which is about the extent of the experience of the older beachers, there has been, in many places, a corresponding diminution of numbers. If this is an unexaggerated statement, it is a very distressing one to reflect on. Since Dr. -- visited this settlement, one of the residents, Mr. --, an educated man, has opened a school for half-bred or any other children, and the progress which the children have already made is very encouraging. <i>(May 22, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1844 May 22 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223]

## beamer
 
 <i>n.</i> [Cf OED2 beaming 2. (Tanning) 1885 `"Beaming", or unhairing, derives its name from an inclined convex wooden form called a "beam", on which the hide is spread during the operation.': also beam v. 4.; cf EDD beam sb1 5. a fleshing-beam.]

>  <b>HOWARD</b> Incoming skins are sorted to arbitrary standards - wigs (old males), clap-matches (females), bulls, yearlings, grey or silver pups (under one year), black pups. If the cargo is intended for the European or American market, the skins are removed from the animal with an inch of blubber adhering, and in the final simple treatment are washed, heavily slated, and then folded or `booked' into rectangular shape for packing. Skins destined for China, however, are treated with more preliminary care. They are taken as cleanly as possible, and after careful washing are sent to the `beamer' to be thoroughly scraped free of the last remaining particles of flesh and blubber. <i>(1940,Rakiura,40</i>)

## beech
 
 <i>n.</i> an important group of Southern Hemisphere timber trees forming extensive forests especially in southern and mountainous regions of New Zealand. Also called nothofagus and popularly but incorrectly, birch; often found with prefixed epithets denoting appearance of tree (black, silver), quality of timber (hard, red), habitat (mountain); the preferred name for spp. of <i>Nothofagus</i> (to 187?, <i>Fagus</i>), the southern beech, and for spp. of other genera resembling the southern beech (see false beech 2 below); contrast the popular name birch q.v. now obs., and for the NI esp., the Maori generic taw(h)ai; and (erroneously) kamahi in the SI. [See esp. the discussion by J.C. Andersen <i>Popular Names of New Zealand Plants</i> (TrNZI vol. 56, 57), and T. Kirk <i>On New Zealand Beeches</i> (TrNZI 17/298ff.).]

>  <b>KIRK</b> With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For <i>Fagus fusca</i>, tooth-leaved beech; for <i>Fagus solandri,</i> entire-leaved beech; and for <i>Fagus menziesii,</i> round-leaved beech. <i>(1875,Durability NZ Timbers,17</i>)

>  <i>Beech</i> (b&emacr.ch), <i>n. [Add.] ... The ordinary</i> native beech <i>of commerce in New South Wales is Gmelina Leichhardtii.</i> The New Zealand beeches are <i>Fagus Solandri, F. Blairii, F. Menziesii, F. fusca, F. Cliffortioides, </i>and <i>F. apiculata.</i> The word <i>beech</i>, however, is rarely used in New Zealand, the trees being called <i>birch</i> by settlers and bushmen, and <i>tawai</i> by the Maoris. See under BIRCH,<i>n</i> <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2018</i>)

>  <i>Birch</i>. Various species of Nothofagus. There are various kinds (white, red, black etc.) of trees in New Zealand called birches. They are all really beeches and the newspapers and forestry people are trying to get them so called, but up country they are still always called birches. Birch (creeks, hill, etc.) is one of the commonest components of local names in the South Island. ([1898 Morris Austral-English], and an unpublished letter to Hunter Brown from Dr Hodkinson, August 9, 1854.) <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> English names of animals and plants are sometimes mistakenly applied. The native beech, <i>Nothofagus</i>, has been called <i>birch</i> since the early days and is still often so called by bushmen; ... <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680</i>) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> Beech .. tawai, tawhai <i>Nothofagus </i> <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712</i>)

>  <b>DAWSON</b> Five species of <i>Nothofagus</i> were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. <i>Nothofagus menziesii</i>: silver beech (the bark is white and silvery particularly in young trees). <i>Nothofagus fusca:</i> red beech (the timber is reddish in colour). <i>Nothofagus truncata:</i> hard beech (the wood has a high silica content making it hard). <i>Nothofagus solandri</i> var. <i>solandri</i>: black beech (the bark is very dark partly due to the growth of a sooty mould). <i>Nothofagus solandri </i>var. <i>cliffortioides</i>: mountain beech (grows mainly at higher altitudes than other beeches). <i>(1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,121</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> A noble forest of beech trees (tawai). <i>(1845,Journal,3/166</i>)

>  <b>McLEAN</b> High beech or Tawai trees. <i>(1845,Journal,I</i>) [NOTES: (Taupo)]

## bellahonie
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> In a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as <i>The Bellahonie </i>(E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as <i>Kick the Tin</i> (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky. In this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.] <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,80</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. <i>West Coast</i>: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; <i>Wellington</i>: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. ## bells
 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to remove belly wool of sheep before shearing or before the winter.

 <i>n.</i> (See [also stockwhip](../A#also-stockwhip))

 <i>n.</i> the wool on or from a sheep's belly; short form of belly wool, shorn belly-wool.

BELLIES ... <i>(1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,74</i>)

The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. ## berdan
 
 <i>n.</i>



 
 <i>n.</i> a device for separating gold dust from crushed rock

>  The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings. <i>(1876,TrNZI,8/179</i>) [NOTES: (Goodall Thames Gold-fields)]

>  <b>BULLER</b> Gold was crushed at first in a `berdan', until they were able to provide [153] an engine of many horse-power. <i>(1878,Forty Years in NZ,152</i>)

>  There are but two or three small Berdan machines on the spot [for crushing stone]. <i>(Oct 27, 1867,Trip to the Thames Gold-fields,28,1978 ed.</i>)

>  Kurunui Battery ... of six stampers, and one stamper specimen battery with Berdans at the end of tables to grind the tailings. <i>(1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,93</i>)

>  <b>No.4 (NS) 112</b> The mill on the Hauraki claim consists of a fifteen-stamper battery, Wilfley, vanner, berdans, and accessories. <i>(1907,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin</i>) [NOTES: [Coromandel]]

>  The crushing machinery in all these batteries consisted of four to ten heads of light stamps, and the gold-saving plant of amalgamated copper plates, with or without the addition of a small berdan. <i>(1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.6 (NS) 26</i>) [NOTES: [Mikonui]]

>  <b>No.42 (NS) 39</b> In 1880 the Welcome built a 10-head mill with berdans ... <i>(1948,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin</i>) [NOTES: [Reefton] [1880] 1948 NZ Geol SB]

>  <b>BALE</b> In front of him was a massive, rust-covered iron dish, with a big iron block inside it. ... `That's a berdan,' replied Mr Alexander. ... `You place crushed ore inside the revolving bowl. ... The iron block stays still, grinding the ore into a slime. Water flows into the dish and spills over the edge carrying the lighter gold-free particles and slurry with it. Then mercury is added to absorb or amalgamate the gold and silver. It's usually used for testing the ore. <i>(1971,Maratoto Gold,54</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> <i>Berdan pan</i>: An annular-shaped cast-iron bowl or basin about four feet in diameter containing heavy weights which were revolved slowly to grind the ore, particularly concentrates, finely. Sometimes mercury was added to the berdans to form an amalgam with the finely-ground gold. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),312</i>)

>  If all that is claimed for this invention is borne out by actual working, the old berdan will at length have more than a rival. <i>(Nov 20, 1890,Otago Witness,13</i>)

>  Almost weekly something turns up which fully tends to prove that the Provincial Government.. should take immediate steps to appoint someone to ascertain for whom the berdan proprietors crunch so many small parcels of quartz. <i>(Apr 19, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,4</i>)

>  <b>JACKSON</b> The soldiers of this war call this unsavoury portion of Cairo [viz The Wasser] the `Berker'. <i>Ibid.</i> 97 Doubtless any old soldier who fought in Egypt in the last war will remember the `Wasser', with the streets the same, the houses ...; but the soldiers of this war call this unsavoury portion of Cairo the `Berker'. <i>(1943,Passage to Tobruk,77</i>)

>  <b>TUCKER</b> I may say that during my stay in Cairo I did all the things that young soldiers do, visiting such places at [sic : ?as] the Burka, which is the red-light district of Cairo ... <i>(1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,23</i>)

>  Over the next few decades, Prices produced hundreds of stamper batteries for crushing rock,...berdans (devices for separating gold dust from crushed rock), steam engines [79] and boilers for the goldfields at Thames and later those at Te Aroha and Waihi. <i>(Apr 1997,NZ Geographic,No. 34/78</i>)

## biddy-bid
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Acaena</i> spp. esp. <i>Acaena anserinifolia, </i>(often formerly <i>A. sanguisorbae </i> occas. <i>A</i>. novae-zelandiae), <i>and other spp., </i> a (mainly) creeping plant and its burr, a prostrate herb having a many-seeded fruit with hooked spines which catch in clothing, the wool of sheep, etc. [from Maori piripiri]; hutiwai, piripiri q.v. cf also related forms biddy-burr, bizzie, and the Aust. alteration<i> bidgee-widgee,</i> AND 1910. [[a1927] Ver.= Vernacular names heard by J.C. Andersen from sawyers, settlers, etc. (And) [biddy-bid]]

>  After tea we went further up the creek, some of us gathering ferns and the rest throwing bid-a-bids at each other. Those throwing "biddies" must have been enjoying themselves. <i>(Feb 22, 1905,Otago Witness,74</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> (And) [bid-a-bid] [not found] <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The</i>)

>  <b>MUELLER</b> <i>(1866,My Dear Bannie,110,1958 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [see cit. at 4. below]]

>  <b>LINDSAY</b> Hence the plant [<i>Acaena sanguisorbae</i>] is only too familiar, as the `Native Burr' to the sheep farmers alike of New Zealand, Australia, and Tasmania. ... To the Otago settler the plant is also known as the `Bidi-bidi,' or `Beta-beta;' to the North Island Maori as `Hutiwai,' `Piri-piri,' (Colenso), or `Piri-kahu,' (Colenso). <i>(1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,59</i>)

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> PIRI PIRI (<i>Aceara ... sanguisorbae</i>). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. In the North Island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. ## bidi-bidi
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [alteration of piripiri] a burred weed of the Acaena spp. that flaws fleecewool and that was used by colonists to augment tea leaves. (See [also biddy-bid](../A#also-biddy-bid))

## big ring
 
 <i>n.</i> a children's game

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. ## billy
 
 <i>n.</i> a vessel (orig. tin can) with a lid and a swinging wire handle used first for boiling water or food over open fires and later as a receptacle for milk and other liquids, billyful, noun; a tin can (or enamelled or, later, aluminium) vessel with a swinging wire handle, and often a lid, used orig. for boiling water or cooking in the open, and later for holding milk and other liquids; a billy can cf tin billy [AND TIN- from tinplate 1881] phs to tin-; cf billy-boiling, boil the billy, milk-billy see also swing the billy, swing 3. [tin pot (occas. tin can or bully pot) and bouilli tin are the the early congeners of billy attested in NZ in lexis and praxis]

>  <i>Bil&#769;.ly</i> (b&ibreve.l&#769;.l&ybreve.), <i>n. [Add.] 3.</i> A bushman's kettle; a cylindrical tin vessel with detached lid and arched wire handle; - sometimes called <i>billy-can</i>. <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2018</i>)
