## Billy Boy
 
 <i>n.</i> a clumsy ship ?? [recorded earliest in NZ]

>  <b>ROCHFORT</b> On awaking in the morning we were disappointed to find a light head wind blowing, and a number of ships of all sorts and sizes, from the noble `East Indiaman' to the clumsy `Billy boy,' wind-bound like ourselves; ... <i>(1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,6</i>)



## billy boy
 
 <i>n.</i> a boy, or cadet, who carries, the billy, makes tea, and does the rouseabout work for field parties, shearing gangs, etc.

>  Starting as a billy-boy, he worked at just about every job in the next 3 and a half years - on the skids, loading timber; breaking down logs in the sawmill; driving logging trucks, a TD18 dozer and chainsaw felling of native trees. <i>(Aug 27, 1982,Dominion,8</i>)

>  The only point I want to make is that my experience of mountains is lengthy although it may not be deep - billy boy to the botanists of the `twenties', mountaineering and field collecting for geologists in the `thirties'. <i>(1960,Report of Ninth Science Congress,144</i>) [NOTES: 1960 Report of Ninth Science Congress May 12-17: Proceedings of Royal Soc. of NZ 144]

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> As the "billy boy," it was my job to get to camp before dark, light the fire and start the dinner. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,60</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) 1. a worker who mixes and distributes billies of burgoo or Ship's Lime to harvesting teams, working in hot, dry conditions [1850s to 1930s]. 2. a person who collects/delivers smoko materials or makes tea in shearing sheds. (See [billy time](../B#billy-time))

>  Here you find boys of scarce fourteen eager to take on a job as billy-boy, a by no means enviable task. <i>(May 1909,NZ Farmer,338</i>)

>  <b>COULSON</b> Cutting grass seed was dry work, and there was a regular break for a drink. It fell to the lot of the Billy Boy to provide this. 2. <i>(1979,Golden Harvest,37</i>)

>  <b>ALLEN</b> I was fleeco, billy-boy and rouseabout. <i>(1980,Farm on the Wanganui River, A,39</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> As the billy-boy, it was my job to get back to camp before dark, get the water, light the fire and start the dinner. [billy boy] <i>(1991,Off the Sheep's Back,60</i>)

## billy tea
 
 <i>n.</i> tea made in a billy [--[Cf description in 1945 Simpson If You'd Care to Know 99-100 The billy is filled with water and suspended over a fire ... When the water boils, the tea is popped in, the lid is clamped down to confine the flavour, and the billy is removed from the fire. A few minutes is allowed for the brew to `draw', and there is your tea in the Australian bush fashion. Maybe there is no sugar in it, and of a certainty there is no milk or lemon; you take this liquor straight and you take it hot, although the temperature of the day may be a hundred in the shade.] W. Ramson: common in Aust., also a trade name; nf W3.] Tea made in a billy over a fire, tea made by tossing a handful of tea-leaves into a billy of water on <i>the boil (used often with the epithet</i> black,<i> either defining</i> tea from the strength of the tea made judged by its colour); or <i>billy</i> from its open-fire blackened appearance: cf [1864 Apr 16 Otago Witness in 1976 Veitch Clyde on the Dunstan 29-30 Heavily swagged diggers and laden horses whose swags consist of all the household goods of a mining party, from the black billy which boils the tea, to the tom cat which kills the rats and mice.]] (See [also boil the billy](../A#also-boil-the-billy))

>  <b>HYDE</b> Starkie ... was off again - not entirely discouraged, for he had eggs, bacon, and billy tea in his stomach and [pounds]26 in his pocket. <i>Ibid.</i> 70 Rannock fed his prison labour on honest bush food: fresh meat, billy tea, enormous flat damper scones cooked on the three-legged camp oven. <i>(1936,Passport to Hell,50</i>)

>  <b>BACON</b> The workmen were having a spell ... The foreman nodded as we came near, squinting up at us from where he sat nursing a mug of black tea. `Goodday, mates. Like a mug of brew?' ... `Yeah, there's plenty in the billy.' <i>(1963,In the Sticks,84</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> But after a good strong brew of billy-tea I was able to carry on, ... <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,149</i>)

>  <b>HALEY</b> Red tea it used to be called ...[sic]somewhere. Billy tea. <i>(1986,Settlement, The,60</i>)

>  <b>SLIGO</b> The fire was going ... The black billy tea stewed. <i>(1987,Final Things,187</i>)

>  <b>PICKERING</b> Of billy tea. Waiting until the billy boils, throwing in half a handful of tea, trying to hook the billy off the fire before it boils over, and tapping the side with a spoon to settle the leaves. Then demonstrating a touch of skill by pouring the tea over the billy handle and into your chipped enamel cup and swallowing the brew in hot blowy gulps. <i>(1988,Hills, The,8</i>)

>  Nowadays, musters are completed in days using helicopters and 4WDs. Hob-nailed boots, billy tea and camp ovens have been replaced by GPS locators, energy drinks and Vibram rubber soles. <i>(Feb 20, 2010,Your Weekend,8</i>)

## bin
 
 <i>n.</i> a wool-bin [main def. there].

>  The T wing of the shed, where the wool press and bins are located.. has a large cellar underneath, into which the daggs and such of the wool as requires handpicking is passed through the hatchway in the floor above. <i>(Sep 16, 1890,Otago Witness,7</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Meanwhile the `pickers up' were busy gathering up the fleeces as they fell from the bereft sheep and carrying them to the sorting table, where they [173] were stripped of the `pieces', which were thrown aside, while the best of the fleece was quickly classified, rolled together, and deposited in a kind of bin, according to its quality, whether `clothing' or `combing.' <i>(1881,Waitaruna,172</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> At the main entrance of the shearing-shed, which is a long building with pens down the centre, and an outlet at each end, stands a wool-press, and behind this are the bins into which the fleeces, after having been classed, are placed preparatory to being pressed. <i>Ibid.</i> 244 Meanwhile the shorn fleeces are carried to a large table in the wool-shed by a man appropriately named `Fleecy', and are spread out by four wool-pickers, who tear away the bad parts and fold the fleeces square, passing them to the classer, who, in turn, after a rapid examination hands them on to his attendant, and he places them in their respective bins according to their quality. <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,242</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> No more mighty fleeces crown the bins like drifted snow,/ <i>(1897,Station Ballads,46,1945 ed.</i>) [NOTES: `Arlington']

>  <b>CARR</b> Dag Cutting. - The wool rollers take off the dirty portion of the fleece and throw it into a bin, the dag cutter ... with a pair of shears cuts off all the wool he can, which he throws into another bin. It is then called `second pieces'. <i>(1913,Country Work,15</i>)

>  <b>PERRY</b> On no account must a man go to the bin of fleeces and, taking up as many as he can gather in his arms, rush to the press putting the whole into the bale in a confused mass. <i>(1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,124</i>)

>  <i>(1933,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: Acland, see wool bin]

>  <i>Bin</i>: Receptacle for holding loose wool prior to pressing in either a shearing shed or woolstore. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,52</i>)

Close by stood the classer's table, where he sat and classed each fleece before it was carried by a shed hand to its respective bin. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,113</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> [Fleeces] laid on the tables before the wool-sorters ... who pronounced ... to which bin they belonged. <i>(1865,Station Life in NZ,33,1874 ed.</i>)

## binning
 
 <i>n.</i> broker service for the disposal of small or mixed lots of wool in which each grower's wool is classed and weighed to bins with similar types from other growers, cf bin.

>  The wool removed by crutching is of low value and the amount per clip is usually small. For these reasons `crutchings' are seldom if ever classed except by the wool brokers when the wool is sent to them for binning. <i>Ibid.</i> 711 In `Binning,' the bales are broken up and classed into lines. This method of building up saleable lines is generally used in the case of small parcels of fleece wool and bales of oddments which cannot be included in the main lines without destroying their evenness. As each vendor's wool [712] is classed in the binning-room, the wool in each class is weighed and credited to the owner before being placed in its appropriate bin. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,710</i>)

## birch
 
 <i>n.</i> (any of a group of deciduous, Northern Hemisphere trees with slender branches and smooth bark, used for timber.) In NZ commonly, but incorrectly, applied to the native beech spp.; a common popular name c1795-1970s for the trees and timber of <i>Nothofagus</i> spp., preferred common name beech q.v. Also occas. used for species of other general thought to resemble Nothofagus. occas. (usu. overseas usage) New Zealand birch. As with beech, vernacular naming tries to distinguish var. and spp. by ref. to colour of bark, texture of wood or timber, appearance of leaf, etc., but with similar confusion and local variation. [cf the use of birch by Cook of Nothofagus in Tierra del Fuego (=? beech <i>Nothofagus antarctica</i> or <i>N. pumilio</i> or both [fn]) 1769 January 25 Cook's Journals (1955) 1/51 [Tierra del Fuego] <i>`The wood is of the Birch kind... wild celery' [fn3</i>Apium <i>graveolens</i>].]

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> On the Hollyford job the road went through beech-forest, but this was locally called birch. Woe betide us if we referred to birch trees in our correspondence with Head Office: we were reminded that it was <i>beech</i> and given all sorts of advice telling us that the botanical name was something like <i>Fagus fagusti</i>, and so on. Some people are allergic to beech trees and the local name for this allergic condition was birch itch. On one occasion a compensatory claim was sent to Wellington advising that the condition suffered was birch itch. Back came a reprimand about this use of the term birch - it should be <i>beech</i>, Head Office pointed out. Nothing was done about this until one day it came to the notice of our chief. He was quick to reply and acknowledge that the trees were beech, not birch, but the itch suffered by the men was birch itch not beech itch. It was locally named by them, and as far as his staff were concerned they used the term birch itch to describe the allergy caused by beech trees. There was no further comment from the Moguls in Head Office. <i>(1975,Men of the Milford Road,93</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  1. A tree with a silvery bark. The name of `birch' was applied in error by early New Zealand settlers to different kinds of beech and is still often so used by bushmen. ... <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),40</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

>  <i>Fagus Solandri.</i> - The most common name of this tree is `black-birch,' but it has several other names. In the Wellington and Marlborough districts it is called `black-birch'; in Canterbury it is called `black-birch,' `white-birch,' `red-birch,' and `brown-birch'; in Otago it is known as `white-birch,' `black-birch,' or black-heart birch.' Young specimens of this tree that have no dark heart-wood are often called `white-birch.' This tree is a beech, and it would do away with confusion if it was called `black-beech'. <i>Fagus Menziesii. </i>- The commonest name of this tree is `silver-birch,' but it is often called `brown-birch,' `red-birch,' and `white-birch' [308] in different localities. It would be best to call it `silver-beech,'though it is gaining an Australasian reputation as `Southland beech.' <i>Fagus fusca. </i>- In Auckland this tree is called `black-birch'; in Wellington `red-birch'; in Nelson, Marlborough and Westland it is called `brown-birch'; and in Otago it is called both `red-birch' and `bull-birch.' The most suitable name is `red-beech.' <i>(1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/307</i>)

>  The utmost confusion prevails among the common names of the birches. There are scarcely two districts, a few miles apart, in which the same name is applied to the same tree, and a similar result may be obtained by consulting two bushmen in the same bush. With a view to obviating this difficulty Mr Kirk suggests `the adoption of new names based of the obvious characteristics of foliage [e.g.] for Fagus fusca `tooth-leaved beech' ... <i>(1876,TrNZI,64</i>) [NOTES: (Blair)]

>  [this cit. not spec. repeated in individual entries] [In Oxford Forest] I learned that the tree [F. solandri, entire-leaved beech ] was termed [red, brown, white, black, and yellow] birch at different stages of its growth, but the application of these terms differed greatly; perhaps Black Birch was most generally applied to the mature condition before decay commenced, and White birch to the young state; but there were too many exceptions to allow the names to be anything but misleading. <i>(1885,TrNZI,17/300</i>) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches)]

>  The perversity with which the true `beeches' have become popularly known as `birches,' and different kinds of `mapau' as `maples - a popular name which includes small trees of widely distinct Natural Order, is enough to fill with despair any botanist who desires to foster a system of popular names that will be free from misleading and inaccurate suggestions. <i>(1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/50</i>)

>  '... the term birch may be regarded as a generic name applied by bushmen to any small-leaved tree, and qualified by the prefixes `black', `white' or `red' at the caprice of the individual or as may be suggested by the colour of its foliage, bark or timber.' So the term `black birch' was in many districts applied to Pittosporum tenuifolium [ ] and to Weinmannia racemosa [Kamahi] in Otago - the latter tree being also known as `brown birch' or `red birch.' Myrsine Urvillei [ ] was known as `red birch', and Carpodetus serratus [ ] and Quintinia serrata [ ] as `white birch.' It was principally to the trees of the species Nothofagus (then known a Fagus), that the term `birch' was applied, and a distinguishing of the various kinds by the prefixing of a descriptive word was a step in the right direction; but in this instance the step was on a path that led to a quagmire. To take only the instance of N. Solandri (formerly Fagus Solandri). [v. 1885 Kirk] ... The confusion created has been endless ; it has at times even resulted in commercial loss ; [v. (Morris) 1889 Kirk `Forest Flora of NZ p.91] yet so strong is habit that confusion was preferred before a change of name. And, indeed, the bushmen might well ask what name they should adopt ; for the scientists came and added to the confusion by pointing out that the trees usually called `birch' were not birch at all, but `beech' - when a fresh crop of names resulted.: `black beech', `red beech', `dusky beech', etc. The scientists themselves, however, in calling the species Nothofagus, `beech', took care - that is, usually took care - to make the distinguishing prefix one that would not lead to a repetition of the old confusion. N. Solanderi was accordingly called `entire-leaved beech' ; N. Cliffortioides, `mountain beech' ; N. Menziesii, `round-leaved beech' ; N. fusca `tooth-leaved beech'. It was some time before even these names were agreed upon ; and `silver beech' finally took the place of `round-leaved beech' for N. Menziesii. A note may here be made of the fact that, whilst the entire-leaved beech was Fagus Solandri, on Fagus being changed to Nothofagus, Solandri was altered to Solanderi ; but this has been altered back again to Solandri ; for that was the original and not incorrect spelling of the word. <i>(1926,TrNZI,56-57/663</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Popular Names ff Kirk in 1875 [Reports on the Durability of N.Z. Timber 16]]

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> ... it is perhaps futile to hope that the more exact name [beech] will become popular ; but we might at least expect some consistent nomenclature to be adopted through the islands. At present the various species are designated almost indifferently, white, red, black, silver birch etc. What is white birch in one part of the country may be black in another ... The use of the name <i>birch</i> in place of <i>beech</i> is inexcusable, though ... N. Menziesii ... [shows] some external resemblance to the English birch. <i>(1940,NZ Plants,136</i>)

>  Colour Coding [heading] ... St Patrick's Day sports organiser, Mr Lyn Thompson yesterday inquired about the difference between red, black and brown birch. It was `clearly' explained for him by a prominent axeman, Mr Bill Evans. The bark of the red birch is silver, but the timber is pink when it's green. Brown birch often has black bark, but the green timber is red. Sometimes the bark of the black birch is white, but the timber is yellow and sometimes it's brown when it's green. <i>(Mar 11, 1972,Otago Daily Times,1</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

## birch itch
 
 <i>n.</i> an allergy affliction (see cit.): phs the same as birch fever, birch sickness, [cf. tauhinu rash ca1914-1918 Marlborough bushmen p.c. W.H.B. Orsman `You catch it off birch trees'] (See [cf. tauhinu rash](../T#tauhinu-rash))

>  <b>THOMSON</b> Cliff developed a kind of skin rash, sometimes called `birch itch'. This rash usually occurs with people who are allergic to bush localities, especially when the pollen is released from the trees in the spring. <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,119</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> On the Hollyford job the road went through beech-forest, but this was locally called birch. Woe betide us if we referred to birch trees in our correspondence with Head Office: we were reminded that it was <i>beech</i> and given all sorts of advice telling us that the botanical name was something like <i>Fagus fagusti,</i> and so on. Some people are allergic to beech trees and the local name for this allergic condition was birch itch. On one occasion a compensatory claim was sent to Wellington advising that the condition suffered was birch itch. Back came a reprimand about this use of the term birch - it should be <i>beech</i>, Head Office pointed out. Nothing was done about this until one day it came to the notice of our chief. He was quick to reply and acknowledge that the trees were beech, not birch, but the itch suffered by the men was birch itch not beech itch. It was locally named by them, and as far as his staff were concerned they used the term birch itch to describe the allergy caused by beech trees. <i>(1975,Men of the Milford Road,93</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a form of dermatitis experienced by bush settlers and hunters.

## Bishopscourt
 
 <i>n.</i> In NZ, the name of the residences of Anglican bishops, prob. since Selwyn's day (?mid or late 19cent)

>  Fine. Dined at Bishopscorte at one. <i>(Aug 22, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,99,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BOREHAM</b> The house of a Mr Clarke had been secured as a `Bishopscourt' for the present; ... <i>(1911,Selwyn,57</i>)

>  Bishop Selwyn lived at Waimate, where his house, the first Bishopscourt, still stands as the second oldest wooden building in New Zealand. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,7</i>)

>  <b>ARNOLD</b> To a pious and dutiful daughter of Bishopscourt, Tom Arnold ... must have indeed seemed a dangerous suitor. [reference to Archbishop's Palace, Dublin- Whately: JB (6/7/89 recollects using it in an Australasian sense: doesn't recall seeing it in Britain] <i>(1966,Letters,xxx [Intro]</i>) [NOTES: 1966 ed Bertram Arnold Letters]

>  <b>HARPER</b> Plans for the future were discussed at Bishop's Court [at Christchurch] when Ellen went there early in the next year, 1862. <i>(1967,Kettle on the Fuchsia, The,40</i>)



## bit
 
 <i>n.</i> in phr. a bit of (a) [1984 14 F E143Wgton Girls C. 7 BIT OF A BUMMER -->1984 17 M E107Pakuranga Coll. 34 BIT OF A LAUGH ca1935 Havelock e.g. She's only a bituva kid. It was bituva hot in there.]

>  <b>HUNT</b> I just lived up there in a bit of a bach with another chap ... <i>(1981,Speaking a Silence,82</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> He was a bit of a one for going on the booze. <i>(1946,That Summer,31</i>) [NOTES: (`Pair of Socks')]

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> as common in NZ in a variety of senses and uses as it is in gen. Eng. - esp. bit of a, pronounced [ ] and often spelt <i>bituva</i>, used adjectively for `small, little', and also ironically in understatement as `large' (e.g. 1944 `I must 'er made a bituva mistake, and opened up yer nose'): also used (esp. by children) adverbially as `rather': e.g. `It's bituva hot in here'. These and other uses are attested in OED(S) and EDD; cf hang of a; collocations (A) BIT OF (A) [to go to file 3BI5 BIT 1.]. The expression is in constant use. It has different meanings, but each is clear from the circumstances of the conversation. For example: <i>A bit of luck, A bit of a break</i> The event is praised, its quality is genuine. <i>A bit of a lark, A bit of fun</i> There is no intense quality in the event. <i>A bit of an ass, aren't you?</i> The quality of the topic is weakened so that the remark will not sting as much. <i>A bit of a hold-up (i.e. check to progress)</i> The delay is brief. <i>A bit of risk attached to it</i> The proportion of risk is not great, possibly slight. <i>A bit of a muddler, A bit of a no-hoper, A bit of a poor show </i> The quality referred to is present in full force. <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],60</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> Exaggeration is not an Australian characteristic and appears mainly in slang ...; understatement shows in style and unemphatic intonation rather than in vocabulary, except for the ubiquitous <i>a bit. </i> <i>Ibid.</i> 126 [qoting a Queensland survey] The word <i>bit</i> is common because it occurs in<i> a bit</i> (169) ...,<i> a bit of</i> (142) ... The word <i>bit</i> (1,241) is thus very frequent; compare <i>two (1,253).. </i> <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,48</i>)

>  <b>STEWARD</b> Not wishing a time-honoured custom to efface,/ I prefix my book with `a bit of a Preface'. <i>(1867,Carmina Varia,9</i>)

>  I must 'er made a bituva mistake, and opened up yer nose. <i>(1944,Hospitiki,3/11</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> The luckiest player that ever pulled on a jersey, said old Bert. He's been a bit of a tin-bum, said Erik. ... Not like me. I'm always shit out of luck. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,158</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> short for gen. Eng. a bit on the side.

>  <b>MASON</b> JUNE: ... Then we had to get dug in again to that bloody pigsty in town - ... and he got all snaky again. Then, when I had to take it quiet an' he couldn't get his bit, he just cleared out, six weeks ago. <i>(1974,Hand on the Rail, The,38,1981 ed.</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> a girlfriend (or boyfriend), esp. my bit [1984 16-17 F E24 Pakuranga Coll. 28 MY BIT [F2M5] -->1984 16-17 M E108Pakuranga Coll. 28 (A) BIT [M6]]

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Bit of skirt</i>. A girl; a woman: coll: from ca1900; esp. military, Australian, New Zealand. [P8 merely Mil.] <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,56</i>)

## bit on, a
 
 <i>phr.</i> (that's) a bit on, from the longer expressions on the cuff (q.v.) <i>nose</i>, the <i>snorer,</i> that's tough; that's a bit much; see also cuff. [ca1945 e.g's `I want four pounds for it.' `Gee, that's a bit on' `He got three years hard for bookying.' `That was a bit on, wasn't it?'; also meaning 'rather drunk' in citation below]

He must have been `a bit on' to leave the other in the river. ... he was asked `Where's the Needle?' He replied `In Hell!' <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,178</i>)



## bitch
 
 <i>v.</i> to play the female part

>  With two guys you can bomb the other into drag by turning into `bitch' i.e. reversing the roles. see <i>Bomb Someone Out</i> <i>(Sep 1973,Salient,11</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HYDE</b> It interested him, after nightfall, to see two boys with flaring painted cheeks ... He had seen plenty of them in Sydney, but not before in Auckland. `Place is lousy with them,' explained a labourer, ... `We call 'em bitches,' <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,235</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <i>Bitch</i>.-(1) Spoil or botch; (2) pour out tea. I thought these were colonial expressions, if ever there were any; but an erudite friend points out that (1) is used by Surtees in chapter XLII of `Handley Cross,' perhaps the most English book ever written, and that (2) is an old Cambridge University expression quoted in Gradus ad Cantabrigiam - a dictionary of Cambridge expressions, published in 1824. Let us hope that Samuel Butler introduced it to Canterbury. <i>(Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13</i>) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

>  ~ Slang. To spoil or make a mess of, e.g., `You've bitched the whole thing.' (C.) <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (ca1890-1910) 1933 Acland Glossary Press 16 Sept 15]



 
 <i>n.</i> to pour out tea, a coarse expression which I haven't heard for years; e.g., `Pass up your pannikins, I'll be bitch.' (C.)

## bite
 
 <i>n.</i> an angry response

>  ... took a lot of cows out of the paddoc into the horse bite, ... <i>(Sep 4, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,56,1950 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> accost and beg successfully from: `the old man bit me for a dollar outside the town hall'; put the bite on, (informal) to ask a favour; to cadge, borrow; to accost and borrow (esp. money)

>  If you ask a pal for many/ When you cannot `strap a beer',/ Then you `chew his lug', how funny,/ And what's more you `bite his ear.'] <i>(Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,41/6/4</i>)

>  <i>bite ... 10. (tr.</i>; often foll. by <i>for) Austral. & N.Z. sl.</i> to ask (for); scrounge from. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,108</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

>  `Sing a song of sixpence.' That is the unmelodious chant of the beer-chewer when he's biting your lug for a sprat. <i>(Mar 10, 1906,NZ Truth,38/1/6</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a crotchetty (old) person; an irritable nag - and usu. a woman (esp. old bite). [ca1935 Havelock, frequently of women.]

>  Two [Sergeants] were universally known as `C.B. Kings', and were the worst `bites' in their respective battalions. <i>(Sep 5, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,28</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> ?To defraud, ?cheat, trick [still in ?obs. use in NZ].

>  The fellow could hardly conceal his chagrin at my having done him and his knavery [in trying to get Chudleigh's land away from him] saying that though he would not have bitten me he should have been able to do so had his lawyers been half smart with his deed and not let mine get in first. <i>(Jul 23, 1977,Chudleigh Diary,258,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HISLOP</b> The other chap who had been taking it all in had a good laugh at the expense of this shrewd head who I bit for a sixpenny bit [sc tricked the trickster out of sixpence]. <i>(1943,Pure Gold,28</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> copy another graffiti painter's style

>  Graffiti Speak... Bite: To copy another writer's style. <i>(Nov 30, 2000,Evening Post,19</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [used elsewhere but sign. in NZ pastoralism] cover or sole of pasture.

>  .. its presence is unfavourable to the ready development of the fresh leafy 'bite' ... <i>(Mar 20, 1931,NZ Journal of Agriculture,202</i>)

## bitzer

[ca1920 (at least) Havelock `old car made up of parts of others']

## bivouac
 
 <i>v.</i> (Sport) to camp in the open

>  <b>FORSAITH</b> The natives ... in fine weather bivouacking in the open air or under sail-made tents. <i>(1856,Handbook for Emigrants,19</i>)

>  <b>SWAINSON</b> ... the climate is too uncertain for bivouacing in the open air. To travel in the bush with any degree of comfort, a tent is indispensable; ... <i>(1853,Auckland,123</i>)

>  <b>SELWYN</b> FOREST BIVOUAC. ... Strengthened by the usual New Zealand food of roasted potatoes and `damper', we set off ... but soon found ourselves bewildered ... in the surveyor's lines which crossed one another in all directions in the wood. We then resorted to the usual expedient of torches made of `karehao' (supple Jack) or `katoa'; ... it was [agreed] ... that we should light a fire and bivouac for the night. <i>(Aug 30, 1848,New Zealand (various authors/titles),NZ Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 76</i>)

>  <b>BREES</b> A party of surveyors and men bivouacking in the bush. <i>(1849,Panorama of NZ,31</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a camping-out; an outdoor camp or camping place; a camping-hut; ? a base-camp (usu. now bivvy).

>  <b>PICKERING</b> [specialist use also BIV] [caption] <i>Bivouacs are shrunken versions of huts and affectionately called dog kennels. Winchcombe Biv, Tararuas. </i> <i>(1988,Hills, The,82</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> A first bivouac must always be united with something strange and even impressive to the feelings. <i>(1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,40</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> [ordinary text] <i>(1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,40</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  [A picture of a frame-tent with the legend] `Building the Hutt Valley Tramping Club's Bivouac in the Otaki Valley.' <i>(1936,Hills and Valleys,2/3</i>)

>  <b>GILKISON</b> We were back at the bivouac. <i>(1940,Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks,54</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  My bivvie door swings open with a slam,/ <i>(1917,New Zealand At the Front,33</i>)

>  Anzac was absolutely dark except for ... the candlelights left purposely burning in the `bivvies' <i>(1918,New Zealand At the Front,15</i>)

>  We arrived at our allotted spot, somewhere in Palestine, and erected our bivvies. <i>(Feb 13, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,9</i>)

>  ... it was not possible to make habitable `bivvies' in either the support or the front line ... <i>(1921,NZ Division,243</i>)

>  any small tent <i>(1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East</i>)

>  <b>SARGE</b> (abbrev) bivouac tent. <i>(1950,Excuse my Feet!</i>)



## bivvy
 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> bivouac [EOD has ANZAC ref 1947]

>  <i>bivvy n. NZ colloq</i>. bivouac. [abbr.] <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,71</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

 <i>v.</i> to bivouac; to camp in a bivvy or shelter

>  We bivvied ... below the summit rocks. <i>(May 31, 2003,Dominion Post,A3</i>)

 <i>adj.</i> As a distinguishing epithet in names of plants, see akeake, ash, beech, southern; bent, bindweed, birch, fern, bristle fern; fern, daisy fern; fern, hard fern; fern, shield fern; fern, tree-fern; grass, blackgrass; hinau, hydrolagus, maire, mapau (mapou), maple, matipo, medick, mustard, nightshade, oak, pine; pine, rue; potato, punga, rata, rue (pine), scrub, shrub, stinkroach, tomato, vine, weed.



 
 <i>n.</i> black flounder.

>  <b>SORENSON</b> <i>FLOUNDER</i> (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (ii) <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> (iii) <i>Rhombosolea tapirina</i> (iv) <i>Rhombosolea leporina</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder. <i>(1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,24</i>)

>  [species name] black flounder .. [scientific name] <i>Rhombosolea retiaria </i>.. [other name(s)] blacks,freshwater flounder, river flounder <i>(Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> black sheep

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> I remember shortly after arrival in New Zealand watching the well-known dealer, Andrew Grant, picking `fats.' When asked by me for his hesitancy and discrimination in regard to several apparently prime blacks, his answer was that they `killed' badly. So many statements, nevertheless, continue to be accepted because it is nobody's interest to disprove them, that this dealer's belief is given for what it was worth. On the other hand, what Sandy Grant did not know of sheep was not worth knowing <i>(1926,Tutira,362 fn 1</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> Black Power gang (member).

>  `We thought it was the blacks.' -->The day before the shooting the couple had seen a car belonging to the Black Power gang in the street below their flat. `That's why Paul decided to barricade the door that night. There'd been trouble once before with the blacks ... <i>(May 10, 1983,Dominion,1</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

 <i>n.</i> (See [cf. blue](../B#blue))

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an Aberdeen Angus cattle beast.

<b>2</b> <i>adj.</i> As an epithet in the names of fish, see: bass, bream, cod, .bd;angelfish, angler fish, bass, bream, cod, dory, eel flounder, javelinfish, marlin, oreo (dory), parore, perch, physeter, ray, rock-cod, rock-fish, shark, slickhead, snapper, snipe eel, stingray whale(r), whalefish, whaling. <b>3</b> <i>adj.</i> As an epithet in the names of birds, see: cormorant, creeper, diver, oystercatcher, petrel, robin, scaup, shag, stilt, teal, tern; see also blackcap.



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i>

Patteson in 1874 Yonge Life of John Coleridge Patteson 1/234 [Picton Maoris to J.C. Patteson]]



 
<b>4</b> <i>adj.</i> As an epithet in the names of insects, see: locust, stinkroach; see also blackbeetle, black-bug.



## Black
 
 <i>n.</i> a Maori or Islander.

>  <b>WHISKER</b> The Blacks or Mowreys acted very well. ... The Natives ware [sic] no clothes at all but some old shirt tied around there weastes. [sic] <i>(1845,Memorandum Book</i>) [NOTES: 1845 Whisker Memorandum Book in 1979 Barthorp To Face the Daring Maori 71]

>  <b>CARBERRY</b> [The Waikato] will eventually fall into the Hands of the Whites when the Blacks go to the wall. <i>(Nov 18, 1863,Journal</i>)

>  A further charge, which Murray admitted, was of robbing Ariki Akamoeau of a transistor radio valued at $25. ... Sergeant Mowatt-Wilson said Murray was in a car with other youths when they saw four schoolboys walking along the footpath. Murray is reported to have said: `I'm going to get a black tonight.' He then asked for the radio from one of the boys who, in fear of his safety, gave it to Murray. Returning to the car, Murray said: `Look what I've got - I didn't even have to beat him up for it.' <i>(Aug 31, 1971,Otago Daily Times,7</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]



 
 <i>n.</i> an Australian Aborigine

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> Mr. Marsden entered with much apparent interest, upon the idea of a New Zealand settlement in Port Jackson; that is to say, within the Colony. ... [We think] that it should not be within one hundred miles of Sydney; that the natives should not be subject to visits from the curious intruders, ... [May 5 54] The natives have had much conversation, relative to the projected settlement in New Holland; ... They wish to be distinct from the whites or blacks, to retain their own teachers ... <i>(Apr 9, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,51,1961 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (usu. pl.) an All Black

It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. ## Black Budget
 
 <i>n.</i> The name given first by opponents, and then generally, to Finance Minister Nordmeyer's deflationary budget of 1958 and thence to any such budget (also used of an earlier budget); Charles Ransom comments (Nov 1986): referred to occas. by journalists but does not seem to have entered the language as meaning `deflationary budget'.

>  June 26 [1958]. Minister of Finance Arnold Nordmeyer presented his first Budget, increasing taxes on beer, spirits, cigarettes and tobacco. Known ever after as the Black Budget, it was a response to a balance of payments crisis and introduced cheap housing loans and the Pay-As-You-Earn (Paye) tax system. <i>(Aug 2, 1999,Evening Post,5</i>)

>  The 1958 budget was labelled "black" by one-time communist and union leader F.P. Walsh. <i>(Feb 11, 1999,Dominion,6</i>)

>  The `BLACK BUDGET' 1958 [heading] In his Budget speech, 26 June 1958, the Labour Minister of Finance, Arnold Nordmeyer, increased taxes in order to reduce demand for imports, encourage local manufacturing and conserve foreign exchange ... <i>(1971,Speeches & Documents,434 185.</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> In 1930 J.G. Coates had called Ward's budget `the Black Budget' [PD 1931, 229, 88] - but that was long forgotten. This time the label stuck. Nordmeyer's budget [of June 1958] was remembered as `the black budget' for many years. It can be argued that it was good for `the country'. For the government it was a suicidal mistake. It was the biggest blunder in Nash's political career. Although he was not immediately and directly responsible, he was the leader and did not say `No'. <i>(1976,Nash,309</i>)

>  Mr Lake and the government are lucky that the country's condition permitted them to avoid a Black Budget. <i>(Oct 1963,Comment,175</i>)

>  <b>NEAVE</b> It would not be an exaggeration to say that [Mr Nordmeyer] was respected as much outside the Labour Party, as he was within it, ... and although his `Black Budget' was known as the cause of the fall of the Labour Government, it was recognised as the anti-dote for the economic situation at that time. <i>(1980,Land of Munros, The,26</i>)

>  he speculates that a second term for Labour will - at this moment - be trickling a tear from the eye of Black Budget author Arnold Nordmeyer. <i>(Aug 17, 1987,Dominion,5</i>)

>  <b>MOORE</b> Would the action we had to take prove to be as fatal as Nordy's Black Budget, when a public eager for handouts got a good kick in the wallet? <i>(1987,Hard Labour,108</i>)

>  he speculates that a second term for Labour will - at this moment - be trickling a tear from the eye of Black Budget author Arnold Nordmeyer. <i>(Aug 17, 1987,Dominion,2</i>)

>  We had a contribution to this debate to-day from one of the Ministers of the Crown.. about the so-called "black" Budget. <i> Ibid. </i> 229/88 When the last Budget was introduced, the Leader of the Opposition described it as the " Black Budget". <i>(1930,NZ Parliamentary Debates,224/843</i>)

>  Nordmeyer became better known as a minister of another kind, producing the notorious Black Budget as finance minister of the second Labour Government in 1957. <i>(May 2001,NZ Geographic,51/48</i>)

>  On June 26, 1958, Minister of Finance Arnold Nordmeyer presented his first budget. It has gone down in political history as the "black budget" and it helped consign its author to political purgatory... In a statement issued on the night of the budget speech the two presidents of the North and South Island Motor Unions called it "black Thursday" and Federation of Labour strongman Fintan Patrick Walsh was soon labelling it the "black budget". <i>(Jun 22, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C2</i>)

## black burn
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an incomplete forest fire where the heat is insufficient to reduce timber to a small residue of white ash.

>  <b>LEVY</b> A white ash, called a white burn was the objective; a black burn resulted from a less intense fire where the heat was not sufficient to burn the timber, leaf mould, seeds and spores on the forest floor. <i>(1970,Grasslands of NZ,241</i>)

>  <b>BIBBY</b> The fire made a horrible mess, the material not being dry enough to get rid of small trees - to the bushmen, a 'blackburn'. [blackburn] <i>(1990,Lunesdale: A Bush Farm Community from 1871,12</i>)

>  <b>LEVY</b> It was not so difficult to replace the forest with grass where the climate made intense white-ash burns possible after the felling of the forest. ... But in higher rain-fall belts, when poor burns (black burns) only occur, much forest litter remained unconsumed ... <i>Ibid.</i> 241 A steady, hot fire was desired in order to burn all fallen timber and leaf mould, seeds, and fern spores lying dormant on the forest floor. A white ash, called a <i>white burn</i>, was the objective; a black burn resulted from a less intense fire where the heat was not sufficient to burn the timber, leaf mould, seeds, and spores on the forest floor. <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.</i>)

These black layers are often one or two inches thick, and repose upon coarse quartzose sands. As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfers' as they are called, examine the coastline near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient. <i>(1948,Julius Von Haast,528</i>) [NOTES: 1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 528-529]

## blanketings
 
 <i>n.</i>



 
 <i>n.</i> [mining]

>  While on an official visit to the Thames Goldfield I ...[observed] the ... effect of Cyanide of Potassium, in preventing the flouring of mercury used in working the blanketings. These blanketings I found have ... a decidedly acid reaction, due ... to the presence of ferric and ferrous salts ..., and it is to the former ... that what is commonly known as [335] `flouring,' is mainly due, in the process cited above; such ferric salts being able to either oxidize or chloridize the surface of any mercury ..., thus enfilming it with a compound, which being practically insoluble in water ... prevents that metallic contact taking place between detached mercurial globules, which is necessary to amalgamation. <i>(1876,TrNZI,8/334</i>) [NOTES: (Skey)]

>  The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings. <i>(1876,TrNZI,8/179</i>)

An American put in that in his country a section was a square mile and the word was used with that meaning in parts of Australia, but in the States they used the word `lot' to describe a building block. ## blood alley
 
 <i>n.</i> a white marble streaked with red

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>Ibid.</i> 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899] A `taw' was usually an `alley' or `blood alley' made of agate. We used to take them home and burn them in a fire to convert them into `blood alleys'. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>blood alley</i>. A white, or whitish, marble streaked with red: Aus. and NZ children's: latye C.19-20. Adopted ex. common English dialect. <i>(1984,Dictionary of Slang,97</i>)

## blood and treasure despatch
 
 <i>phr.</i> (also blood and money despatch) Grey's despatch accusing missionaries (and the Williams family in particular) of obtaining excessive Maori land. [Frances Porter in a p.c. 4 November 1987 drew HWO's attention to a use of the collocation `blood and treasure' by Jane Maria Atkinson: checks in biblical concordances and main dictionaries of quotations did not turn up any evidence of a general use or source outside this NZ one]

Williams, Journal 1847 August 19] was that of Grey to Gladstone, 25 June 1846, which came to be known as the `Blood and Money' or `Blood and Treasure' despatch. ... (Carleton ... Vol. 2, Appendix D.) <i>(1974,Turanga Journals,441fn</i>) [NOTES: 1974 Frances Porter in Turanga Journals]

>  As the editor [of the New Zealander] says if he [Governor Grey] has compounded many such documents as the blood & Treasure despatch, he is a ruined man ... <i>(May 5, 1848,Turanga Journals,487</i>) [NOTES: 1848 Apr 5 William Williams in Turanga Journals (1974) 487]

## bloody
 
 <i>adj.</i> a colloquial intensifier, used, so EDD, by the `lower classes' `indifferently as a term of depreciation or appreciation'; frequent in NZ speech as it is elsewhere, but not so much as to be regarded as a New Zealandism (contrast <i>great Australian adjective</i>: no doubt used off the New Zealand coast from earliest English rediscovery, but not much recorded in print before WW1 (See [cf. also bloody oath; my oath](../A#also-bloody-oath;-my-oath))

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> Miss Bloody Haigat. <i>(1944,Troop Target,26</i>)

>  [Third Mate - whaler] ... amongst other things said that all who said so were bloody liars. <i>(1836,Journal Barque 'Australian'</i>)

>  <b>SWAINSON</b> When the heathen Maories see their men made drunk, their women debauched, and their chiefs called `bloody Maories', no wonder our religion shall appear to them but little better than the empty profession of a barren creed. <i>(1859,New Zealand and Its Colonisation,37</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> I was telling them at the school [for painting] I go to ... about your man and his [mate][sic] saying `bloody' 72 times in 10 minutes; only I did not mention names. <i>(1867,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1867 Samuel Butler letter to Haast in 1919 Jones Jones Samuel Butler, A Memoir 1/128]



 
 <i>adv.</i> as an intensifier, very

>  You'll find out, too, that your New Zealand buddy is no Puritan when it comes to swearing. You hear the word `bloody' - bloody this and bloody that - all over the place, except in mixed company. <i>(1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,34</i>)

>  <b>ASHCROFT</b> [Against the over use of bugger, bloody and hell] ... One of [these], the word b-y, is simply coarse and nasty, but it may have had a perfectly harmless, even pious, origin. ... Its absurd uses now ... `That's a high building, Tom.' ... `Not so bloody high.' <i>(1900,Public Morals,13</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>DAVIN</b> ... no bloody fear <i>(1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,196</i>)

>  <b>6/114</b> Like bloody hell it will! <i>(1948,Landfall</i>) [NOTES: (Ballantyne)]

>  You mind your own bloody business. <i>(1948,Landfall,13/23</i>) [NOTES: (Gaskell)]

>  <b>WILSON</b> Hell's bloody bells. <i>(1950,Brave Company,83</i>)

>  Not bloody likely. You buggers started all this. <i>(1950,Landfall,15/213</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSTON</b> `Eight pounds of bug down his [sc. the cat's] furry cakehole! Shell and bloody all. ...' <i>(1981,Fish Factory,78</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>adj.</i> immediately after an [ ] sound, perhaps to suggest the indef. art. of phrases as <i>not a bloody bit</i>

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> abso-bloody-lutely <i>(1944,Troop Target,99</i>)

>  <b>BRUNO</b> `Who goes there?' `Santa Bloody Claus.' `Pass Kiwi.' <i>(1948,Maleesh George,24</i>)

## blow
 
 <i>n.</i> an isolated outcrop of mineral (esp. quartz). [Check whether date is 1897 or 1898]

>  <b>BARRY</b> I came to the conclusion that the lode was not a permanent one, but only what is called a `blow' of quartz. <i>(1879,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,224</i>)

>  The molybdenite deposits ... are described ... as roughly circular or oval-shaped outcrops of [24] quartz, or `blows' carry wolfram and native bismuth. The `blows' when followed down develop into irregular pipe-shaped masses ... <i>(1906,TrNZI,38/23</i>)

>  So far as one could judge from a surface examination, the outcrops appear to be isolated blocks of quartz or `blows' that follow the foliation planes of the schist. <i>(1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.5 (NS) 65</i>)

>  In places [scheelite] occurs as blows in the quartz in sufficient quantity to be sorted by hand-picking. <i>(1939,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.39 (NS) 104</i>) [NOTES: (Williamson, Naseby)]

>  An immense `blow' of quartz 150ft by 100ft on the surface, and standing 30ft above the surrounding ground was located in 1872 on the Rainy Creek property. <i>(1948,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.42 (NS) 54</i>) [NOTES: (Gage, Reefton)]

>  <b>NOLAN</b> <i>Blow</i>: a large outcropping reef, usually of barren quartz. <i>(1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,111</i>)

>  This great "blow" of quartz, as the miners term it, strikes to the north-west, and therefore crosses the auriferous belt nearly at right-angles. <i>(1897,AJHR,C9/9</i>)

>  The great "blow" or "buck-reef" of the Tokatea is found in the slates at the western end of the lower or No. 7 adit. <i>(1898,AJHR,C-9/51</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to open with explosives (See [peter](../P#peter),[tank](../T#tank))



 
 <i>v.</i> to clean a mineral (esp. gold) by blowing air over it to remove the particles of the material in which it was found; to dry-blow [mining] (See [cf. dry-blowing](../D#dry-blowing))

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> [Bank clerk] `By the time I had cleaned, or `blown' the gold, it was too late to think of returning. <i>Ibid.</i> 220 The gold is placed on a flat pear-shaped metal dish, with a perpendicular rim or edge except at the point of the pear, where there is no rim. This is moved in such a manner that the gold is tossed up, and all the finer particles and dirt are worked forward towards the opening, out by which the operator blows the sand. <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,217</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> of a fly, to deposit eggs on (food, blankets, clothing, etc.), (See [also fly-blown](../A#also-fly-blown))

>  <b>BUTLER</b> Red blankets are usual; white show fly-blows. The blue-bottle flies blow among blankets that are left lying untidily about ... Fly-blown blankets are all very well, provided they have been quite dry ever since they were blown; <i>(Mar 24, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iv/52</i>)

>  A system of sluicing in which strips of ground about 3 yards wide, on each side of a gutter, are sluiced into a gutter which runs down the slope. This is a novel system of sluicing that has been successfully used for the working of wide stretches of poor alluvial ground in Central Otage.  <i>n.</i>

## blucher boots
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  [The gumdigger's] essentials were dungaree trousers, with leather belt, short-sleeved flannel shirt, blucher boots (socks were rarely worn), a cap or wide-brimmed felt hat - <i>(1972,Gumdigger, The,51</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> In those days [early 1900s] the [kauri bushmen's] customary dress was the old Blucher boots ... and tairoa trousers, which were made of a kind of heavy white duck; these were tied with bowyangs below the knees. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,155</i>) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> The customary dress was the old Blucher boots... and Tairoa trousers, which were made of a kind of heavy white duck; these were tied with bowyangs below the knees. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,155</i>)



## bluchers
 
 <i>n.</i> strong leather half-boots

>  ... bluchers of good hard leather, flat and thick in the soles, ... <i>(1875,Otago Guardian</i>) [NOTES: c1875 Otago Guardian in 1980 Tonkin Dunedin Gaol 17]

>  <b>MANSFIELD</b> ... her front teeth were knocked out, she had red pulpy hands, and she wore on her feet a pair of dirty `Bluchers'. <i>(1912,Stories,111,1984 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MANSFIELD</b> Everything was in that shop. Bluchers and sand shoes, straw hats and onions were strung across the ceiling, ... <i>(1916,Aloe, The,45,1982 O'Sullivan ed.</i>)

>  <b>MANSFIELD</b> A pair of old bluchers was on one side of the door, and a large red watering-can on the other. <i>(1922,Stories,475,1984 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HUNT</b> ... bluchers - they were lace-up working boots with thin soles. <i>(1981,Speaking a Silence,29</i>)

>  <b>CHI</b> Working in the wet was hard on footwear, and boots were a heavy item in clothing expenditure. Some wore `bluchers', a short boot; gumboots do not seem to have been in general use until the twentieth century; ... <i>(1982,Diary,x</i>) [NOTES: 1982 Child Introduction to Ayton Diary x]

>  <b>FITTON</b> BOOTS AND SHOES.- ... Napoleons, 35s. ... per pair; Wellingtons, English, 30s. ...; colonial, 35s. ... per pair; Bluchers and Oxford, ... 12s; ... <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),83</i>)

>  <b>PICARD</b> ... the waster that has a bad word for him isn't fit for you to wipe your hob-nailed bloody bluchers on. <i>(1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,7</i>)



## bludge
 
 <i>v.</i> to live off the generosity of others, to sponge;often with on; to cadge, scrounge; sponge (on). [From <i>N.Z. English to U.S. English Dictionary</i> at http://nz.com/NZ/Culture/NZDic.html]

>  We bludged our way into a bus and went down to the Franz Joseph. <i>(Aug 1905,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,5/19/93</i>)

>  Those oysters you bludged from me. <i>(1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East,43</i>)

>  The writer goes midnight like a lag/ Who knows that his pals will twist/ And tell a pernicious different tale/ Though they bludged him his last fag. <i>(1952,Here & Now,26</i>) [NOTES: (K. Smithyman)]

>  `What in hell are ya doin in Christchurch anyway? Bludgin on social security, I spose.' `No. Dicken on that.' <i>Ibid.</i> 47 I was nearly bowed over by some officer being thrown out. Trying to bludge in on their party he was. <i>Ibid.</i> 227 ... I felt sick. Like the time guarding the boob back at Advance Base and there were New Zealanders behind the wire. New Zealanders bludging cigarettes. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,44</i>)

>  <b>HELMER</b> ... we strolled up to see Russ Tullock. `Maybe bludge a drink,' Crump said. `Haven't a drop in the house, lads,' said Russ. `You'd be welcome to it if I had. ...' <i>(1964,Stag Party,103</i>)

>  v.int.(slang) impose on, avoid hard work at expense of others, whence : <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),611</i>)

>  <i>bludge ... v. (Sl.)</i> impose on, avoid hard work at expense of others, whence :<i> bludger ...n</i>. hanger on, parasite, `scrounger'. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),3</i>)

>  <b>AGNEW</b> He had bludged a smoke from me and had asked why I refused to go to war. <i>(1974,Loner, The,127</i>)

>  <i>bludge Austral. & N.Z. inf. ~ vb. 1.</i> (when <i>intr</i>., often foll. by <i>on</i>) to scrounge from (someone). 2.<i> (intr.)</i> to skive. <i>~n. 3.</i> a very easy task. [C19: back formation from<i> bludger</i> pimp, < BLUDGEON] - <i>bludger n. </i> <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 76; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 53]]

>  <b>ROBINSON</b> I sometimes joke about what I call `the worldwide freemasonry of runners' which makes it possible by just putting on a pair of road shoes and shorts to bludge a spare bed in any city in the world. Derogatory. To continually ask for help in money, goods or services <i>(1986,Heroes and Sparrows,70</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> ?over long periods. .in 4;`He won't go out and get a bit of wood from the bush like the rest of us do, he'd rather bludge some from his old mother's shed.' Thus also, to make an occasional request, in good humour. .in 4;`We won't unpack till we get there, we'll call at Don's on the way and bludge a snack. He'll be real pleased to see us.' <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],77</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> He's got no time for any man bludging./ I owe him [the publican] for a grunter and a bottle/ And he'll think I'm dodging. <i>(1979,Collected Poems,219,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (1960) 1979 Baxter Collected Poems 219]

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i> bludger:</i> a bludger is a SPONGER - someone who is always borrowing and rarely repaying. To bludge is to borrow. It's socially acceptable to say `may I bludge a cigarette (or a cup of sugar)' but calling someone a bludger can be a fighting insult <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,15</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Trying to bludge in on their party he was. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,47</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to enjoy a job at base; live at ease or apparently safely at the front line's expense, (a back-formation from bludger) (See [cf. Bludgers' Hill](../B#bludgers'-hill))

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> He'll immediately assume that you were one of the 95% who bludged at base in Enzed or England or Yankee Land. <i>(1944,Troop Target,186</i>)



## bludger
 
 <i>n.</i> a useless person; one who avoids responsibility or lives on the back of others; a loafer, an idler [cf. dole bludger 1984 14 F E131Wgton Girls C. 10 BLUDGER [useless person]] (See [cf. dole bludger](../D#dole-bludger))

>  What type of skunk Costello is can be gathered from the fact that he is an individual of the bludger class, who will never attempt anything in in the form of honest hard work, and against whom the detec [check] engaged in war. <i>(Sep 8, 1906,NZ Truth,64/4/4</i>)

>  <b>HILLIARD</b> See that bludger there? He's an auctioneer's stooge. <i>(1960,Maori Girl,194</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> As far as he was concerned, he said, bludgers [here, members of a search-and-rescue party] could stay lost if they didn't have the sense to follow a creek. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,60</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> This term is used in contempt. .in 4;`Here comes that Z now we've done it on our own. He's always got an excuse to be somewhere else when there might be a bit of work to be done. The greatest bloody bludger of all time'. <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],78</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a thick-edged axe, used by bush workers.

>  <b>DAHM</b> The bushman always carried two axes as he worked. One he called the bludger. It had a thick edge and he used it where the going was tough. The bludger was almost impossible to gap. He would lend the bludger to almost anyone who asked for it. <i>(2000,People of the Axe, The,38</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a criminal who uses a bludgeon

>  Was Griffiths Brutally Butchered by Bludgers? <i>(Jan 10, 1906,NZ Truth,34/7/8</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sheep or cattle dog that does not perform well. (See [follower](../F#follower))

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> As Wonk did all my heading much better than the other two bludgers, the mustering went on a lot easier for the next couple of days. <i>(1973,Boot in the Stirrup,57</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a man who lives with or on the earnings of a harlot.

>  ... What, in slang phrase, we call a `bludger,' or a species of un-human being that lives on the proceeds of an `unfortunate's' prostitution, ... <i>(Aug 25, 1906,NZ Truth,62/5/1</i>)

>  Bludger and Bawd and Their Brats: ... He allowed his wife to go out battling ... of nights while he stayed home. <i>(Aug 11, 1906,NZ Truth,60/5/5</i>)

>  <b>HYDE</b> In the noon heat everything in Cairo slept except the male defenders of the prostitutes' quarters, known to the dictionary as <i>souteneurs</i>, and to the troops as bludgers. <i>(1936,Passport to Hell,96</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> one who has a safe job at base; who shirks active service; a Base-wallah.

>  <b>DAVIN</b> How the hell are you, you big staff-wallahs? ... What are you doing out of bed at this hour? If I had a fine bludger's job like this I'd take it seriously. <i>(1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,103</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> `Bloody doctors and dentists and base pay bludgers, even nurses and V.A.D.'s know more about the war than we do who fight it!' <i>(1951,Brave Company,100</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Nobody put up stripes in our outfit. That was for base bludgers. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,92</i>)

>  <b>DAVIN</b> ... You should be jake sitting out the rest of the war in some bludger's job in Trentham [Military Camp]. <i>(1975,Breathing Spaces,124</i>)

>  <b>WAGENER</b> `The Bludger' typifies the Div. man's contempt for a certain type who were numerous enough at one time in a certain part of Maadi Camp to earn for it the title `Bludgers' Hill' [different from<i> base-wallah </i>who is often there through circumstances he cannot control]. <i>(1943,Kiwi's Soliloquy,7</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> inveterate cadger; sponger; occas. one who `borrows' or `lifts' objects

>  <b>HAMILTON</b> The Bludger. He was known among the boobheads as that. When they called him by his name you felt they were being intentionally respectful. ... But connected with him it didn't mean what it was supposed to mean. A bludger is a pimp, a man who lives on women, but I doubt if anyone thought specifically that of him. Bludger is also what it sounds, a fairly indiscriminate term of abuse. When the boobheads called him that they meant a lot of things. A bully, something sly, a chap who'd put a dirty one on to you, not necessarily for any purpose other than it gave him pleasure to do so. <i>(1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,89</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> A dairy-farmer type ... was enthusiastically entertaining an obvious bludger, spending money. <i>(1962,One of Us,11</i>)

>  <b>WALLIS</b> The bloody working man's the backbone of the country. ... Pack of bludgers, that's what they are. <i>(1963,Point of Origin,10</i>)

>  <i>bludger n.</i> hanger on parasite, ` scrounger'. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),611</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> We'll go up North and start a boarding house. No bludgers allowed. <i>(1982,Collected Plays,39</i>) [NOTES: Wide Open Cage]

>  <b>BAXTER</b> We'll go up North and start a boarding house. No bludgers allowed. <i>(1982,Collected Plays,39</i>) [NOTES: Wide Open Cage]

>  <b>LELAND</b> a bludger is a SPONGER - someone who is always borrowing and rarely repaying. To bludge is to borrow. It's socially acceptable to say `may I bludge a cigarette (or a cup of sugar)' but calling someone a bludger can be a fighting insult. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,15</i>)

>  <b>IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.)</b> He supposed she was thinking, 'Another bloody bludger' and was frustrated because she couldn't do anything about it. <i>(1982,Into the World of Light,127</i>)

>  Coming from the sheltered upbringing of New Zealand, where misguided and ill-thought-out benefit policies by well-meaning governments have produced a generation of bludgers - sons and daughters of people on the dole deciding to follow their parents into the family business, rather than actually work for a living. <i>(Dec 11, 2000,Dominion,6</i>)

>  Some bludger's got my tin hat. <i>(Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/17</i>)

>  "Don't you know that. It's a bludge. I'm just a bludger." <i>(Feb 9, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28</i>)

>  Your correspondent.. unfortunately epitomises the still widely-held view that the unemployed are idle, drug-ridden, lazy bludgers who live a life of ease and luxury on fat welfare cheques. <i>(Sep 19, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12</i>)

>  Everybody accuses and abuses them like they were the culprits because they're on the DPB and they're bludgers. <i>(1995,Mana,No. 10 : 31</i>)

>  <b>LACEY</b> Unless you were a Rugby Union bludger you got out on the old pavement outside Eden Park. <i>(1976,Loosehead Len's Bumper Thump Book,7</i>)



 
<b>5</b> <i>n.</i> a term of abuse for a beneficiary

>  Social Welfare minister Michael Cullen spoke out yesterday against those who criticised beneficiaries as `undeserving' or `idle bludgers'. <i>(Nov 11, 1988,Dominion,2</i>)



## bludger's fish
 
 <i>n.</i> cadger's fish

>  <b>WILSON</b> MEGRIM ... Sometimes called Lantern-fish (because a lantern could be easily shone through it) and known to the Maoris as `mahue' - the fish that is left behind. Known to Christchurch fishermen in early years as the Bludger's Fish. It was the fish they handed out to well-known bludgers who came down to the docks to cadge fish. <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,74</i>)



## Bludgers' Hill
 
 <i>n.</i> nickname for the site of 2NZEF headquarters (Maadi near Cairo) [WW2] (See [cf. Daffodil Hill](../D#daffodil-hill))

>  <b>HELM</b> The hill that has since become famous in the 2 NZEF as Bludgers' Hill, or Daffodil Hill (beautiful but yellow) as it is now known. <i>(1944,Fights and Furloughs,8</i>)

>  <b>DAVIN</b> They drove back along the [Maadi] camp road and up on to Bludger's Hill where the Base Staff dwelt, aloof. First the MS, inscrutable but cordial. Then the Pay Office ... `The working class can kiss my arse, I've got a bludger's job at last', sang Smithy to the tune of the Red Flag. ... `All the boys sing it whenever they pass Bludger's Hill. ... Makes the base-wallahs mad.' <i>(1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,147</i>)

>  <b>BRUNO</b> ... before Bludgers' Hill was officially condemned as a title in Routine Orders by sensitive base wallahs. <i>(1948,Maleesh George,58</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> This chap finally admitted he had never come down from Bludgers' Hill and then asked what outfit he had been in. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,66</i>)

>  Maadi, once known to thousands of New Zealanders as `Bludger's Hill' the site of Freyberg's headquarters, the training camp and the main camp for those on leave from the front - is unrecognisable. <i>(Oct 4, 1982,Evening Post,41</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>Bludger's Hill</i> nickname for admin. quarters on rise of Maadi base camp near Cairo, WWII. <i>[Jim Henderson] </i> <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,16</i>)

>  <b>KIPPENBERGER</b> The Fourth Brigade Headquarters was established on the Hill, so on [1940-1941] to be derisively and unfairly known as `Bludgers' Hill.' <i>(1949,Infantry Brigadier,10</i>)

>  They sent ole Bill to Bludgers' Hill, and jacked him up a stripe. <i>(Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/78 : 17</i>)

>  "What do they all do up there on 'Bludgers' Hill'?" (the name given to that hill in Maadi Camp where Headquarters 2 N.Z.E.F. and other odds and sods resided. <i>(1958,RSA Review,35(1) : 1</i>) [NOTES: Check year]

>  Hot for the foe, Noel "Wig" Gardiner has a year at Bludgers Hill near the Nile, while the bloody defeats of Greece, Crete, Sidi Rezegh and Ruweizat scar into our island history. <i>(Mar 13, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),73</i>)



## bludging
 
 <i>n.</i> (1)(WWII period) appropriating, "borrowing", helping oneself, "liberating" (2)(post 1970) living off state benefits

>  <b>DAVIN</b> Well, how do you like the idea of a bit of bludging at Div HQ, Curly? <i>(1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,304</i>)

>  Back at base, they set the pace, when bludgin' was an art <i>(Dec 21, 1942,NZEF Times,II/78 : 17</i>)

>  What is undeniable, however, is that a large number of New Zealanders have come to believe that universal welfare does breed state dependency, that bludging is a national way of life for too many and that a "selfish" older generation would see their descendants reduced to penury so long as their divine right to the pension survives as long as they do. <i>(Jan 23, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),4</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> cadging

>  <b>CASEY</b> We came on a bludging trip. Can you let John have Padre to ride for a day or two? <i>(1963,As Short a Spring,194</i>)



## blue
 
 <i>n.</i> nickname for a ginger or red-headed person

>  Andrew James (Blue) Kennedy (1925 - ......) ... Never one to dodge a `blue' with employers ..., he was in fact nicknamed for his wiry crop of ginger hair. <i>(Jan 11, 1987,Sunday Star (Auckland),A7</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to scold; to go off. [[d?] June 20 The Evening Post I don't know where she was when we got there. She started blueing at me about the beer.]

>  Apparently, I had made a meet at the Johnny Horner for that afternoon and when I didn't front she blued. to blue....to abuse someone <i>(May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a bluey, a summons; also a bit of blue a criminal charge. (See [cf. blue paper](../B#blue-paper))

>  He is still a conductor in the tram service, and was shown the blister when Bailey was served with a bit-o'-blue. <i>(Mar 13, 1909,NZ Truth,195/5/1</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  For a man on the Collar, every blue he gets in means maybe another two years. <i>(Nov 1950,Here & Now,15</i>)

>  <b>HAMILTON</b> Bluey had lost his seaman's ticket over his jail blues, and I don't suppose he'll ever get it back. <i>(1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,127</i>)

>  <i>blue, n</i>. a bill, a summons. Also a fight or row. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),611</i>)

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> BLUE (n) Criminal charge <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,245</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the back country (See [i.e. the far blue yonder](../I#i.e.-the-far-blue-yonder))

>  A soggy packing up followed next morning and then it was once more `into the blue.' <i>(1948,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,4/18/300</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants, see: bindweed, borage, convolvulus, grass; grass, couch; grass, tussock; grass, wheat; lupin, morning glory, pimpernel, pine, sedge spaniard, toadstool, twitch, vervain.



 
 <i>n.</i> error, blunder, bloomer (unfortunate, unconscious) (esp. make a blue) (the infrequent verb blue (something), `to break, ruin (sthg)' seems formed on this noun, although it may be related to blue v1.), CCR suggests blow (sthg) with past tense blew it. [1953 16 M A32 Thames DHS 19 BLUE (BLOO) [make a mess]]

>  He rang Mr McGavin, Cromwell's solicitor, asking if there could be any `blues' or defects in title. <i>(Jul 14, 1954,Evening Post,12</i>)

>  <b>KEINZLY</b> `I'm not fighting, Kathy. Not with you. I'm just wanting you back in Auckland, you and the kids with your buses and milk bottles and squint-eyed postman. ... Kathy, I think I've made a blue.' <i>(1960,Tangahano,33</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> As it was not to be a hunting trip, in order to keep the weights of their packs down, they made the blue of not even taking one rifle. [1934] <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,17</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> Trouble with your blokes is you won't admit when you've made a blue. <i>(1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,17</i>)

>  <b>PEARSON</b> She heard him say to one of the men: `By God, I made a blue this morning, Ted', and he sniggered heartily. <i>(1963,Coal Flat,251</i>)

>  <b>MACNICOL</b> The men would ... tease me into admitting I'd had a blue. <i>(1965,Skippers Road,46</i>)

>  <i>blue n. (Coll.)</i> bill, summons; fight, row; mistake (N.Z.). <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),3</i>)

>  <b>MOORE</b> On one ... occasion I made a `blue' which I have not lived down yet. [here a mistaken or bad batch of bread] <i>(1969,From Forest to Farm,63</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>blue:</i> a GOOF or mistake. `I made a blue in trying to get on with her on the first date'. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,15</i>)

>  Deans planted the ball down an estimated six inches over the line, then made his second `blue' - he got up. <i>(Sep 18, 1980,Dominion,4/8</i>)

>  <i>blue</i>: mistake <i>(1981,Auckland Secondary Teachers College</i>) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <i>blue ... 8. Austral. sl. </i>an argument or fight:<i> he had a blue with a taxi driver. 9.</i> Also: <i>bluey. Austral. & N.Z. inf.</i> a summons. <i>10. Austral. & N.Z. inf.</i> a mistake; error. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,116</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 76; see 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 53 for sense 9 & 10 below]]

>  <b>SHERWOOD</b> Oh Rosie, forgive us, what have we done? Have we made a blue? <i>(1985,Botanist at Bay,42</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a convalescent soldier (See [cf. blue boy](../B#blue-boy),[blue pants](../B#blue-pants))

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> [sic] <i>(1945,Away from Home,77</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a policeman.

>  <b>THATCHER</b> All honor [sic] to the watchful trap,/ .../ He isn't an invisible blue,/ Long may this town by him be haunted,/ <i>'Tis the only case I ever knew/ Of a bobby all there when he was wanted./ </i> <i>(1864,Invercargill Minstrel,11</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the unknown

>  <b>JACKSON</b> Early in the month of September, 1941, the whole battalion moved `up the blue' (a term used to indicate any portion of the sterile Western Desert) to a place called Baguish. <i>(1943,Passage to Tobruk,104</i>)

>  We were striking out into the blue... In the desert the unknown is always "the blue", whether it be Egypt, Cyrenaica, Tripolitania or Tunisia. <i>(Apr 19, 1943,NZEF Times,II/95 : 6</i>)

>  When we had settled down and knew that the Western Desert was ALWAYS "up the blue", I inquired.. where could I learn the language? <i>(Aug 9, 1943,NZEF Times,III/111 : 2</i>)

>  You'd be talking, you'd take somebody shopping or go out for lunch or dinner today. Tomorrow they'd be up the blue and walk on a landmine and you'd never see them again. <i>(Feb 2, 2002,Dominion,13</i>)

>  <b>BARBER</b> ... the whole brigade [the Camel Corps] could, on an hour's notice, go off into the `blue' for five days without any communication or assistance from base. <i>(1984,Red Coat to Jungle Green,93</i>) [NOTES: 1938 John Robertson The Cameliers in Palestine 27 in 1984 Barber Red Coat to Jungle Green 93]

>  Out in the blue! <i>(Sep 2, 1941,2NZEF Times,15/6</i>)

## bob
 
 <i>n.</i> orig. worms threaded and coiled (see cit. 1967), but also meat, bacon, etc. held in a tangle of twine or shredded flax-blade, attached to a line, for catching eels. [ca1940 a bob of tangled bindertwine, or flax, holding a bait for eels whose backward-sloping teeth would become entangled allowing them to be dragged from the water]

[early 20C.] We went down to the river about dusk, each of us with a rod, ... our bobs suspended in a deep pool. <i>(1967,Tang of The Bush,103</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> fiddle @v (1952-53)



 
 <i>v.</i>

 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to dispose of unwanted sheep by cooking them and selling the tallow, especially prior to refrigeration of meat for export in 1882.

It is built of galvanised iron. <i>(Mar 24, 1875,Jottings on the Spot,16</i>)

He is simply extending to you the original and (I hope) the everlasting hospitality of all Australia; he is suggesting that he make a brew of tea. <i>(1945,If You'd Care to Know,99</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>phr.</i> (Rural) [shepherding, mustering and hunting] [originally] to light a fire and heat water for tea; [recently] to have a cup of tea/coffee.

## boiling down
 
 <i>n.</i> [(attrib. uses)]

>  The fine grassy land bordered on the overstocked district of Sydney - the `boiling-down' system was then unknown - the soil overstocked, Pat Philip undiscovered. <i>(1852,Saunders' Monthly Magazine,1/</i>) [NOTES: 1852 Saunders' Monthly Magazine Vol I in 1976 Canterbury Colony 10]

>  <b>CRAWFORD</b> The Boiling Down works ... provides a great service to the runs in freeing them of their surplus stock,... <i>(1981,Station Years,69</i>) [NOTES: 1870 McLean in 1981 Crawford Station Years 69]

>  <b>JACKSON</b> I believe [the kea] acquired his liking for fat in the old `boiling down' days. <i>(1935,Annals of a NZ Family,132</i>)

>  <b>SEWELL</b> After which time, assuming favourable circumstances, ... and surplus stock worth something above boiling down rate, they will give a large return for the capital laid out; <i>(1855,Journal,2/147,1980 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the process of, or tanks for, boiling down sheep carcasses to extract tallow.

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> `Boiling-down' was formerly practised to a considerable extent in Australia; the mere fat or tallow of the animal for export to England <i>being worth far more than the meat for colonial consumption</i>. `Boiling-down establishments' were formed in the pastoral districts, and the process became a regular business. The sheep or cattle were killed and skinned, the carcass thrown into the boiling vat, the fat skimmed off for export tallow, and the meat thrown away. `Boiling down' will probably remain a permanent feature of Australian grazing in the districts remote from large towns. <i>(1861,New Zealand (various authors/titles),374</i>)

>  <b>BENMORE</b> On 25 may, B.D. started on benmore; boiling down, like other unpleasant things, was usually known by its initials. <i>(May 25, 1870,Diary</i>) [NOTES: >[1870 May 25 Benmore diary] in 1981 Pinney Early Northern Otago Runs 24]

>  <b>BURDON</b> Boiling down did not begin in New Zealand until later [than the Australian 1850], as there was no need for it; ... <i>(1938,High Country,112</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> ... some run-holders set up boiling-downs [specific reference to 1880 slump] <i>(1944,Moonshine,7</i>)

>  <i>boiling down n</i>. process of rendering tallow from sheep's carcases. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),4</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the slaughtering and boiling of surplus sheep for tallow.

>  Boiling-down appears likely to become an important industry in the province of Wellington. <i>(Feb 20, 1869,Otago Witness,17</i>)

>  .. low-priced meat and boiling down are synonymous terms. <i>(Nov 29, 1872,Hawke's Bay Herald,2</i>)

>  <b>KAY</b> One farming practice long gone is remembered by the name, Boiling Down paddock. The boiling-down of mutton carcasses for tallow was the end use of sheep until refrigeration was an alternative. [boiling-down] <i>(1996,Anthony Wall, Settler of Porirua,124</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sheep surplus to requirements, destined for the boiling-down or rendering-down works [1880s].

>  I brought in a lot of boiling downs. <i>(May 24, 1886,E.M. Hutchinson Diary</i>) [NOTES: EM HUTCHINSON Diary May 24 (1981)]
