## bolter
 
 <i>n.</i> (Sport) an unexpected selection [J Boon (jboon@unitec.ac.nz) suggests this comes from the phrase "bolt from the blue". Trish Ryan (dentrish@clear.net.nz) says it comes from "infamous horse betting circles. Back before the days of judicial videos, race results were sometimes 'pre-arranged'. The backed horse would be given the perfect run in behind a nominated pacemaker. Other horses would be ridden into deadend passages or taken wide in the run home. Occasionally an uncooperative pacemaking horse would 'bolt' on its jockey and win the race - and lose large betting plunges that had been made on the intended victor." >Google search showed in used in Australia also and to a lesser degree also UK, the Netherlands.]

>  Royce Willis has yet to start in a national provincial championship game for Waikato but is the big bolter in the All Black squad. <i>(Jul 1, 1998,Dominion,1</i>)

>  [Hdg] Rookie lock bolter in All Black test squad. <i>(Jul 1, 1998,Dominion,48</i>)

>  For a number of reasons, Graham Henry and his fellow selectors made sure that there wouldn't be many bolters into the 2007 line-up .. When looking at possible bolters, there didn't appear to be many options who hadn't already been tried. <i>(Jul 26, 2007,Wellingtonian,34</i>)

>  They still produced one "bolter" in the Chiefs No. 8 Dylan Mika, who moved to that franchise when he was not wanted by the Blues. <i>(May 25, 1999,Dominion,28</i>)

>  Greg Feek: A bolter in the All Black selections. <i>(May 30, 1999,Sunday Star Times,B3</i>)

>  There would be polite appplause when the.. certainties were named, and whistles and shouts when a bolter was chosen. <i>(Jun 5, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21</i>)

>  Jesse Ryder has put his troubles in the past and is now being tipped as a Black Caps bolter. <i>(Dec 17, 2005,Dominion Post,D1</i>)

>  What's going on? I'm after Nathan Cayleess, the bolter in the Kiwi league team, but some bloke with a strong Australian accent has sneaked into his room and answered his phone. <i>(Oct 9, 1998,Evening Post,19</i>)

>  Was it Colin Cooper telling the All Blacks bolter that he had been drafted into the Hurricanes? <i>(Oct 29, 2005,Dominion Post,D3</i>)

>  Marian Hobbs : The Broadcasting and Environment Minister is the bolter in the Cabinet. <i>(Dec 20, 1999,Dominion,2</i>)

>  ..represents the last chance for Bracewell to make some considered adjustments to his squad..and it's not beyond all possibility that he could come up with another bolter. <i>(Feb 9, 2006,NZ Herald,C18</i>)

>  Bolters are rare in the modern era . . . <i>(Oct 24, 2005,Dominion Post,D1</i>)

## bomb-squasher
 
 <i>n.</i> [cf DARE bombsies a dropping shot in marbles] (See [also bum-squasher](../A#also-bum-squasher))

>  Culled dairy cows and culled beef animals are sent directly to the works as `boners' - that is, the bones are removed from the carcasses and the meat is used for manufactured products (as distinct from meat that is used for prime cuts). Farmers are paid schedule rates on the killing weights. <i>(1974,NZ Agriculture,188</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>bomb-squasher</i> big marble, a menace to small marbles. <i>(1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,15</i>)

As for the Soobs, which are typically 2 or 3 women whoring out of private homes throughout the Auckland suburbs, the city council argues they could move into the city, where there are 9500 apartment units or, more to the point, 12,000 bedrooms. <i>(Oct 30, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A5</i>)

## book
 
 <i>v.</i> to fold sealskins into layers like the leaves of books

>  <b>HOWARD</b> Incoming skins are sorted to arbitrary standards - wigs (old males), clap-matches (females), bulls, yearlings, grey or silver pups (under one year), black pups. If the cargo is intended for the European or American market, the skins are removed from the animal with an inch of blubber adhering, and in the final simple treatment are washed, heavily slated, and then folded or `booked' into rectangular shape for packing. Skins destined for China, however, are treated with more preliminary care. They are taken as cleanly as possible, and after careful washing are sent to the `beamer' to be thoroughly scraped free of the last remaining particles of flesh and blubber. <i>(1940,Rakiura,40</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a bookmaker

## boom
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  There was one more sound that so far had gone unrecorded - a sound as of someone blowing across the top of an empty milk bottle with the power of a fog horn and the regularity of a heartbeat. This was the male kakapo booming - sitting inside the amphitheatre of his bowl, inflated into a feathered balloon, sending out a pulsing, low-frequency love call. <i>(Mar 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 56/30</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a timber-boom across a river, etc. to retain floating logs.

>  <b>BAINES</b> It is nine miles from the dam to the `boom' at the mouth of the creek. <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,177</i>)

>  At the mouths of streams a line of floating [kauri] logs have been previously fastened together with iron `dogs' and short chains; this is called a `boom', and prevents the timber getting away to sea. The logs are then fastened together in rafts, and, guided by men armed with long poles shod with iron (called rafting-spears), are conveyed to the mills, ... <i>(1894,NZ Official Yearbook,365</i>) [NOTES: (E. Tregear: Labour in NZ)]

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> Here [the felled kauri trees] lie until a `fresh' drives them down to the creek or harbour where the `boom' lies waiting. This boom is formed of a circle of logs fastened together with chains. There may be as many as fifty logs forming the chain, which sometimes encloses acres of water. The logs enter the boom, - are fastened together into a kind of raft, and towed to their destination. <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,62,1940, p. 63 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PINFOLD</b> On his return [from Upper Thames] he took us to what were called `The Booms'. These were great logs of wood driven into the ground across the mouth of a river that opened out toward the sea. The bushmen ... felled the trees. Afterwards, when a good rain came and flooded the river, the `logs' would come down, and the `booms' were expected to stop them from going out to sea. <i>(1930,Fifty Years In Maoriland,60</i>)

>  <b>MANDER</b> They watched the progress of the log from the booms up the skids to the side of the breakdown platform... Halved and quartered, it was then levered ... on to greased rollers and rushed towards the big circulars, which turned it into flitches. Then the small circulars, the drag, and the goose completed its metamorphosis into the regulation strips ... <i>(1920,Story of a NZ River, The,198,1960 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HOWE</b> We had certainly expected life in Thames to be more lively than it was at the `booms' [of a timber camp]. <i>(1964,Stamper Battery</i>)

>  <b>EADDY</b> Here [the logs] would be discharged and rafted into `booms' alongside the different sawmills to await their turn of being hauled up and sawn. <i>(1939,Neath Swaying Spars,11</i>)

>  <b>BARLOW</b> ... the [kauri] logs are placed behind booms until enough are collected to make a raft. <i>(1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,112</i>)

>  <b>INGLIS</b> a `boom' of great logs <i>(1887,Our NZ Cousins,27</i>)

>  The practice obtains among bushmen of rolling the logs into the adjacent creeks, down which they are afterwards driven during freshes to the `booms.' <i>(1876,TrNZI,9/368</i>) [NOTES: (Brown)]

## boozeroo
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Walker's explanation was that he was on the boozeroo, and didn't know what he was doing. <i>(Jan 4, 1908,NZ Truth,6</i>)

>  The face of Elizabeth Sheehan, next charged, reminded one of a lost soul plunging violently in a sea of boiling beer. She pleaded guilty to boozeroo, but denied with vehemence that she was a rogue and vagabond. <i>(Mar 5, 1910,NZ Truth,245/5/7</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a boozy party

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a (low) pub; a party or drinking group (?transf. f. 1). [ca1951 Wellington (H.W.O.) used of @workingclass' pubs]

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>boozeroo</i> drinking bout. - pub. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,19</i>)

## borage
 
 <i>n.</i> a coarse, hairy, blue-flowered European herb found mainly in the North Island (See [blue borage](../B#blue-borage))

>  <b>BAKER</b> She put her cup of borage tea down... <i>(2000,Kokopu Dreams,171</i>)

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> VIPER'S BUGLOSS (<i>Echium vulgare</i> ), also called blue weed and by mistake, blue borage, occurs on roadsides, river-beds, and fields in both islands, though it is commoner in the south, and especially in Marlborough. It is an annual or biennial with a deep penetrating tap root root and a stem 2 to 3 ft high. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,143,1967 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McCASKILL</b> Small local hives of wild bees produced honey with a special flower due to the mixture of nectar from white clover, viper's bugloss (known locally [on Molesworth] as blue borage) and various wildflowers. <i>(1959,Molesworth,248</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> The Taylor River [Marlborough] river-fan glowing with <i>eschscholtzia</i>, the orange-yellow four-o'-clock, or bright with blue borage. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,171</i>)

>  <i>borage, [=] viper's bugloss</i> [s] <i>(1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,7</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> Viper's bugloss is often wrongly called `blue borage' - the correct name for an ornamental plant of the same family. <i>(1980,Weeds of Crops,110</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> Viper's bugloss, or blue devil, often incorrectly called `borage', makes a sea of blue on open ground, particularly ... in the South Island. <i>(1980,Wild Flowers,32</i>)

## borax/borak
 
 <i>n.</i> banter, ridicule [(The 1905 cit. has spg <i>borah,</i> which is taken as a typographical error for<i> borak</i>, which itself is less common in NZ than the folk re-formation borax)] (See [also poke the borax](../A#also-poke-the-borax))

>  They've been taking it out on borax since. <i>(Aug 27, 1910,NZ Free Lance,13</i>)

>  Although Borak could not repeat his Winter Hurdles win at Riccarton.. the Nightmarch gelding has a jumping future. <i>(Aug 28, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/166 : 11</i>)

>  To poke the borax at Tottennham Hotspur soccer fans for getting so excited about a 3-0 halftime lead over Manchester United would be childish. (Hah, losers!) <i>(Oct 2, 2001,Evening Post,30</i>)

>  <b>GRACE</b> "Go on chiaking.. poke borak - it doesn't hurt me." <i>(1914,Tale of a Timber Town,88</i>)

>  If one could only think that Attic salt was a commodity that you could buy at the grocers.. it would be easier to determine how much of the eloquence poured out at smoke concerts.. and meetings of the Natives' Association is genuine and how much "borak". <i>(Apr 23, 1904,NZ Observer,4</i>)

>  Notwithstanding all the "borak" that has been poked at the Premier, Richard is plainly in earnest on the subject of stimulating the birth rate. <i>(Aug 27, 1904,NZ Observer,2</i>)

>  Now I know <i>Heartland</i> isn't meant to be <i>Hard Copy</i> but a little poke of the borax wouldn't have hurt. <i>(Dec 11, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58</i>)

>  It is all very well for Opposition members to "poke borax" at this sort of thing. <i>(1945,NZ Parliamentary Debates,272/254</i>)

>  Then Alexander, who always seems to carry a packet of borax about with him, went on to say "he knew what a racing calendar was." <i>(Apr 30, 1904,NZ Free Lance,4</i>)

>  We've had the borax thrown at us, and I can't say it didn't have a detrimental effect on some of the players. <i>(Jul 26, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,27</i>)

>  My first thought was that the gentle shepherd was "taking a rose out of me," "poking borax," "playing a little game," and so forth. <i>(Sep 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,21</i>)

>  Was it necessary to poke borax from across the street? <i>(Apr 23, 1995,Sunday Star Times,A15</i>)

>  Infometrics' Gareth Morgan is a dab hand at poking the borax. <i>(Jul 31, 1992,National Business Review,10</i>)

>  We need the borax and the bite that the talent can produce. <i>(Jun 1, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64</i>)

>  <i>Bor&#769;.ak</i> (b&obreve.r&#769;.&adot.k), n. [Aboriginal.] Banter; ridicule; chaff. <i>[Colloq.] </i> <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2018</i>)

>  The Winton Borough Council has ... agreed to ... [do] its business in secret because the local `Herald' poked a bit of borah[sic] at a new and self-satisfied Alderman. <i>(Oct 7, 1905,NZ Truth,16/1/5</i>)

>  You mustn't joke, or borak poke/, At monarchs gone to hell. <i>(Jul 14, 1906,NZ Truth,56/1/8</i>)

>  <b>GRACE</b> <i>(1914,Tale of a Timber Town,88</i>) [NOTES: [see quot Chiack)]

>  <i>borak n</i>. banter, chaff.- to poke borak at, to make fun of [Abor.] <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,2</i>)

>  <b>MARKS</b> As soon as the boss left the room (always an opportunity for us to `poke borak' at one another) ... <i>(1934,Memories (Mainly Merry),60</i>)

>  <i>borak n</i>. banter, chaff, fun at another's expense, to poke borak at, to poke borak at, to ridicule [Abo]. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),611</i>)

>  <i>borak ...n.</i> banter, chaff, fun at another's expense, <i>to poke borak at</i>, to ridicule [Abo]. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),4</i>)

>  <i>borak n.</i> (also <i>borax) NZ & Austral. colloq.</i> banter, ridicule; <i>poke borak at</i> make fun of. [Abor.] <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,80</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 55]]

>  <b>BENNETT</b> To `poke borax at' (to tease) comes from Australia, and contains a corruption of an Australian aboriginal word. <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90</i>)

## bord
 
 <i>n.</i> workings or areas driven into or off a main coal seam or at right-angles to the seam (so EDD Nhb, wYks) [???check].

>  Bords, or headings, are tunnels driven in the coal. ... lead off on both sides from the heading or main drive. <i>(1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,?2</i>)

>  ... both stentons and bords should be blinded so as to make the air full. <i>(Nov 10, 1911,Maoriland Worker,36/6/2</i>)

>  <b>DEVANNY</b> ... drives were broken off at right angles to [the dip heading] at distances of two chains apart ; thus forming pillars on either side of the dip, two chains square. These drives were called main levels. The bords were driven about two chains off the dip, and the `stenton' would be driven from the lower level to the one above. <i>(1928,Dawn Beloved,169</i>)

>  <b>BATTYE & EATKIN</b> <i>Bord</i> the mine was divided into several working areas, called <i>Bords. </i> <i>(1980,Shadow of the Valley,72</i>)



## bord and pillar
 
 <i>phr.</i>

>  The system of work [in the Grey coalfield] is mainly by bord and pillar, a small portion only of this coal having been worked by the longwall method. In the bord-and-pillar system the bords are 18ft. wide, and pillars 14 yards thick. The pillars are left intact until the boundary of a section is reached, when they are worked back. The roof has in [418] main proved good, enabling a large percentage of the pillar-coal to be won. <i>(1905,NZ Mining Handbook,417</i>)



## border
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [irrigation] to surround an area with ditches or dykes.

>  After a farmer has decided on the area to be bordered it should be ploughed and worked up. After bordering it should occasionally be worked up to keep down weeds, at the same time consolidating the land to produce the firm seed-bed so desirable for grass and clover seed. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33</i>)



## Border Leicester
 
 <i>n.</i> a breed of sheep bred for wool and meat.



## border-ditch
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a simplified form of border-dyking surface irrigation.

>  There are a number of methods [sic] of irrigating land, of which the following are the principal:- 1. Border dike. 2 Border ditch. 3. Contour. 4. Wild flooding. 5. Furrow. 6. Basin-check. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25</i>)

>  The Border Ditch method is used where the fall of the land is over 1 ft. per chain, and can be constructed direct on to pasture land without previously working and levelling it. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,26</i>)

>  <b>RIDDOLLS</b> Border-ditch Irrigation. Where the fall of the land is too steep or the surface is too irregular for using the border-dyke method, or where it is not too desired to plough up the pasture, ditches are constructed over the area to be irrigated and the water is caused to flood over from the ditches. These ditches are called border ditches ... <i>(1958,Farm Engineering,187</i>)

>  <b>RIDDOLLS</b> The border-ditch method is not as efficient as the border-dyke method in its use of water. [border ditch] <i>(1958,Farm Engineering,188</i>)



## border-dyke irrigation
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [used elsewhere but sign. in NZ farming] a type of surface irrigation commonly used on the Canterbury plains, in which a system of races and gates is used.

>  Border-dyke irrigation is the most economical method, but uses more water than other methods and requires large flow-rates. <i>(Dec 1976,NZ Journal of Agriculture,38</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> After borrowing a further $10,000, they went into a syndicate set up to develop a 400 ha (990 acre) dry land farm, in Canterbury, into border dyke irrigation. They put in up to 140 ha (345 acres) a year of border dykes ... <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,121</i>)

>  <b>RENNIE</b> Flood irrigation, commonly called border dyke irrigation is the system used. Once installed, border dyke irrigation costs little to run. <i>(1988,Agriculture in NZ,27</i>)

>  The farm has the advantages of good soils, borderdyke irrigation and medium rainfall. [border dike, border-dyke] <i>(Nov 25, 2000,Press, The,64</i>)



## border-dyke system
 
 <i>n.</i> an irrigation system (See [border-dyke irrigation](../B#border-dyke-irrigation))

>  Using a border-dyke system to partially flood his paddocks, Ted.. can irrigate 20-30 ha a day between September and April - as long as river flows hold up. <i>(Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/46</i>)

>  The border dike method is the most efficient in utilisation of water and saving of labour. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25</i>)

>  <b>RIDDOLLS</b> The advantages of the border-dyke system are the fair degree of uniformity attained in the application of water, the high irrigation efficiency attainable in a well-designed and carefully operated scheme, and the speed of the application. <i>(1958,Farm Engineering,188</i>)

(Dec. 26, 1752). [no etym given: cf. barrow sb3 1. a hill; a heap of stones. [gen. dial. Cum to Ken and Cor]; DARE barrow ditch Also, by folk-etym. borrow ditch; rarely barrow [EDD ref.] Cf bar ditch1 1927-1973: barrow pit Also by folk-etym. borrow pit Prob, from barrow a mound of earth; for folk-etym. see quot1950 ... 1 rarely burrow pit: a roadside drainage ditch. Chiefly West, esp. ## boshee
 
 <i>n.</i> (derogatory) a Maori

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> But the attitude of the settlers was not wholly a product of their environment. To a large extent their prejudice was imported with them. The Maori was called `nigger', `black', and in the <i>Auckland Examiner</i>, `Boshee' [subscript 44] by people who had never seen a slave. ## bot
 
 <i>n.</i> esp. a cold, the flu (esp. with coughing fits); catch, have the bot to become, feel unwell [ca1938 Havelock to have the bot 1953 14-15 M A2 Thames DHS 31 BOT, THE [sickness] [M7] -->1960 16C F B3 Marton D.H.S. 31 BOT, THE -->1960 17C M B6 St Bede's, Chch 31 BOT, THE BOT -->1984 16 M E89 Pakuranga Coll. 31 GOT THE BOT -->1984 17 M E97 Pakuranga Coll. 31 THE BOT -->1984 16-17 F E6 Pakuranga Coll. 31 BOT [F3M2] -->1984 16 F E9 Pakuranga Coll. 31 BOT, THE [F3]]

>  <b>BAKER</b> Emerging originally from children's slang to bulk quite considerably in a grown-up world is the serviceable term <i>bot</i>. Its origin seems to be medical, since in early uses <i>bot</i> is rendered as a germ, doubtless from bot-fly. [52] From this comes the phrase of greeting, <i>How are the bots biting?</i> By the 1920s a <i>bot</i> is being used extensively for a troublesome person, for a persistent borrower, a financial parasite. By 1925 the noun <i>bot</i> was translated to a verb, and as a result we have <i>to bot,</i> to borrow money, to impose on others, and <i>botting</i>, the practice. <i>To bot on</i> a person is widely used. An interesting extension to the term is to be found in Australia, in which country<i> to bite</i> is often the equivalent for <i>bot</i>. On the other hand <i>cold botting</i> is a straight-out request for food at house-doors. ... Of fairly recent development in New Zealand is the phrase<i> to have the bot</i>, to be sick or out of sorts, moody or disagreeable. par <i>(1941,NZ Slang,51</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Bot, have the</i>. To feel unwell: to be moody: querulous: NZ: since ca1930, B1941. Ex bot n2 (<i>Dict</i>) <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,997</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> And if you have a good rub down and wrap up warm after, nobody will catch the bot. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,144</i>)

>  After complaining of Scott-Base-like conditions at last week's Auckland club footie, old Loosehead has come down with a spot of the bot and his regular Sunday Star column will take a week's rest with the joker himself. <i>(Jul 20, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B10</i>)

>  <i>bot n. NZ & Austral. sl. 1. n</i>. scrounger, cadger; unspecified minor ailment (<i>have the bot). 2. v.i. bot on cadge from, impose on. [orig. = parasitic worm, f. LG] </i> <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,81</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 125]]



 
 <i>n.</i> short for bottle (of liquor)

>  `It's a grim show,' I said. `You can't have a victory on one bot of Canadian.' <i>(1945,Sixes & Sevens,7</i>)

>  You had a hell of a lot of laughs smuggling the booze in [to the Majestic Cabaret], especially when it was wartime ... Then you'd con the girls into hiding a couple of `bots' in the [?their] enormous stoals[sic] and stash the grog up the chimneys ... <i>(Jul 1984,Cosmo,56</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> to have the bot, (informal) to be ill; usu. as <i>the bot</i>; A vague feeling of unwellness in human beings; the mulligrubs: 1898 Alab.; a lung or bronchial disease, specifically positive tuberculosis

>  <b>MARY O'CONNOR</b> the bot; also bot ward, the isolation ward for tubercular patients <i>(1964,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: (Wairau Hospital) ca1912]

>  `Bot' is a rare example of medical slang, meaning a germ or a tubercular patient. <i>(Apr 4, 1938,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

>  <i>bot n.</i> annoying type of fly, hence a troublesome person, particularly a persistent borrower of money; <i>to have the bot</i>, to us;have tuberculosis; how are the bots biting? how are you? <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),4</i>)

>  <i>bot n.</i> annoying type of fly, hence a troublesome person, particularly a persistent borrower of money; <i>to have the bot</i>, to us;have tuberculosis; how are the bots biting? how are you? <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),4</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> Bot. See bot-fly. 2. A germ: New Zealand medical: from ca1928. Perhaps ex the bot(-fly), which, in horses, lays eggs that are said to penetrate into the animal when they hatch. 3. Hence, a tubercular patient: id: from ca1929. Cf <i>bots biting,</i> q.v. <i>bot-fly</i>. A troublesome, interfering person: Australian: C.20. In G.W. +, often abbr. to <i>bot. </i> <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,83</i>)

>  He had been feeling "a bit nauseous, hot and crabby" after taking antibiotics for "a bit of the bot." <i>(Nov 4, 1992,Evening Post,2</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> a smalltime financial parasite, a cadger, a bludger.

>  <b>BAKER</b> By the 1920s a <i>bot </i> is being used extensively for a troublesome person, for a persistent borrower, a financial parasite. By 1925 the noun <i>bot</i> was translated to a verb, and as a result we have <i>to bot,</i> to borrow money, to impose on others, and <i>botting,</i> the the practice. <i>To bot on</i> a person is widely used. <i>(1941,NZ Slang,52</i>)

>  <i>bot n</i>. annoying type of fly, hence a troublesome person, particularly a persistent borrower of money; <i>to have the bot</i>, to us;have tuberculosis;<i> how are the bots biting?</i> how are you? <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),4</i>)

>  <i>bot n. NZ & Austral. sl. 1. n</i>. scrounger, cadger; unspecified minor ailment <i>(have the bot). 2. v.i. bot on cadge from, impose on. [orig. = parasitic worm, f. LG] </i> <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,81</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 125]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>bot </i>a germ, originally in 1920s a TB patient, latterly a minor ailment, usually cold or flu; probably derived from the botfly, whose larvae feed beneath the skin, an afflicter of horses. - <i>to have the bot</i> to feel unwell or irritable. - <i>how're the bots biting? a humorous greeting. - <i>on the bot</i> to cadge. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,19</i>)

## bottlie
 
 <i>n.</i> a spherical, glass stopper of an old-fashioned patent soft-drink bottle used as a marble, cf bottle-o; clear glass marble. [ca1910 W.H.B. Orsman -->ca1938 Havelock]

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. ...When I first went to school, bottlies were good currency, being classed as two-ers, but usually sodawaters and black-bottlies counted as the equivalent of six-ers. ... (Petone, Wellington, 1913) <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,Yesterdays in Maoriland,288</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>bottlie</i> marble stopper from neck of aerated water bottle, prized by marble buffs. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,19</i>)

>  I could spin a top `overarm' and shoot alleys, glassies and bottlies with the best of the boys. <i>(1988,Through the Looking Glass,7</i>) [NOTES: (Dorothy Butler)]

>  Bottlies - the glass marble stoppers from the tops of bottles. These worked perfectly well but were not considered to be high class. <i>(1987,Alfredton,75</i>) [NOTES: Quote from c1935]

>  <b>BUTLER in GIFKIN</b> I could.. shoot alleys, glassies and bottlies with the best of the boys. <i>(1988,Through the Looking Glass,7</i>)

>  Marbles was another recreational pursuit... Silveries and bottlies being the most prized marbles. <i>(2008,NZ Memories,73/12</i>)

## bow
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <i>Bow</i> (1) The bows are the curved parts at the top of the handle of a pair of sheep shears. They give the shears their spring open after the shearer has made his blow. All shears are now made with double bows; but until about the 'seventies single bows were the only kind. (2) The iron that holds the yoke to a bullock's neck (see <i>bullocks</i>). ([1890- 1910]) <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>BURDON</b> The sheep they shore were not so well woolled on the belly and carried less wool on the points than they do now, so that fewer short blows were required to take off the trimmings; but the shears they used were one inch and a half shorter in the blade and, being joined by a single instead of a double bow, required a wrist of iron to drive them continuously throughout a summer's day. A piece of raw hide known as a knocker is now used to prevent the shears clashing when closed, but before this was introduced the clack and snap of steel meeting steel was a noise inseparable from any busy shearing shed. <i>(1938,High Country,84</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> So most of us stick to `the blades,' the big shining steel shears eight and a half inches long, with a double spring `bow' on the end to keep them apart. <i>(1951,High Country,26</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> <i>Bow</i>. The curved top of the handle of the shears which incorporates the spring. Until the late 1870s shears were made with only one bow and the extra tension made them more difficult to operate. Now all shears have double bows. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,95</i>)

>  <i>bow</i>: The curved handle top of hand shears. The grip is against the bows which causes the blades to spring open after each cut. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22</i>) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]



 
 <i>n.</i> an iron contrivance in the shape of a double bow which fitted to the underside of the necks of a pair of draught bullocks and was fastened to the yoke across the upper side of the pair's necks.

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> ... you would have only to buy another [bullock] plough and two yokes and bows. <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,261</i>)

>  The Working Bullocks, with Bows, Yokes, and Chains, can be warranted as most unexceptional, being in good condition, and perfectly quiet. <i>(Aug 2, 1851,Lyttelton Times,8</i>)

>  <b>W H S ROBERTS</b> I yoked up the bullocks. The bullock yoke was a square piece of white pine smoothed and hollowed out to fit the necks of the two bullocks, with holes for the iron bows which went round the neck and through the yoke, being fastened above with a key tied with a bit of greenhide; in the centre a bolt with a ring called `the start' passed through the yoke, to which the chain was fastened from the sledge. <i>(Sep 19, 1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42]

>  <b>BUTLER</b> In the small river Ashburton ... we had a little misunderstanding [105] with the bullocks; the leaders ... slewed sharply round, and tied themselves into an inextricable knot with the polars [sic], while the body bullocks, by a manoeuvre not unfrequent, shifted, or as it is technically termed, slipped, the yoke under their necks, and the bows over; ... <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,vii 104-105</i>) [NOTES: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year ch vii 104-105]

>  The iron that holds the yoke to the bullock's neck. <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (ca1890-1910) 1933 Sep 16 Acland Glossary Press 15 (2)]

>  [<i>T. novae-zelandiae</i>] It has been called the `bowing-bird' by the settlers, from its habit of bowing its body when approached. <i>(1872,TrNZI,5/127</i>) [NOTES: (Travers)]

>  ... a suitable piece of kauri ricker ... shaped at each end to receive the ends of the bows or loops by which the yokes were fastened to the bullocks' necks. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,182/3</i>) [NOTES: [ca1900]]

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> BOW: Term used for front of horse-drawn vehicle. <i>(1961,Friends in Chains,185</i>) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 185]

>  Bullocks were also driven in sledges (two or four bullocks). The iron iron which passed under the bullocks' necks to keep the yoke in place was called the<i> bow</i>. The <i>bow</i> was held to the yoke by a <i>yoke key</i> which passed through a hole in it. (C. [Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p.95, etc.) <i>(Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  They were returning [in a bullock dray] ... when a carelessly tied `key' that held the `bow' into the `yoke' dropped out and let one bullock free. <i>(1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,151,1988 ed.</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a curved spring at the top of each blade of a pair of handshears.

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> So most of us stick to 'the blades', the big shining steel shears 8 and a half inches long, with a double spring 'bow' on the end to keep them apart. <i>(1951,NZ High Country,26</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> bow: (i) curved spring at the top of each blade of a pair of hand shears. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,9</i>)

>  `A BOX OF BIRDS' Sir, - I am aware that idioms in any language are often difficult to analyse, but there is one phrase used in New Zealand which leaves me completely puzzled. It is the expression `a box of birds,' given in reply to the greeting `How are you?' and is evidently intended to mean a state of well-being. This appears to be so completely irrelevant that I would be pleased if any of your readers could elucidate, if that is possible. The term suggests to me something to be prepared for the dinner table, but I am willing to be corrected. - I am, etc. KIWIPOM. ? 1957 Evening Post (?p) [To feel like a `box of birds' is to feel happy and chirpy - Ed.] <i>(Dec 1957,Evening Post</i>) [NOTES: month guessed at; check]

## box up
 
 <i>v.</i> -

>  ... all the mercies we had to be thankful for ... possession of `tucker' galore, and ... (as the weather became worse) how we were safe on this side of the Godley and not boxed up in Scone Creek. <i>(1936,NZ Alpine Journal,6/23/228</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to mix different mobs, either intentionally or unintentionally.

>  If you heeded the facial eczema warning and boxed the ewes up, many farms could be 100 per cent certain of a severe salmonella outbreak. <i>(Sep 24, 1970,NZ Farmer,46</i>)

>  .. it is only during the tupping season that it will be necessary to keep the ewes separate .. The ewes can then be boxed up again, and run in convenient sized mobs. Before boxing them up, however ... <i>(Mar 1918,NZ Farmer,271</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> Not a single sheep [in three mobs] got boxed up. <i>(1990,Matawhero, Elsewhere and Other Things,70</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) boxing (See [box v](../B#box-v))

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Many a `box up' occurred while the drovers were arguing who had the `right of way' [for their mobs]. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,53</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a mixing of sheep from two or more mobs into one.

>  <b>HUTCHINSON</b> Silently, relying only on their instinct to 'head' sheep, they had worked through the night, keeping the escaping wethers under control, so averting the threatened box-up. <i>(1981,Hutchinsons of New Zealand, The,48</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Many a box up occurred while the drovers were arguing who had the right of way. <i>(1991,Off the Sheep's Back,53</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a mess up; state of confusion

>  <b>BAKER</b> When flocks are mixed they are said to be <i>boxed</i>, and from this peculiar use of the verb we have derived the term a <i>box-up</i>, a state of confusion, and <i>to be in a box</i>, to be in a confused state of mind. <i>(1941,NZ Slang,39</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>box up</i> state of confusion; eg `It's a total box up, nobody seems to know what his position is, or what he's s'posed to do.' ANZ. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,20</i>)

## boxing
 
 <i>n.</i> the inadvertent or purposeful mixing of drafts of farm animals (See [box v](../B#box-v))

>  <b>BARKER</b> [Shepherd speaks] He couldn't cross [his mob] over a river ... and never a week passes without his getting boxed. That's mixed-up ma'am. We calls it boxing when your sheep go and join another mob feeding close by, and you can't tell one from another except by the brand or the earmark. <i>(1872,Xmas Cake in Four Quarters, A,Chapter iii</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Fear of boxing was the origin of this custom of giving notice. [sc. of driving sheep through another's property: see sheep notice] <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,152</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Boxing - Sometimes different lots of sheep would fail to keep separate, and entanglement followed. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,84</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> technique of fighting used by deer of the same sex who are in dispute in a pecking order. [citation also includes verb to box]

>  <b>LENTLE & SAXTON</b> boxing ; technique of fighting used by deer of the same sex who are in dispute in a pecking order. Hinds often box one another. Stags do also, particularly when in velvet. Contestants rear up on their hind legs and approach each other with downward-kicking forelegs. <i>(1991,Red Deer in New Zealand,182</i>)

## boy
 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> a male servant or porter in early colonial NZ, and elsewhere; a Maori male (as a servant, porter, convert, attendant).

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> After breakfast our boys urged us to move on. ... we acordingly packed our baggage and by seven o'clock were all on the road. <i>(Nov 6, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,82,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> Our Settlement has been in an unsettled state for several days from the circumstance of my elder boy's taking a young female to wife who was designed for another person. <i>(May 14, 1829,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1829 May 14 C. Baker Jnl in 1986 Baker Never the Faint Hearted 57]

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> [a Maori servant or man] The boys preparing a <i>Wata,</i>a high stand for [245] native food, about 16ft. long and 10 wide, 16ft from the ground, to preserve it from the English rats which are now beginning to infest all parts of the land ... <i>(May 16, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,244,1961 ed.</i>)

 <i>v.</i> ca1945 As a totalisator or betting convenience, to pair horses in certain circumstances so that if either is placed a dividend is paid on both. The circumstances are these: a) horses beyond 18 in any race are paired (bracketted) with a number, and hence a horse, already given (e.g. in a race of 20 entries, the last numbers would be 17, 17a, 18, 18a); b) similarly, when entries are more than can be safely run at one time and the race must be run in two divisions, each horse in the first division is paired (bracketted) with each horse in the second; c) (formerly) horses of the same ownership (galloping) or of the same ownership and trainership (trotting and pacing), running in the same race were bracketted.



 
 <i>n.</i> to couple in a horse race for dividend payment purposes the horses of the same owner or trainer [(revise this definition use HNZD2) racing in the same race.]

## branks
 
 <i>n.</i> a kind of bridle or halter ?with a piece of wood on each side instead of leather joined to a halter.

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Mr. Andrew Liddell, who lived to be over a hundred, and who was a bullock-driver from the age of sixteen until he was twenty-two, had much to tell me of this adventurous portion of his long career, ... `You ask how the bullocks were attached to the vehicle, and as bullock-driving is now a lost art, I had better try and explain ... Very seldom was harness used, and then without winkers, and it was called branks. The pulling strain came on the bows, and a yoke joined two bows and went over each neck of a pair of bullocks. If there were five pairs, say, a chain ran from the yoke of the first pair to the yoke of the second pair, and another chain from the second to the third, and another chain from the third to the fourth. These chains were lighter between the first pairs and heavier as you got further back. The two rear bullocks were yoked to the pole of the dray or waggon. As there were no reins, the driving was all by commands and cracking the whip. The calls were `Get up' or `Gee up' to start, `Whoa' to stop, `Come here' to turn to left, and `Gee off' to turn right. If you came to a sharp corner, you would often say persuasively, `Way! Way! Come here.'' There is a general impression that bullocks could not be successfully driven without roaring oaths and curses at them, but this idea is a relic of early-day humour. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,42</i>)

Richmond)]



## bread and butter dog

## breadiebut
 
 <i>n.</i> bread and butter [ca1935]



## break
 
 <i>v.</i> of sheep

>  <b>SCOTT</b> I could just see his expression when the wonder-dog shot off after rabbits and all the sheep broke. <i>(1953,Breakfast at Six,144</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [re lambing]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> He made his name during his first day on the place by his masterly handling of a "break" of lambs. Only those who have had experience of dealing with "breaking" Merino lambs at tailing time can appreciate the test for man and dog. <i>Ibid.</i> p. 153.Break : Lamb-break:... Great care must be exercised, as a false move by man or dog will have the lambs, ever on their toes, stampeding or breaking. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,148</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [wild pigs] to escape from bailers and holders.

>  <b>SWAN</b> Further up the hill John heard Osgood start to bail. Within seconds the pig broke but Osgood quickly stopped it and resumed his bail. Once again though the pig broke and this time Osgood was not heard again. <i>(1992,Grunter Hunters, The,22</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stock,esp. lambs, being handled in a mob] to bolt.

>  <b>CHUDLEIGH</b> The sheep broke repeatedly before we could get them in. <i>(Oct 25, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,202</i>) [NOTES: (1950)]

>  Break - break away, usually of lambs. Both as a noun and a verb. <i>(Jan 13, 1934,Press, The  (Acland Glossary),13</i>)

>  <b>BLAKISTON</b> When lambs 'break' as this bolting is termed, they may run for miles before they stop ... <i>(1952,My Yesteryears,22</i>)



## break away
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stock] to bolt from a mob.

>  <b>CHUDLEIGH</b> Started after a mob of sheep that had broken away from the man that was keeping a boundary. <i>(Oct 6, 1864,Chudleigh Diary</i>) [NOTES: (1950)]

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> The wild brutes tried to break away in every direction. <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,135</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to break free from a herd or mob.

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> The wild brutes tried to break away in every direction, and ... poor C. would have stood a small chance ... if we had not been there to help him in forcing them into a small wattle yard near at hand; ... <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,135</i>)

>  Had dinner and started after a [147] mob of sheep that had broken away from the man that was keeping a boundary. <i>(Oct 6, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,146,1950 ed.</i>)



## break back
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stock in a mob] to rush in the opposite direction to which they are driven.

>  <b>CHUDLEIGH</b> A mob broke back when we where [sic] crossing a small stream and ran over two miles before we could turn them in. <i>(Oct 13, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,148</i>) [NOTES: (1950)]

>  <b>JONES</b> If a mob .. broke back .. the rest of us would have to wait while the shepherd on whose beat the sheep had broken back, went for them. <i>(1933,Autobiography of an Early Settler,59</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to run or dash in a reverse direction (of a mob of sheep)

>  A mob broke back when we where [sic] crossing a small stream and [we] ran over two miles before we could turn them. <i>(Oct 13, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,148,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>JONES</b> If a mob ... broke back, ... the rest of us would have to wait while the shepherd on whose beat the sheep had broken back, went for them. <i>(1933,Autobiography,59</i>)



## break camp
 
 <i>phr.</i> (of sheep) to move from a camping ground

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> Got up fron the ground by daybreak and let the sheep break camp at once. <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,211</i>)

>  <i>Break camp.</i> - Move away from camp; shift camp. Sheep which camp together are also said to `break camp' when they move off to feed at dawn. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p.113; Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement, p.54.) <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>BLAKISTON</b> Next morning we had to be up early to reach the tops before the merinos broke camp and started back for the country off which they had been mustered. ... At this stage, it was essential to get around the sheep before they broke camp, for to muster them again after they had begun to scatter would take many hours. <i>(1952,My Yesteryears,18</i>) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]



## break down
 
 <i>v.</i> tone down, cease

>  Break down the swearing... The padre doesn't like it. <i>(Mar 15, 1943,NZEF Times,II/90 : 6</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Break down</i>. v To make lighter: 20C. NZ C. -2. See n2. <i>(1938,Dictionary of Slang,91</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to take the first cuts off a log to make it into a manageable size for sawing into timber (See [breaking-down saw](../B#breaking-down-saw))

>  In the south, rough tramways are laid down in the bush, and the logs hauled on low carriages to the mills by horse- or bullock-teams. here the great round baulks of timber are `broken down' being cut lengthwise (by saws moving up and down vertically) into `flitches', which are passed over to the circular-saws to be ripped into boards and scantling. <i>(1892,NZ Official Handbook,158</i>)



## break feeding
 
 <i>n.</i> the rationing of feed to stock by a temporary fence (usually electric), moved at frequent intervals (See [cf. break n](../B#break-n))

>  Break feeding: Feed is rationed by use of a temporary fence (usually electric) moved at frequent intervals. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,15</i>)

>  ... break-feeding of stock ... <i>(Jun 26, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: Farm and Rural reporter]

## break fence
 
 <i>n.</i> [Check meaning: ?f. break(away) of sheep - i.e. to stop breaks; or is the reference to break off difficult or dangerous places like steep faces or gullies [(farming)]

>  <b>McLEOD</b> This was the repair of a `break fence' crossing a leading spur above the bush. <i>(1959,Tall Tussock,37</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Most of the paddock fences were renewed and attention was then directed to the hill; numerous `break' fences (short lengths of two or three barbs spanning gullies or running from existing fences up steep faces and into bluffs) were put in at strategic spots ... <i>(1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,199</i>)



## break in
 
 <i>v.</i> [Is this the sense here; or is the reference to the topography of the land.]

>  <b>FEATON</b> The fore-ground is open fern land, partially broken and intersected by a fresh-water stream and one or two shallow gullies. <i>(1879,Waikato War,56</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to train to be milked

>  <b>FITTON</b> ... milch cows, and heifers ready to be broken in for milking. [fn] A friend tells me the expression `breaking in' requires explanation. ... A young cow [allowed to run wild] when first milked is generally `baled up', that is, her head is secured between upright posts so that she can raise or lower it, but cannot turn round to use her horns. ... A pint or less of milk is considered a satisfactory result of the first attempt to milk an `unbroken heifer'. When a cow has submitted to this process a few times without much struggling, she is considered to be `well broken in to milk'. <i>Ibid.</i> 242 A well broken cow for milking generally sells for nearly [pounds]20. <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),218 and fn</i>)

>  <b>WIERZBICKA</b> They put the cow into the bail today. She seems ... uncommonly quiet for a cow that had not been broken in. <i>(1973,Wilson Family,91</i>) [NOTES: 1874 J.G.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 191]



 
 <i>v.</i> to clear and prepare virgin land for cultivation (See [cf. break up](../B#break-up))

>  Jim and Rose Henare set out to break in a farm at Motatau that people said would never pay its way. <i>(Aug 11, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29</i>)

>  <b>FITTON</b> Considering the facility of breaking in land here, ... the clearing and burning off for the entry of the plough varying from ten to twenty shillings per acre ... <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),99</i>)

>  <b>WALLACE</b> <i>(1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,1/24</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> The fact is my dear Mrs. Ashwin, I am supposed to be here for the purpose of gaining `colonial experience,' as it is called. I am supposed to be ... receiving daily lessons in the rougher and more laborious branches of colonisation - here, where men are hourly engaged in breaking-in the wilderness, and all that sort of thing. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,222</i>) [NOTES: [?transf.]]

>  Imperceptibly, farming had progressed from a developmental phase when a high proportion of labour was utilized in `breaking in' new land ... <i>(1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,24/205A</i>)

>  The place is getting a good clean up, more bush being broken in. <i>(Jan 5, 1929,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/168,1986 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

>  <b>VAILE</b> I was breaking in some country about two and a half miles from the homestead. <i>(1939,Pioneering the Pumice,99</i>)

>  <i>(Feb 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,141/1</i>)

>  <b>BACON</b> It isn't far to where they'll be breaking in this land you've heard so much about. <i>(1963,In the Sticks,87</i>)

>  <b>HUNT</b> But there were no cattle coming up to listen. ... They'd been in there fern crushing, hundreds of acres of bracken. Men'd just walked off that land in the slump but those cattle were breaking it all in again. <i>(1981,Speaking a Silence,46</i>)

>  <i>break in ... 5. Austral.</i> to bring new land under cultivation. <i>~ n. break-in. </i> <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,133</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 86; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 59]]

>  <b>REES</b> Breaking in country means clearing it, doesn't it? <i>(1927,Life's What You Make It,118</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to tame or develop [land] into pasture from bush or wasteland.

>  <b>WALLACE</b> Of the fern country, that upon a limestone formation is the best and least expensive to break in. <i>(1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,230</i>)

>  The land is nearly all broken in, fenced and in grass. <i>(Feb 1894,NZ Farmer,64</i>)

>  The best routine for a settler breaking in pumice land is to sow a limited area in permanent grass ... <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture</i>)

>  With two six-horse teams he worked for 12 years breaking the land in from tall tea-tree and flax. <i>(1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,18</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> For nine years he has been breaking in the scrub country. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,54</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. some years ago an area of about 3,000 acres at the Ngamatea homestead was broken in and sown down ... <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,151</i>)

>  The farm is 150 acres but 25 are steep river bank and are not really usable although they are clearing and breaking in five of these which seem to have some potential. <i>(Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,28</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> break in or bring in: to clear land of its orginal flora, cultivate it, and sow it down with something more productive such as a pasture of exotic grasses. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,10</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i>

>  <i>Sheep dog</i>.- Dog to work sheep; <i>collie</i> (q.v.).<i> S.ds</i>. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called <i>heading ds.</i> (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to <i>lead</i> (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to <i>huntaway</i> and are called<i> htwys</i> (q.v.). Some dogs will both <i>hd.</i> and <i>htwy</i> and are called <i>handy ds</i>. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special <i>slewing d</i>., but a well-trained,<i> hdg.</i> dog or <i>htwy</i>. will usually <i>slew</i> (q.v.). (C.) <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> a bullock to harness

>  McD and Edwardes brought home young bullock to break in. <i>(Feb 5, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  I broke in young bullocks for working. <i>(1882,TrNZI,14/131</i>)

<b>2</b> <i>exclam.</i> go easy [1940s]



## break out
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to tame [land] into pasture from scrub or bush.

 <i>v.</i> [[Should this go in as an hist. use in NZ; or is it merely a common use of OED2 `disband' etc.]]

 <i>n.</i> ?washout; ?landslip; a piece of land washed out by a stream or river in flood. -

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [droving or shepherding] a break in a mob of sheep or cattle.

## broomie
 
 <i>n.</i> a worker who sweeps the shearing board clean during shearing (also called sweepo).

>  <b>BOWEN</b> This is why a lot of tally pens and yards holding freshly-crutched sheep present the appearance of a fall of snow, and very often shearers are blamed for not making clean blows when it is the fault of the `Broomie'. <i>Ibid.</i> 155 BROOMIE. The broom hand on the board. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,65</i>)

>  <i>Broomie</i>. A sweeper on the shearing board. <i>(Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15</i>) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing Gloss)]

>  <i>BROOMIE</i>: The sweeper on the shearing board. <i>(Sep 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20</i>)

>  <i>Broomie:</i> Person who sweeps the shearing board clean during shearing (also called sweepo). <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53</i>)

>  <i>broomie n. NZ & Austral. colloq.</i> person who sweeps floor in shearing shed. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,90</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <i>broomie</i>: A shedhand who uses a broom. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/22</i>) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

>  <i>Broomie</i>.- A boy who keeps the board swept of locks, etc., at shearing. (C.)[c1890-1910] <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  At shearing time about 55 men were employed in the shed; 28 to 30 shearers, 2 penners-up, 4 pickers-up, 2 broomies, 6 rollers, 1 classer, 1 fleece carrier, 4 piece sorters, 3 pressers, 1 bale brander, 1 butcher and brander. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,208,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MEEK</b> BROOMIE: A shed hand who sweeps the board. <i>(1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a person who works on the broom in a woolshed, sweeping the shearing board clean between sheep being shorn. (See [sweepo; rousie](../S#sweepo;-rousie))

>  Broomie, a boy who keeps the board swept of locks, etc at shearing. <i>(Sep 16, 1933,Press, The  (Acland Glossary),15</i>)

>  <b>MEEK</b> It seemed a wrench to leave the crowd, to wear a broomie's crown .. as shearer, roller, picker-up and broomie all in one. <i>(1952,Station Days in Maoriland,9</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> As in the Lagoon Hill shed the fleecies and broomies take turns about doing the bottom end ... <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,210</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> In the smaller sheds he [the fleece-o] may also act as a broomie. If so, he will enjoy a lower social status in the shed, for a broomie sometimes acts as penner-up. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,31</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> Broomie: Person who sweeps the shearing board clean during shearing (also called sweepo) <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,53</i>)

## brown
 
 <i>n.</i> anus

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> The concrete truck driver ... informed us that a woman had thirty-two muscles and nerves in her bottom ... every time he saw us he would yell `Rember [sic] what I told you Tim - whack her up the brown!' <i>(1971,Bullshit and Jellybeans,45</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a situation or mood unpleasing or unpleasant. [1984 17 M E103 Pakuranga Coll. 5 WHAT A BROWN [indicating annoyance]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>brown</i> in phr. <i>do a brown</i> shy or sulky or ashamed; eg `What's wrong with Jill?' `Nothin', Miss. She does a brown for no reason, eh.' <i>[Alison Gray]</i> <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,21</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants and animals, see beech, birch, bittern, creeper; daisy, mountain; dogfish, duck; fern, hypolepsis; grass, mountain poa; kiwi linnet, lizard(tree), mudfish, parrot, pine, robin, shark, teal, trout, tussock.



 
 <i>n.</i> a penny, a copper coin [also brownie c1950s p.c. G.J.Griffiths notes: a copper coin; Aust; used very occasionally in NZ in my hearing - `toss him a brown' - and that was some years ago] (See [also brownie](../A#also-brownie))

>  <b>THATCHER</b> And said they scorned to earn a brown;/ <i>Ibid.</i> 18 There are lots of little swindles/ In all New Zealand towns,/ Got up by folks for easing you/ Of your superfluous browns;/ <i>(1864,Songs of the War,10</i>)

>  You can't turn an honest brown (sc. penny) anyhow. <i>(1896,Tom Bracken's Annual,41</i>) [NOTES: [check quotation]]

>  <b>BENNETT</b> In New Zealand Slang a penny is a <i>brown. </i> <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,91</i>)

>  <b>SOLJAK</b> Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... <i>brown</i>: penny <i>(1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115</i>)

>  <b>HARGREAVES</b> Half penny [:] half copper, brown, magpie, bawbee <i>(1972,From Beads to Banknotes,151</i>)

>  For the penny nicknames used were<i> copper </i>and <i>brown</i> (sometimes<i> Brownie</i>), while the halfpenny was called a <i>half-copper</i> a <i>mag</i>, or a <i>rap. </i> <i>(Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,16</i>)

## brown duck
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Elasmonetta chlorotis</i>, a scarce NZ wild duck [aka brown teal, see]

## brown skink
 
 <i>n.</i> a well camouflaged skink which lives in damp habitats in the lower North Island and the northern tip of the South Island; a sunbasker but secretive. [<i>Oligosoma zelandicum</i>, previously <i>Leiolopisma zelandicum</i>]

>  At first glance the food mass in the weasel's stomach appeared blackish with numerous tiny yellow flecks. This proved to be the remains of a juvenile Whitaker's skink, which made up about 70% of the stomach contents. The rest of the stomach's contents were comprised of the remains of a juvenile brown skink Leiolopisma zelandicum and three tiny invertebrates (a spider, an isopod and a fly) that may have come from the skinks' stomachs. <i>(1997,Internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn146.pdf 1997 Department of Conservation, P.O. Box 10-420, Wellington, New Zealand. Reference to material in this report should be cited thus: Miskelly, C.M., 1997. Whitaker's skink Cyclodina whitakeri eaten by a weasel Mustela nivalis. Conservation Advisory Science Notes No. 146, Department of Conservation, Wellington.]

>  We carried out captive-based behavioural comparisons between striped skinks and the common terrestrial brown skink (Oligosoma zelandicum). Brown skinks are of similar mass to striped skinks and overlap in geographic range and habitat, but are easily captured by hand and pitfall trapping in the wild. <i>(2004,Internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: New Zealand Journal of Ecology (2004) 28(2): 267-278 (C)New Zealand Ecological Society http://www.nzes.org.nz/nzje/abstract.php?volume_issue=j28_2&pdf_filename=NZJEcol28_2_267.pdf]

>  Since then four other species of skinks and geckos have been re-introduced to the island, the brown skink has been re-discovered and the numbers of gold stripe gecko and the equally threatened MacGregors skink were thought to have grown markedly. <i>(Dec 31, 2007,Internet - see Notes,3</i>) [NOTES: http://www.manaisland.org.nz/Newsletter35.PDF Annual Report for the AGM of Friends of Mana Island Inc (FOMI) for year ending 31 December 2007]

>  Brown skinks are now present in the Taranaki area and the western half of the southern North Island, on Kapiti Island, Mana Island .. and possibly on islands in Wellington Harbour. Brown skinks are also found in the northern and north-western South Island. Brown skinks frequently co-exist with common skinks .. and at a few localities with spotted skinks. Brown, common, spotted and speckled skinks co-exist in Marlborough Sounds on Stephens Island/Takapourewa and are likely to have once done so in the Wellington area ... <i>(2002,Internet - see Notes,11</i>) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/TSRP48.pdf North Island Oligosoma spp. skink recovery plan 2002-2012]

 <i>adj.</i>

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> the violent bucking of horses

>  <b>W H S ROBERTS</b> BUCKJUMPING [title] ... August 23, 1856. I mounted my good mare `Lassie,' with the intention of leading the two packed horses, when to my astonishment her ladyship started buckjumping, and after a long fight, finding she could not throw me, suddenly stood on her hind legs and fell over backwards. ... Buckjumping is a horrid vice, although it is a very amusing performance - to the spectator. The horse tries to roll itself up into a ball, with all four feet close together, head down as near the ground as possible between the forelegs, tail well down, back stuck up like the hump of a camel when in good condition. Attitude is everything. Then commences the performance. With an active spring and rather a forward motion up you go in the air, and down again with a jerk, then up and down like an india-rubber ball, occasionally varying the action by jumping forward and kicking out behind with both legs at once, returning to the oval position as rapidly as possible, then turning round like a teetotum at lightning speed. <i>(Aug 23, 1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Aug 23 W.H.S. <b>3</b> <i>n.</i>

This small evergreen tree, known by the native names of `Kowhiwhi' and `Maupariki', abounds on the eastern coasts of both Islands. ... Even as firewood it is despised, and bears the all too suggestive name of `Bucket of Water Wood', so little is it calculated by its combustive qualities to enliven the domestic hearth. <i>(1889,Art Album NZ Flora,32</i>)

## buckjump
 
 <i>n.</i> a buck of a horse.

>  <b>CHARLES</b> I used to go to every show/ Where they ran a buck-jump ring./ The wildest moke I thought a joke,/ I really had a fling/ <i>Ibid.</i> 18 A bullock-busting sideshowman/ Who knew the buck-jump stunts./ <i>(1981,Black Billy Tea,9</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to buck

>  <b>McKENZIE</b> Saddled my horse. She got away and buckjumped fearfully. <i>(1853,Journal,45</i>) [NOTES: 1853 Journal in 1893 Capt F.W. Mackenzie (Journal) Overland from Auckland in 1853 45]

>  I had scarcely remounted my horse before the animal began to buck-jump most violently ... <i>(1873,TrNZI,5/99</i>)

>  <b>BOOTH</b> The faculty of buckjumping is ... almost confined to Australian horses...it was a fact that eight out of every ten horses could and did buckjump, and with many of them the vice was incurable. <i>(1912,Five Years in NZ,50</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i>

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Perhaps the most recurrent and universal of rough games in the early period was <i>Cockfighting</i> (K-78). This was a free-for-all contest in which a smaller boy mounted on the back of a bigger boy and the two endeavored [sic] to dislodge all other riders by pushing or [202] pulling them over. ... Sometimes the game was known as a Piggy-back Contest or as Pulling Off. `One trick of the game was to "buck-jump" your rider, which consisted in jerking your elbows so that the rider was lifted over your head' (Naseby, Otago, 1905). <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,201</i>)



## buckjumper
 
 <i>n.</i> a horse which bucks violently

>  Clarke's horses are notorious buck-jumpers. <i>(1866,Canterbury Rhymes,18[fn]</i>)

>  <b>BOOTH</b> According to bush custom it was usual to dub all fresh arrivals 'new chums' until they had satisfactorily passed certain ordeals in bush life. >  <b>AYSON</b> Thomas soon realized that riding a buckjumper meant more than just sticking to the saddle and allowing oneself to be jerked up, down, here, there and everywhere. <i>(1937,Thomas,66</i>)

## buckley

## Buckley's
 
 <i>n.</i> short for Buckley's chance, little or no chance at all, a forlorn hope

>  The [Boxing] Association is making a `dead set' against the professional talent which has come into such prominence in Wellington of late, and the stoushers' chance of fixing up `shleinter goes' is `Buckley's'. <i>(Jul 28, 1906,NZ Truth,58/3/3</i>)

>  To oust Hereditary Ward's Government, Massey will have to hold all the seats that he has got and capture fifteen more. He has got two chances of doing this - his own and Buckleys. <i>(Aug 11, 1911,Maoriland Worker,23/8/2</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> <i>Buckley's chance</i> or<i> Buckley's</i>. No chance whatever. Does anyone know who Buckley was? <i>(1951,Early Canterbury Runs,358</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>Buckley's </i>short for <i>Buckley's chance</i>, which is no chance; after mid-C19 Australian outlaw who was reckoned to have no chance of escape, though other explanations exist; eg `We haven't a Buckley's of winning the cup now Honk's had to drop out of the team.' ANZ. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,22</i>)



## Buckley's chance
 
 <i>n.</i> no chance

>  <i>Buckley's chance, Buckley's</i>.-No chance whatever. Does anyone know who Buckley was? <i>(Jan 13, 1934,Press, The,13</i>) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> We've Buckley's Chance of getting there first. <i>(1944,Troop Target,38</i>)

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> `You haven't got Buckley's chance.' (Buckley's chance was a colloquialism for an impossible hazard.) <i>(1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,140</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> No possibility. .`You've got Buckley's chance of doing that - it's an impossible task.' `You'll have your own and Buckley's chance of doing this.' (i.e. no chance) <i>Ibid.<i>1118 The odds against you are far too heavy. .;`Carrying heavy loads and setting out on that track at this time of the year, they got their own and Buckley's chance of getting as much as half way. They'll never be able to do it.' <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],465</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> I added a little more for good measure. `Borrower's Buckley's. Borrower's Buckley's.' I amplified that and made it read, `Borrower has Buckley's chance. Lender has a bad attack of memory.' <i>(1965,Rhetoric at the Red Dawn,95</i>)

>  <i>Buckley's chance ... (Phr.)</i> one chance in a million, no chance at all. Derived from name of convict who escaped into bush and survived all hazards. Used commonly in <i>haven't Buckley's chance.</i> <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),4</i>)

>  <i>Buckley's chance n. Austral. sl.</i> no chance at all. Often shortened to Buckley's. [C19: <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,141</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 91; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 62]]

>  <b>CLAPPERTON</b> I don't suppose for a moment I have Buckley's chance. <i>(1936,Lauder Brothers,10</i>)

>  <i>Buckley's chance.</i>-A correspondent from Kirwee, the same as explained <i>Jimmy Woodser</i> for me, writes that Buckley was one of the earliest convicts (perhaps the first) to escape from Botany Bay and take to the bush. It was then thought impossible to do this and live, as apart from the problem of food and water, the blacks were numerous and savage and reported to be cannibals. Extensive search was made, but no trace was found of Buckley; and it was concluded that the natives had got him. Any other convict who talked of escaping was invariably told that he would have `Buckley's chance' - hence the saying. However, many years afterwards Buckley was found to be still living. He had managed to make friends with a small band of natives who were moving to a remote part of the country, married one of their gins, and lived their life. The convict system had by that time been abolished, so the Government granted him a free pardon. <i>(Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

 <i>exclam.</i> In various forms and expressions it is as widely used in NZ as elsewhere, and not popularly regarded as an obscene, nor even by many a coarse, word. Often used familiarly or friendly-like, but not as often in this sense as `(old) bastard'; cf OED: and OEDS In low language: A coarse term of abuse or insult: simply `chap; customer; fellow' (cf Baggage) Leic Gloss 1881 `this little bugger'; see esp. P: for various forms, and an interesting note; some expressions which are not (or not well) attested elsewhere follow. There is no claim that they are exclusively, in even predominantly, New Zealand English. ## bulkie
 
 <i>n.</i> shortened form of "bulk tonnage operator" [King (24/3/1999) says bulk tonnage operators were firms which developed from the 1960 in reaction to the then regulations limiting road competition with rail. These firms consolidated small lots of goods into wagon lot, thus creating "bulk" goods (from the Railways perspective) out of much smaller units. Their workers did not in fact "load bulk goods" - it was the result of their working that the goods became "bulk". Such firms still exist; their current formal name is "freight forwarders" although one hears bulk tonnage operatore or "BTO" occasionally. Examples include Mainfreight and Daily Freight... Given that the expanded name of "bulk tonnage operator" is some thirty years older than [your] example, I would be surprised if its contraction is not also somewhere recorded earlier than 1991.]

It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied.  <i>n.</i> a freshwater fish (?Morris <i>Eleotris gobioides</i>); ?bull-trout; ?bully @n; ?cockabully.

>  There are only three fish in the River Avon, sufficiently common to justify the supposition that either of them may be the adult form of the Whitebait; these are the Bull-head, the Silver-fish, and the Smelt. The name of Smelt is applied indiscriminately to the two latter fish, we will ... retain the trivial name of Silver-fish as a distinction. We may first dismiss the Bull-head ... It is an Acanthopterygious fish ... Head, large, one third of the length of the body ... [86] The Silver-fish again belongs to the <i>Malacopterygii abdominales</i>, or fishes having soft fin rays, with the ventral fins placed below the abdomen. ... We now come to the ... fish ...called, by boys, the Smelt; but why a Smelt, I know not. ... the Smelt is a Galaxia ... <i>(1875,TrNZI,2/85</i>) [NOTES: (Powell)-]

>  <b>NATUSCH</b> The very common and widely distributed broad-headed or upland bully is <i>Philypnodon breviceps</i> ..., which probably inspired the original name of `bull-head', later shortened to `bully' and applied to the whole lot. <i>(1967,Animals of NZ, The,228</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> BULLEY Probably our most common freshwater fish the Bulley is also known as the Bullehead [sic] and is a basic staple diet of our trout. ... Several varieties of Bulley exist in New Zealand including the Blue-gilled, Common, Hutton's, Large and Upland varieties. <i>Ibid.</i> 28 BULLHEAD: <i>see Bulley </i> <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,24</i>)

>  <b>HUTTON</b> 45. ELEOTRIS GOBIOIDES. C. and V. Bull-head. <i>(1872,Fishes,29</i>)

>  <b>SHERRIN</b> BULLHEAD (<i>Eleotris gobioides</i> ). <i>Ibid.</i> 302 <i>Eleotris gobioides</i> C. and V. Bull-head, or Hawai <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,129</i>)

>  Several varieties of smelt (<i>Retropinna</i>) called by the Natives `inanga', ...; bullheads of different sorts, and a slimy fish the `kokopu' (<i>Galaxias fasciatus</i>) the young of which are supposed to be the New Zealand `whitebait' are widely distributed ... <i>(1894,NZ Official Yearbook,431</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Bull-head </i>... (2) a fresh water fish of New Zealand, <i>Eleotris gobioides</i> , Cuv. and Val., family <i>Gobiidae.</i> see <i>Bighead. </i> <i>(1898,Austral English,63</i>)

>  <b>DRUMMOND & HUTTON</b> The bully, or bull-head, and the kokopu, or native trout, live entirely in fresh water. <i>(1902,Nature in NZ,74</i>)

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> BULLEY (TOITOI) <i>Gobiomorphus gobioides</i> (Cuv. and Val.) The bulley is one of the most abundant of our native freshwater fish. ...The Bulley, or Bullhead as it is known in some parts, forms an important food for the introduced Trout throughout New Zealand. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,318</i>)

>  <i>bull-head n</i>. small Tasmanian and S. Australian shark; New Zealand freshwater fish. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),612</i>)

>  <i>bull-head n.</i> small Tasmanian and S. Australian shark; N.Z. freshwater fish. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5</i>)

## bullock dray
 
 <i>n.</i> a usu. four-wheeled vehicle, with a pole rather than shafts, drawn by a team of bullocks; a rough two-wheeled cart to which bullocks were attached by neck-yokes and chains (see Kennaway <i>Crusts</i> illustration), (See [cf. bullock wagon](../B#bullock-wagon))

## bullock language
 
 <i>n.</i> the practical language of command used by bullock-drivers to bullocks.

>  A tall young man ... but he takes to a blue serge shirt and `Way! Woap!' with bullocks in a manner not to be enough commended. <i>(Dec 1, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/105</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> Nearly all the drivers used the same bullock language, giving the command always in the same words ... [180] <i>wo</i> `halt'; <i>back</i>; come here; [183] <i>gee</i>; hoit. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,188</i>) [NOTES: [D.J. McLeod]]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [1889 (but still referred to in a non-historical, non-obsolescent way in Truth]

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> If the English sailors have acquired a not undeserved reputation for their curses, surely the New Zealand bullock-drivers must be reckoned superior to them in this accomplishment, for such an assortment of fantastic oaths from all kingdoms of Nature, Heaven and Hell I have never heard before from mortal lips. Astounded I listened to this blue-eyed son of Albion and was at last impelled to ask him why he cursed so horribly; it could serve no purpose and only made the beast more stubborn. `You don't understand, Sir,' the young man answered. `I'm only speaking the bullock language. The animal certainly wouldn't understand or obey me if I spoke to him as I would to my horse. The bullock has been brought up to carry in this way, and if I want to get on fast, I've got to talk to him like this.' To this argument advanced by the driver with a good-natured smile I naturally could find no reply. I refer it to the linguists to enrol this new language in the appropriate family of dialects. <i>(1948,Julius Von Haast,36</i>) [NOTES: [c1860 <i>Weiner Zeitung</i> (Vienna) Nos 57-65 in German] in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 36]

>  <b>HART</b> Bullock drivers are seldom choice in their language under the most favourable circumstances, but to drive a team with a load of firewood ..., from Papanui to Christchurch, was a work of so much difficulty, that the flow of bullock language was more than ordinarily profuse [March 1852]. <i>(1886,Stray Leaves,27</i>)
