## bullock whip
 
 <i>n.</i> [also bullocky whip (1960 below)]

>  <b>ROBERTS</b> The whip was rawhide plaited sinnet, about six feet long, thick at the upper end, where it was fastened to a handle as long as itself, but tapering nearly to a point, to which was attached a narrow strip of rawhide, called `the fall,' finishing off with a twisted `cracker' made of `weetau' or dressed flax in [43] place of whipcord, and was a powerful flagellator in the hands of an experienced `bullock puncher.' <i>(Sep 19, 1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43]

>  <i>Bullock whip</i>.- Whip used by bullock driver. It was made with a very long handle (perhaps eight feet) and a long lash. `Come here' and `gee back' were the words the driver used to turn the bullocks left and right, accompanied by a crack of the whip on the opposite side. (C.) <i>(Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> In driving bullocks the best bullock-whips were made from the skins of plump wild sows - these skins pleated [sic: ?plaited] well and lasted well. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,154</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> The art of cracking a `bullock-whip.' <i>(1940,Te Waimate,139</i>) [NOTES: [Reference 1870s-80s]]

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> `Bullocky' whips were not so long in the leather as stockwhips, but had very long, flexible handles, ... <i>(1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,142</i>)

>  <b>BARRY</b> This necessitated much expert use of the bullock whips, and not a little sulphurous language. <i>(1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,295</i>)



## bullock yard
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sturdily-built yard on large stations where wild bullocks and horses are mustered and broken.

>  <b>CHINN</b> With every rider now concentrating on his duties, we drove the wild horses towards the station bullock yards where several decoy horses were quietly feeding. <i>(1963,Packtrack to Highway,74</i>)



## bullock yoke
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>ROBERTS</b> I yoked up the bullocks. The bullock yoke was a square piece of white pine smoothed and hollowed out to fit the necks of the two bullocks, with holes for the iron bows which went round the neck and through the yoke, being fastened above with a key tied with a bit of greenhide; in the centre a bolt with a ring called `the start' passed through the yoke, to which the chain was fastened from the sledge. <i>(Sep 19, 1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42]



## bullock's kai
 
 <i>n.</i> raurekau, <i>Coprosma australis</i>

>  <b>KELLY</b> [The eels] are then covered with the broad leaves of the raurikau (or bullock's kai as it was known by the early settlers). <i>(1892,Journey Through Waitara,3</i>)



## bullock-chain
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> There was a rattle of the yokes and bullock-chain as the sledge tried to follow, ... <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,155</i>)



## bullock-drawn
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> ... now a generation has arisen to whom a bullock-drawn vehicle would be as strange as a Roman chariot. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,41</i>)



## bullock-driver
 
 <i>n.</i> one who drives a bullock-team; bullocky, bullock-puncher; also swear like a bullock driver.

>  <b>NESFIELD</b> It was before the days of buggies. At any rate, buggies or vehicles of any [118] sort were a rarity. The journey had to be accomplished in a bullock-dray. The station bullock-driver was, like all bullock-drivers, addicted to swearing. <i>(1881,Chequered Career,117</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> Bullock drivers who handle from 12 to 24 animals are also employed [in the sawmills]. ... A good `Bullocky' is like a good shepherd, his voice is seldom heard. ... The saying ... to `swear like a bullock driver', is common. <i>(1913,Country Work,40</i>)

>  ... she heard Bloomfield say that Price was a dirty bullock-driver. <i>(Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8/4/14</i>)

>  ... bullock-drivers, stockmen and carpenters. <i>(1846,McLean Papers,3/226</i>)

>  Thursday week we met to the number of ninety-five visitors, besides bullock drivers and some Maoris ... <i>(Dec 1, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/104,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

>  ... you have the Canterbury bullock-driver before you. <i>(Aug 22, 1857,Lyttelton Times,4</i>)

>  <b>PAUL</b> As soon as maybe after his arrival, [the new settler] engages himself as a shepherd, or bullock-driver, or hut-keeper at a station, ... makes a hut of sod or wattle and dab, ... encloses [his land] with ... a post and rail or ditch and bank fence. <i>(1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,27</i>)

>  McGill bullock driver ... All hands washing Humes ewes. <i>(Nov 29, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  Shennan's and Black's drays came with four bales wool. Bullock drivers taking a spell.' <i>(Oct 23, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1859 Oct 23 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 102]

>  <b>BUTLER</b> I am informed that the having faithfully learned the ingenuous arts, has so far mollified his morals that he is an exceedingly humane and judicious bullock-driver. <i>(Mar 24, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,4/50</i>)

>  Built grate in fireplace; put up bunk for bullock drivers. <i>(Jul 1, 1861,Puketoi Station Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1861 July 1 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 78]

>  <b>WALKER</b> (Central Otago) I am bullock driver, although it is hard work I prefer it to selling [in a store]. <i>(Jan 4, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)</i>)

>  We are a good party here, two shepherds and one bullock driver, gentlemen's sons, Tennant a cadet, he used to be at Harman's. <i>(Jun 20, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,93,1950 ed.</i>)

>  Thousands of sheep now depasture on that well-remembered corner of `the plains,' on those gently-swelling downs; ... we have the bleating of flocks, the bark of the colley[sic] as it rounds up its charge, the loud crack of the stockwhip, the hearty curse of the bullock driver delivered `ore rotundo'; ... <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/49</i>) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

>  <i>April</i>, 1861 - It is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the hut. I sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar. <i>(Apr 1861,Samuel Butler</i>) [NOTES: 1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87]

>  <i>Bullock-driver.</i> - Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was <i>bullocky, bullock-puncher</i> being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English) [c1962 One of the last bullock teams was driven (ceremonially) in Canterbury in 1962.] <i>(Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13</i>) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

>  <b>HEYWOOD</b> ... bullock-driver ... <i>(1863,Vacation Tour at the Antipodes, A,167</i>)

>  <b>VON TEMPSKY</b> On the Wairoa Road, Hewitt, a commissariat man, and a bullock driver by the name of Hamlyn were shot; ... <i>(1864,Memoranda,67</i>)

>  <b>THATCHER</b> If nice expressions you would learn,/ Colonial and new,/ Some bullock driver who is bogged,/ Is just the man for you: <i>(1875,NZ Songster,No.5/64</i>) [NOTES: The Leary]

>  <b>COTTLE</b> As long as a man earns what he wants on the square, ... we don't care a rap whether he is a Member of Parliament or So-and-so's bullock-driver. <i>(1891,Frank Melton's Luck,2</i>)



## bullock-driving
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>BUTLER</b> Every now and then he leaves his up country avocations. He then returns to his shepherding, cooking, bullock-driving ... <i>(Mar 24, 1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,49</i>) [NOTES: 1860 Mar 24 in 1863 Butler First Year iv/50]

>  <b>FARJEON</b> ... bullock-driving is scarcely a gentlemanly occupation... <i>(1866,Grif: a Story of Colonial Life,200</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> I took the job of hedge-trimming at first, and, after having finished this all round the station land, which consisted of some 1500 acres parcelled off into paddocks and fields, I began to pick up bullock-driving; ... <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,146</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Talking of bullock-driving reminds me of an incident that occurred the other day, and which rather amused me at the time. <i>(1881,Waitaruna,67</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> In 1860 he was bullock-driving for Low of Galloway .. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,186</i>)



## bullock-fence
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  I was once called upon to endeavour to obtain compensation from a native who had destroyed ... several hundred yards of stout bullock-fence. ... [29] ... rushing at the posts and rails, [he] vented his rage in chopping them to pieces with his axe. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,28</i>)



## bullock-plough
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> The first day was devoted to a ploughing match, for bullock-ploughs and for horse-ploughs. ... only eleven ploughs were on the ground, seven of which were bullock-teams ... <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,247</i>) [NOTES: [quoting 1847 Mar]]

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> A season or two later bullock ploughs were used ... <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,95</i>)



## bullock-puncher
 
 <i>n.</i> bullock-driver

>  <b>McMORRAN</b> Sometimes [the cattle] took charge of the town, and almost defied the efforts of the experience "bullock punchers" in charge to pen them in the yards provided for them. <i>(1900,Some Schools & Schoolmasters of Early Wellington,4</i>)

>  <b>W H S ROBERTS</b> The whip was rawhide plaited sinnet, about six feet long, thick at the upper end, where it was fastened to a handle as long as itself, but tapering nearly to a point, to which was attached a narrow strip of rawhide, called `the fall,' finishing off with a twisted `cracker' made of `weetau' or dressed flax in [43] place of whipcord, and was a powerful flagellator in the hands of an experienced `bullock puncher.' <i>(Sep 19, 1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43]

>  <b>INGLIS</b> The whare with its idle group of Crimean-shirted stockmen ... bullock-punchers, horse-breakers, fencers and general rouseabouts ... came back to us. <i>(1887,Our NZ Cousins,163</i>)

The expression is painfully true, as these men, who receive but very poor wages, and are recruited from the worst class, ill treat the poor animals by <i>punching</i> their sides with a pointed stick. <i>(1888,Antipodean Notes,170</i>)

>  <b>BROOKES</b> One of the bullock-punchers did his duty for him. <i>(1892,Frontier Life,27</i>)

>  A stream of adjectives one would hardly expect from a bullock-puncher. <i>(Jul 1, 1905,NZ Truth,0/2/3</i>)

>  <b>BOOTH</b> [In the accommodation house were] the villainous-looking 'lag' from 't'otherside', the bullock puncher, whose every alternate word was a profane oath, the stockrider, in his guernsey shirt and knee boots ... <i>(1912,Five Years in NZ,39</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> <i>(1920,Tutira</i>)

>  ~ Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was <i>bullocky, bullock-puncher</i> being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English) <i>(Sep 23, 1933,Press, The,13</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> The next day the snow had almost ceased so the `bullock-puncher' pushed his mob on as fast as conditions allowed. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,136</i>)

>  He said he received the earliest part of his training in public speaking as a "bullock puncher" in the district where the new pastor was born. <i>(Jun 12, 1890,Otago Witness,19</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a bullocky, bullock teamster or driver.

>  The town of Tapanui had now started, and the sawyers, bush-fellers and 'bullock-punchers' put up their temporary huts. <i>(1910,Tapanui Station,9</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> Owners and employees had worked shoulder to shoulder as .. bullock-punchers. <i>(1921,Tutira,382</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> bullocky, bullock puncher: by tradition the bullockies were considered the most fluent and imaginative swearers of all. [bullock puncher] <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,12</i>)

>  <b>ROBERTS</b> The whip..was a powerful flagellator in the hands of an experienced 'bullock-puncher.' <i>(Sep 19, 1856,Roberts Diary,43</i>) [NOTES: in Beattie (1947) Early Runholding in Otago]

 <i>n.</i> (See [cf. cow-banging etc](../C#cow-banging-etc))

I.I. weeding G.S.P. for mail - Seal up from Xchurch by mailman <i>(Nov 9, 1868,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point</i>)



## bullock-sledge
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>CLIFFORD</b> It would be easy to bring a bullock-sledge thus far. <i>(Apr 3, 1844,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Apr 3 Clifford to Wakefield in 1854 NZ Company Reports XVII 62]

## bullocker
 
 <i>n.</i> a bullock-driver (See [bullocky](../B#bullocky))

>  <b>ARTHUR</b> I once saw ... a bullocker who was working with his team. <i>(1894,Kangaroo and Kauri,91</i>)



## bullocking
 
 <i>n.</i> pertaining to the hauling etc., (of logs) by bullocks; [[ca1900] 1953 see vbl n]

>  <b>MASTERS</b> Sam hadn't long been here before making his way up to Hawke's Bay and becoming a professional bullock driver. Early in his bullocking career Sam and three other bullockies, ... were engaged in carting stores from Napier to Te Aute . <i>(1959,Tales of the Mails,115</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> vigorous, aggressive (esp. used of rugby union forwards); (of work generally) strenuous, arduous

>  <b>COWAN</b> In his crippled old age he was cheered now and again by a visit from some old friend of his bush-scouting, bush-clearing, bullocking days when one could march all day with a seventy-pound swag ... <i>(1935,Hero Stories of NZ,223</i>)

>  <b>GASKELL</b> Big bullocking bastards always mauling each other about. <i>(1947,Big Game,8</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Now the bullocking forward is king of the field and the game is to work close down the sideline and get into penalty range of the goalposts. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,80</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> Describes manual labour demanding mainly brute strength;`It's uphill and in gravel soil down there. To dig a trench would be hard, bullocking work; I wouldn't tackle it, anyway.' <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],129</i>)

>  <i>bullocking adj</i>. hard arduous, <i> i.e. bullocking work. </i> <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> barging through

>  Mansfield did some good work for Ponsonby, though still inclined to do a little 'bullocking'. <i>(Aug 30, 1890,NZ Observer,11</i>)

>  <b>FROBISHER</b> To use his own emphatic expression, he set his face against all such senseless "bullocking" [sc. in dancing] <i>(1893,Sketches of Gossipton,15</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> hauling, drawing, carting by a bullock team

>  <b>REED</b> While bullocking on a skidded road ... During bullocking operations in a portion of Puhipuhi, a nineteen foot log was being taken out on a catamaran. <i>(1853,Story of the Kauri, The</i>) [NOTES: [?1900] 1953 Reed Story of Kauri 186 (R. Ross)]



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> hard manual work; hard slogging; hard heavy work (See [cf. bullock v](../B#bullock-v))

>  <b>SATCHELL</b> `There's no bullocking attached to the job; all that'll be done for you.' <i>(1905,Toll of the Bush,37,1985 ed.</i>)



## bullocky
 
 <i>adj.</i> Like a bullock, violent or physically strong

>  <b>FANNING</b> Those were the times [20 years ago] of packs of [rugby] Goliaths, brawny but `bullocky'. <i>(1910,Players and Slayers,61</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Then the swine made a bullocky rush for home, though too late, the gate withstanding the impact. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,179,1954 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> an old word for the driver of a bullock team; also called bullock-puncher; bullock-driver

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> It was interesting to watch the leaders. The pair in front [sc. of the bullock team] were the leaders, they answered commands immediately, and the bullocky could get them to do all sorts of things. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,159</i>)

 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>McGILL</b> Bullrush involved as many of the school as possible, all at one end of the paddock, one person in the middle. At the cry of 'bullrush' we all ran and he had to catch one of us. It was also called Charlie across the water and kingaseeny <i>(1989,Kiwi Baby Boomers,41</i>)

>  In its simplest form bullrush involved one person standing in the middle of the field, then everyone else lined up on one side. The middle person would call someone's name (often in a rhyming way) into the middle. The object being of course to get past the middle to the other end of the field. If the runner was caught he or she joined the middle to call and catch more runners. Should a single runner get through there would be a bullrush, where everyone ran through the middle... These games had a thousand different names in earlier times: broken barley, king dick, punch king (where you had to punch the runner down!), goosey and so on... But if the runner gets across he calls out Bull Rush and everyone runs ...[sic]' `That's King-a-Sene!' said Ewan. `But we're only allowed to tag the player, we're not allowed to tackle him ...'[sic] ... `Do you play with the girls at all?' `Sometimes we play Drop the Handkerchief. >  <b>NATUSCH</b> BULLIES: Sub-order GOBIOIDEA Bullies are not the same as cockabullies. The family these rather severe-faced fishes belong to is widely distributed over moderately warm and even tropical countries, and reaches its southern most distribution in New Zealand. The bully family is called Gobiidae by some writers, Eleotridae by others. Bullies are spiny-rayed fishes with the paired ventral fins placed well foward; they have a genital papilla for passing out eggs or sperms; and the males look different from the females. ## bung-a-bung
 
 <i>v.</i> to kill [Philip Temple e-mailed on 2/7/2000 that "On 12 March 1843 in Nelson, Te Rangihaeata told Arthur Wakefield that he would 'bung-a-bung' him if he went to the Wairau... In the DNZE p. 103 you deal with the word 'bung' which can mean become useless, broken, ruined and 'bung out' meaning to die. But your earliest reference for these words is 1887 and the origin is given as Australian pidgin. I wonder what the earliest Australian reference is and whether Rangihaeata would have picked it up from this source so early. It seems that if he was using it, then it already had some currency in NZ by then." Harry Orsman replied that "I think (and I can recall this from the limits of an imperfect memory) that this use in early Maori-Pakeha New Zealand relations was a pidgin word from 'bang(a)bang' meaning to shoot. It wasn't related to the Aboriginal word usually spelled 'bung' 'dead', etc."]

## bureau manager
 
 <i>n.</i> the wharf labour system manager

>  The Lyttelton waterfront has been working under the bureau system of engaging labour for nine years now. ... `And,' the bureau manager said, `the men wouldn't like to go back to the old way again.' Under the old system, foremen of the various shipping companies stood on a small platform or block with the men awaiting employment before them and nominated those they required to work their own ships. The trouble with this `auction block' system, as it was called, was that each company tended to give preference to a certain group of men. It engaged the same men first all the time and employed others only when the preferred group were all at work. This meant very often the available work on the waterfront was not evenly shared; and that's what the bureau system tries to avoid. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,91</i>)



## bureau system
 
 <i>n.</i> a system for hiring wharf labour which replaced the auction block system.

The trouble with this `auction block' system, as it was called, was that each company tended to give preference to a certain group of men. It engaged the same men first all the time and employed others only when the preferred group were all at work.  <i>n.</i> (an instance of) clearing bush, scrub, unpalatable grass, etc. from the land by means of fire to improve pasture or to bring into cultivation by clearing logs or bush. (There seems a distict cleavage between early South Island and early NI usage, cf. burn v1. In the South Island `a burn' was a periodical burning off of old tussock to prepare the way for good crop of new grass. In 20th century usage, however, has been applied (e.g. in the Pelorus Sounds) to burning off noxious weeds, fern, scrub etc. to get a good growth of green feed (cf. match-farming). In the North Island, `a burn' was chiefly applied to clearing away (felled) bush by burning, a burning off (or over) of unwanted bush: that is, to clearing or bringing land into cultivation, not merely to improving pasture. burn off seems chiefly used in this North Island sense (cf bush-burning)) (See [also bush burn](../A#also-bush-burn))

>  <b>BARKER</b> [The wind] must not be <i>too</i> violent, or the flames will fly over the grass, just scorching it instead of making `a clean burn.' <i>(1867,Station Life in NZ,194,1870 ed.</i>)

>  The time for felling the bush in order to ensure a good burn in at [prob. typo.:<i> in</i> not deleted] the proper burning season - which is generally most favourable about the beginning of February - is from August to October. <i>(Oct 1877,Country Life</i>) [NOTES: 1877 Oct NZ Country Journal (Kelly) quoted in 1958 NZJ Ag 96 (4): 375]

>  <b>WALLACE</b> ... an amount of small wood is thus secured to guarantee a `good burn', ... <i>(1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,231</i>)

>  <b>KELLY</b> The bush is felled carefully so as to give a good burn. <i>(1892,Journey Through Waitara,20</i>)

>  Everything depends on a successful burn. <i>(1850,Otago Journal,6/108</i>)

>  The fire if it is a good burn destroys all the small stuff, leaves, and burns the surface of the ground well. <i>(Nov 10, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/158,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (H.A. Atkinson)]

>  We got the burns over ...[sic] James & Arthur fired ours after nine o'clock on the night of the 15th. <i>(Feb 25, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960,1/356 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson)]

>  Arthur is going to make a clearing on our land this year, and ...[sic] after the burn would put up a slab house of two rooms which might serve afterwards for cowshed or kitchen or workshop ... `Bird's heart is in the bushland, his heart is not here.' <i>(Aug 8, 1855,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/172,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson)]

>  <b>FULLER</b> Grass springing up after a burn. <i>(1859,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,168</i>)

>  ... while the Australian bush recovers more or less from the burn that of New Zealand perishes ... <i>(1897,TrNZI,29/492</i>) [NOTES: (Walsh)]

>  <b>BELL</b> The season promised to be a good one for bush-burning; and those who had bush-felled were congratulating themselves on the prospect of getting excellent `burns,' while many, who, ... had been unfortunate in getting bad `burns,' were now hopeful of clearing off much of the timber by means of a second fire. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,198</i>)

>  There is very little logging-up done now-a-days, and with a good burn it is quite unnecessary. ... two or three chains around the site should be logged up and burnt. <i>(1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,21</i>)

>  The swampy nature of the soil ... and the too abundant rains make a successful burn impracticable. <i>(1905,TrNZI,37/352</i>) [NOTES: (Walsh)]

>  ... the same good quality of sheep pasture that in the past had given this district an excellent name as a fertile country immediately following the `burn.' <i>(1929,TrNZI,59/406</i>) [NOTES: (Aston)]

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> The `burn' of 1902 ... was not what is technically known as a `clean' fire. ... this fire left unburnt ridge-caps, the tops, sometimes even the upper slopes. <i>(1926,Tutira,170</i>)

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> The big burn was the spectacular event for which their visit was timed. <i>(1933,Tides of Youth,55</i>)

>  These [sown pastures] may be divided into two groups - (a) sown on cultivated land, and (b) surface sown after forest, scrub or fern burn. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,359</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> A bad burn [of cleared bush] may spell ruin to a man with limited capital. <i>(1955,Land of My Children,25</i>)

>  Burning hard fern should not be a regular practice, but often good burns can be made in spring and sometimes in autumn and if the burns [n2] can be oversown and the pasture well-managed afterward, it is a help in the control of hard fern. <i>(May 1958,NZ Journal of Agriculture,96 (5): 457</i>) [NOTES: (Burgess)]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> The `burn' of this bit of bush has not been a good one. <i>(1905,Bush Boys of NZ,31</i>)

>  <b>McLAUCHLAN</b> If the summer rains came and spoilt the burn, it meant a great loss for the farmer; once the leafage of fallen timber drops and becomes a soggy mess on the ground, it is almost impossible to get a successful burn. <i>(1981,Farming of NZ,177</i>)

## burn and graze
 
 <i>phr.</i> (Rural) [of land development] where fern and scrub is burned and stocked quickly to inhibit regrowth.

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> The burn-and-graze technique most commonly used in farms such as those in the Mohaka region during the nineteenth century was developed by Archdeacon Samuel Williams and J.H.Coleman, who discovered that fern could be burnt in January when the sap was up, and that regrowth would mature in about a month. <i>(1985,Farming in the Mohaka State Forest,7</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> Because this expansion into marginal land was coupled with farming techniques - such as the 'burn and graze' method of running sheep - that led to the rapid degradation of the land, it was not long before farming became impossible in some areas... <i>(1985,Farming in the Mohaka State Forest,50</i>)



## burn back

## burn-out
 
 <i>n.</i> From the 1930s at least, according to W. Martin and Bob Adams of NZ Seamen's Union, a bad discharge from a ship, a transferred and figurative usage from stoking the furnace of a coal-burning ship. An inefficient or tyro stoker who built a bad fire had a `burn-out' in the furnace - i.e. the fire went partially out. He was allowed to get away with one of these, but on doing a second, was eased off the ship. Hence it came to mean a bad discharge in general.

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the process of clearing land of forest and scrub by burning.

 <i>n.</i>

## bush costume
 
 <i>n.</i> early costume or outfit suitable for wear in the bush A1 or C4. [The following describe a bushman's or bush-farmer's outfit.] (See [cf. bush hat](../B#bush-hat))

>  <b>ADAMS</b> My costume consisted pair of white duck trousers, checked shirt, stout boots, large cabbage-tree hat and a sort of blue flannel frock confined at the waist by a leather belt. <i>(1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A</i>)

>  <i>(1911,NZ Journal of Agriculture,3/394-399</i>)

>  "Bush" Disease. This affliction appears to be due rather to innutrition [sic] than to any disease, and is apparently confined to the Rotorua district. The animals seem to pine away, but if removed to other and older pastures they usually recover. <i>(1897,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,V/68</i>)

>  Bush-disease in Cattle. Beyond a few cases belonging to a settler of Arahiwi, I have not seen anything. <i>(1898,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VI/88</i>)

>  [Hdg] "Tauranga" or "Bush Disease". This peculiar wasting disease, which is confined to the tract of land lying in the vicinity of Tauranga, and extending from there to Rotorua and Lichfield, was made the subject of an investigation by Mr. Park three years ago... It appears that both sheep and cattle will do well and put on condition for the first few months after being placed on this diseased country, but as time goes on a gradual wasting sets in, which ends in death if they are not removed to another district. <i>(1899,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VII/87</i>)

## bush drive
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a method of treefelling where trees are part-scarfed in front of one or more that are fully felled, taking the part-scarfed trees down with them. (See [Taranaki drive](../T#taranaki-drive))

>  Those great crashing bush-drives, when one tree was aimed to hit another partly-cut tree, which in turn smashed into another half-severed tree, and so on smashing and roaring downhill to the gully's bottom, ... the bush snails dying, the woodhens confounded, the brown pebbled creek and all its reflections from the beginning shrinking back in dismay. <i>(Feb 3, 1985,NZ Times,12</i>) [NOTES: (Jim Henderson)]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> ... high bush faces. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,110</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> All the bush faces were spotted with the dead branches of trees. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,32</i>)



## bush falcon
 
 <i>n.</i> an endangered indigenous bird of prey, the smallest of the three forms of karearea.

>  The Bush Falcon can be found in forest (including exotic pine plantations) and bush patches of the North Island and northwestern South Island. <i>(2007,Internet - see Notes,2</i>) [NOTES: www.ranz.org.nz/raptor-information.]

>  <i>New Zealand Falcon Falco novaeseelandiae</i> GMELIN, 1788 ...[155] OTHER NAMES: <i>Karearea, sparrowhawk, bush hawk, quail hawk, eastern falcon, southern falcon, bush falcon. ... Bush falcon: In the North Island confined to the main ranges, ... Eastern falcon: The main ranges of the South Island ... Southern Falcon: Fiordland, the Auckland Islands, and Stewart Island. </i> <i>(1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,154</i>)

>  Bush falcons - the most widespread of the three races of New Zealand falcon or karearea - are highly territorial. <i>(Jul 1998,NZ Geographic,No. 39/59</i>)

>  [Caption] A rare New Zealand bush falcon perches on the hand of the Matthew Wong who nursed it back to health after it was wounded by an air gun pellet. <i>(Feb 3, 2000,Dominion,6</i>)

>  <b>MORELAND</b> As I came back I saw a bush falcon in the beech before the door, dusky-black when he spread his wings, but speckled like a thrush below. <i>(1911,Through South Westland,163</i>)



## bush falling
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the felling of native forest and undergrowth.

>  <b>DONEY</b> A considerable saving is effected in the cost of bushfalling ... <i>(1891,Essays on Bush-Farming,2</i>)

>  <b>HAY</b> We worked steadily at bush-falling. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,184</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> Bush-falling had barely been started. <i>(1921,Tutira,203</i>)



## bush fare
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> The mountain ... added to the<i> bush </i>appetite we had brought with us. Instead of the old proverb, `Good wine needs no <i>bush</i>', the Bishop ... always reads it, `Good bush needs no wine'; ... I feel as if I have a lee-way of a fortnight's bush-fare to make up. <i>(1959,Early Travellers,111</i>) [NOTES: 1855 Aug 16-18 Abraham Walk from Auckland to Taranaki in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 111]



## bush farm
 
 <i>n.</i> a farm cleared from the bush

>  <b>DAVIN</b> ... someone from a bush farm had taken it from a wild pig's litter and shoved it in the sale ... <i>(1959,No Remittance,138</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Several miles beyond this block, out across the rolling gumland hills, thickly covered with short manuka scrub, lay a back-block section, a bush farm in the early stages of development ... <i>(1956,Green Kiwi,38,1960 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Theirs was to be a bush farm, for the Government was opening up some bush country said to be the finest land in all New Zealand. <i>(1955,Land of My Children,17</i>)

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> He married her and took her off to his first bush-farm. <i>(1965,Among the Cinders,115</i>)

>  <b>KEENE</b> Rover surprised me by arriving at my bush farm three miles from the Bonnet. ... After that he often appeared where I was cutting bush. <i>(1967,Tang of The Bush,65</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> Any man who chooses to spend three years breaking in a bush farm in the North Island . <i>(1889,New Zealand After 50 Years,144</i>)

>  My experiences in settling here on our bush farm. <i>(1916,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1916 letter in 1939 Winter King Country 13]

>  <b>MULGAN</b> [He] married, and invested in a bush farm at Normanby, in Taranaki. This was in 1881, ... <i>(1958,Making of a New Zealander, The,81</i>)

>  `The Melon' comments: `Diggers, Go for the bush farm If you like, but tale a 'orrible example of me, and beware of widders all yer life!' <i>(Nov 1, 1918,Quick March,15</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> A settler ... and his young son had been found tomahawked on their bush farm ... about four miles from Drury; ... <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,1/253</i>)

>  [Advt] 146 Acres - Workingman's Bush-farm, about 16 miles from Auckland... The property consists of about 90 acres of Virgin Bush. <i>(Jun 4, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,2</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a farm property developed from standing bush.

>  Remembered 30th July defendant was on the bush farm. <i>(Jun 30, 1888,Egmont Star,9</i>)

>  Among those valleys the courageous women helping their soldier husbands to make a 'go' of the new bush farms. <i>(Oct 30, 1926,NZ Dairy Exporter,41</i>)

>  No two bush farmers, even of experience, are of same opinion regarding the best method of working a bush farm. <i>(Jul 1887,NZ Farmer,196</i>)

>  <b>DONEY</b> There is a matter which is rarely ever attended to on bush farms that should command some attention .. the planting of shelter. <i>(1891,Essays on Bush-Farming,10</i>)

>  For sale - Improved bush farm, situated ... <i>(Apr 17, 1896,Hawera Star,3</i>)

>  I am dairying on a bush farm. <i>(Jul 20, 1923,NZ Journal of Agriculture,63</i>)

>  When I was first married, my husband took me to a lonely bush farm ... <i>(Oct 29, 1927,NZ Dairy Exporter,40</i>)

>  <b>HOWITT</b> It was a great day for the youngsters on the bush farms when Chew Chong, the old Chinese storekeeper, found out the value of fungus which grew on the stumps in the bush clearings. <i>(1945,Pioneer Looks Back, A,25</i>)

>  <b>SPENCER</b> We were going back into the bush country to make our home. It was a bush farm in the Waioeka Gorge. <i>(1992,Waioeka Pioneering Saga,203</i>)

>  He took up a fair-sized bush farm at Onuku, and married Miss Grandi. <i>(1945,BLANK ENTRY,20</i>) [NOTES: in KEEGAN (1983) The First Generation]



## bush farmer
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a farmer who develops and farms a property from bush settlement.

>  <b>WARR</b> A bush farmer, with about 200 acres, would be felling the last 20-30 acres of his holding after about ten years ... <i>(1988,From Bush-Burn to Butter,42</i>)

>  No two bush farmers, even of experience, are of same opinion regarding the best method of working a bush farm. <i>(Jul 1887,NZ Farmer,196</i>)

>  All the talk in the district now is butter, and it is scarcely to be wondered at when it is considered how closely the market price of that commodity is bound up with the bush-farmer's prosperity. <i>(Dec 1, 1888,Egmont Star,9</i>)

>  <b>DONEY</b> All classes of sheep are not suitable for the bush farmers. <i>(1891,Essays on Bush-Farming,3</i>)

>  Were it not for the rather low reading of the financial barometer, the bush farmers of the Dominion would have little ground for complaint. <i>(Oct 20, 1914,NZ Journal of Agriculture,232</i>)

>  <b>RICHMOND</b> I also found that I was a bush farmer with 60 acres of clearing for the most part badly burned ... <i>(Jan 17, 1858,Letter,338</i>) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

>  <b>WASWO</b> ..most of the bush farmers chose sheep because they were more economical and they provided the quickest return. <i>(1996,Farming Progress in NZ 1814-1995,8</i>)



## bush farming
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>WARR</b> Walter Riddell was an early bush-farming pioneer on the Otago Peninsula. <i>(1988,From Bush-Burn to Butter,57</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the clearing of bush in order to lay down pasture.

>  <b>RICHMOND</b> My own future is as uncertain as ever. I do not mean as regards my occupation .. bush farming ... <i>(Dec 2, 1855,Letter,184</i>) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

>  <b>DONEY</b> [title] <i>(1891,Essays on Bush-Farming</i>)

>  <b>WESTMACOTT</b> He had seen fortunes lost at bush farming as a result of bad burns. <i>(1977,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,96</i>)



## bush farmstead
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a cleared area where land can be lived on and farmed.

>  <b>COMBS</b> The clearing of a bush farmstead was a full-time job in itself. <i>(1951,Growing Up in the Forty-Mile Bush,37</i>)



## bush fastness
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a bush section for development into a farm.

>  .. the success or otherwise of the pioneer grazier depends to a very great extent upon the security of his fences, especially in the bush fastnesses of the King Country. <i>(Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,927</i>)



## bush feed
 
 <i>n.</i> green-feed growing in the bush; leaves of forest trees and shrubs as feed for stock (see, for example, burnt feed).

>  We have 36 head of cattle running this winter on the back bush land.... The bush feed keeps the cattle in fine order in winter time. <i>(Aug 8, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/154,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (C.W.Richmond)]

>  <b>HAY</b> He [the open-land farmer] has no bush-feed for cattle as we have, ... It is eight or twelve years before the bush-farmer gets a [208] chance of ploughing; ... <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,207</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) strippings of foliage from native bush for stock feed.

>  <b>REA</b> .. in the winter-times [they] would drive their cows over, pitch a tent and spend weeks at a time cutting bush feed for them. <i>(1991,Honey and Cheese,73</i>)

>  Farm management has also changed from wintering the herd for three months on bush feed and roughage, to winter cropping <i>(Jan 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture,27</i>)



## bush fence
 
 <i>n.</i> in the only recorded use the sense and force of bush are obscure, and if not a slip of the pen for `brush', prob. means `made of material from the bush A1' (cf. 1855 Journal St Leonard's Station, Canterbury - `brush fence' for stock yard'; (See [cf. bush harrow; brush harrow](../B#bush-harrow;-brush-harrow))

>  <b>LANGDALE-HUNT</b> In my time we would make an early potato garden by felling the trees in a sheltered hollow where there was no growth underneath, making a bush fence of the trunks and branches round the plot which made it both sheltered and stock proof. <i>(1985,Last Entail Male,8</i>)

>  <b>PHARAZYN</b> Making a bush fence. <i>(1849,Journal,293</i>)

>  <b>PERHAM</b> ... a kind of yard fenced with logs piled one on top of the other. In New Zealand it would be called a `bush fence'. <i>(1958,Kimberley Flying Column,32</i>)



## bush fencing
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  All hands at bush fencing and all very tired. Karawas [supplejacks] as thick as a cloud, every tree hung together like wax. <i>(Jun 25, 1888,Chudleigh Diary,362,1950 ed.</i>)



## bush fever
 
 <i>n.</i> a fever of cattle caused by the ingestion of certain bush plants

>  <b>KEENE</b> Those [cattle] accustomed to hina-hina could eat it with impunity, but to strangers it was poison. We lost four milking cows ... We had no further trouble with bush fever unless strange cattle were brought in. <i>(1967,Tale of a Timber Town,61</i>)



## bush fight
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>COWAN</b> Those who escaped Ngatapa ... includ[ed] a number of women who survived the terrors and hardships of the bush fight. <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,2/281,1983 ed.</i>)



## bush fighter
 
 <i>n.</i> an irregular during the Land Wars, skilled at fighting in the bush (See [cf. bushranger](../B#bushranger))

>  <b>ALEXANDER</b> Active and wiry men, of sound constitutions, are best adapted for bush-fighters. <i>(1873,Bush Fighting,1</i>)

>  Four further AC patrols - cavalry and bush-fighters - were dispatched from inland localities to scout and endeavour to intercept Te Kooti. <i>(Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32</i>)



## bush fighting
 
 <i>n.</i> irregular or guerilla fighting in the bush (esp. during the Land Wars)

>  <b>F MATHEW</b> [The natives] beat us in skirmishing and bush fighting. <i>(1847,Report,4/15</i>)

>  <b>ROCHFORT</b> They [officers] can fancy them [bush-rats] to be Maories, by a little stretch of imagination, and practise bush-fighting from behind the bedposts. <i>(1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,26</i>)

>  <b>ALEXANDER</b> Bush fighting is a comprehensive term for warfare conducted in forests, in broken ground and on the hill-side. Whereever cover can be got, in attack and defence, under the canopy of heaven, there bush fighting can be practised, and it is highly useful to practise it as a part of army manoeuvres. <i>(1873,Bush Fighting,1</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> Yet there were not only settler-soldiers but many of the veterans of the 65th which could have been formed into an excellent forest-ranging corps, competent to follow the Maori into the roughest country ... But it was not until 1863 that the value of such bush-fighting companies was recognized. <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,1/211</i>)

>  <b>SOLJAK</b> Finally the British Government withdrew the bulk of the Imperial forces and Frederick Weld, head of the new `self-reliant' colonial Administration, proceeded to employ the New Zealand militia in unconventional bush fighting [43] better suited to cope with the elusive Maori. <i>(1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42</i>)

>  <b>BARTLETT</b> `Von' [Tempsky] was dead, famed through New Zealand for his reckless bravery and his skill in bush fighting. <i>(1974,Emigrants, The,78</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Had the Maori combined, they would have driven the Government troops and settlers into the sea, and the English nation would then have learned what the Caffres are now teaching them, that the arms, dress and equipment of the English soldier are the worst possible for bush fighting. <i>(1852,Saunders' Monthly Magazine,Vol. 1/</i>) [NOTES: 1852 Saunders' Monthly Magazine Vol I in 1976 Canterbury Colony 19]



## bush fire
 
 <i>n.</i> a fire in uncleared or forest land; also called a forest-fire

>  <b>WELD</b> If provisions run short [the sheepfarmer] should not think it a degradation, gentleman born though he might be, to heap fresh logs on the bush fire, to put on the soup pot, or to bake a damper in the ashes. <i>(1851,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,11</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> As the night darkened we saw far in the distance the red glow of a huge bush-fire. <i>(1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,14</i>)

>  <b>HODDER</b> That night I enjoyed - what had often pleased me to read of in books - a bush-fire. Six or seven large old dry trees had been chopped down and cast onto the already large fire , which threw out a capital heat and lit up the whole of the bush surrounding us. <i>(1862,Memories of NZ Life,72</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> By the side of the creek, the Grey Party ... pitched their tent. Of course they lit a bush fire. They rolled huge logs into it, and piled branches of odiferous gum-trees on it, until it blazed high up into the brilliant atmosphere. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,2/vi/64,1889,1974 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [?Aust ref]]

>  <b>MONE</b> ... I smoked my evening pipe. This I did by the light of a good bush-fire, that danced and flickered on the trees and scrub around me, and showed the only living animals that formed my society - grey bush rats. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,31</i>) [NOTES: <i>Ibid.</i> 45 Another hour saw the whole party under a temporary break-wind, with a roaring bush-fire hissing under the pouring rain, ...]



 
 <i>n.</i> [[Aust. usage applies to any large fire in the open; NZ mainly to a forest fire - other fires would be termed scrub fires, etc.]]

>  A great bush fire on either side of Merton ... <i>(1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/345</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> Man, bushfires and cats have destroyed [tuataras] on the mainland. <i>(1855,Journal,9/138</i>)

>  <b>WALKER</b> We were then just opposite Akaroa Bay, ... Last night we saw a light which we thought to be the Southern light, but which turned out to be a bush fire. <i>(Oct 17, 1862,Journal and Letters (Walker)</i>)

>  <b>RUTHERFORD</b> For the prevention of bush and other fires, and the restraint of persons firing bush, scrub, ... to the danger of life or property. <i>(1949,Selected Documents,112b</i>) [NOTES: 1861 Nov 2 Sir George Grey Memorandum in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112b]

>  ... the climate is so humid as to be unfavorable[sic] to the spreading of bush fires. <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/III/8</i>) [NOTES: (Monro)]

>  ... the constantly recurring bush fires have cleared off the stately Ti palms (so fragrant in early spring); ... <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/49</i>) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

>  ... the once silent woods now resound with the blows of the felling-axe ... the Wattle-bird is no longer to be found in its old haunts; it seeks shelter amongst the higher parts of the bushy gullies ... the condition of the forest is changing under the effects of ... constantly-recurring bush fires. ... The Kokako loving a moist temperature will probably soon entirely forsake its ancient places of resort. <i>(1874,TrNZI,6/146</i>) [NOTES: (Potts)]

>  Very bright Aurora australis due south at 9.30, 10 etc. Abner has seen this light two or three times lately ... They thought it was a bush fire. <i>(Nov 3, 1882,Chudleigh Diary,314,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>LADY MARTIN</b> Far away up this vista, some thin blue smoke went up from a bush fire. <i>(1884,Our Maoris,94</i>)

>  <b>HOPEFUL</b> ... there were fearful bush-fires on the west coast of the North Island at Taranaki, whence many of the settlers had to flee for their lives. <i>(1887,Taken In,186</i>)

>  <b>D'AVIGDOR</b> When the base of the mountains is veiled ... by the blue smoke of the too frequent bush-fires, the sharp peaks seem to rise to empyrean heights ... <i>(1888,Antipodean Notes,151</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> Bush fires were now more frequent. Decaying timber, the remnants of former fires, ... and stumps were now like tinder. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,199</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Bush-fire</i>, ... forests and grass on fire in hot summers. 1868. C. Dilke, `Greater Britian, `vol. ii. part iii. c. iii. p. 32: <i>(1898,Austral English,70</i>)

>  ... we find extensive tracts of forest composed chiefly of beech, unfortunately fast disappearing in the saw-mills and in the bush-fires which so frequently devastate the hillsides. <i>(1900,Canterbury Old & New,186</i>)

>  <b>WHITE</b> The New Zealand Quail, which was very plentiful, is nearly extinct now: Bush-fires have burnt it, and dogs, cats, and rats have eaten it, but the Australian and Californian varieties have filled its place. <i>(1905,My NZ Garden,69</i>)

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> Jessie was used to bush fires. <i>(1933,Tides of Youth,62</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> This was in the big bush fire that destroyed so much property at Waimate in November, 1878. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,142</i>)

>  And from the engine-room there was enough smoke to make you think there were not two kerosene engines below, but a bush fire. But even an Australian bush fire couldn't smell as bad. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,15</i>)

>  It was like reading those school essays we used to write, before Professor Gordon, in which every noun had to have at least one `expressive adjective', in which a bush fire was a fierce holocaust raging down stately corridors of ancient rimus. <i>(Sep 1952,Landfall,23/213</i>) [NOTES: Pearson `Fretful Sleepers']

>  We may speak of kauri forest or beech forest, but we get lost in the bush, fight bush fires, and climb above the bushline. The kauri forest, like the mixed podocarp forest, the sub-tropical rain forest, ... and such-like are terms that come from the botanist and forester, not from the layman - or from the bushman. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,23</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']



 
 <i>n.</i> [is this a separate use?]

>  <b>BULLER</b> But, partly owing to the introduction of dogs, ... and partly to the prevalence of the so-called `bush-fires' or burning of the runs (a necessary incident of sheep-farming in a new country), the Quail has rapidly disappeared ... <i>(1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/226</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to burn bush in the process of clearing land for pasture.

## bush fireplace
 
 <i>n.</i>

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the burning of native bush to develop pasture.

## bush flow

 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i>

## bush flying
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [dee-hunting] the piloting of fixed-wing aircraft at low altitudes in bush-covered terrain.

## bush jigger

Small hand-worked jiggers were used extensively on the NZR but they were not common on trams... The first bush jiggers were constructed early in the 20th century... The earliest confirmed jigger appeared in April 1908 when it was reported that a trolley had been built by Gamman at Te Ohu to convey 10-12 men to and from work... The principal use of bush jiggers was to get the bushmen to and from work.  <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SWAINSON</b> For such [who declare all travel barren], a bush-journey in New Zealand will have neither pleasure nor profit; but not so to an intelligent and observant man. <i>(1853,Auckland,128</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> As they arrived there, after their rough bush journey of ten days they were received with loud cries ... from the women. <i>(1940,Sir Donald Maclean,54</i>)



## bush justice
 
 <i>n.</i> rough justice

>  He had good reason to believe the gang wanted to extract retribution from him. The penalty he had already suffered was substantial, a penalty by way of `bush justice.' <i>(Nov 13, 1979,Evening Post,32</i>) [NOTES: [AND 1959]]



## bush karaka
 
 <i>n.</i> [(?bush =?).]

>  <b>BROOKES</b> .. whitewood, fern trees, bush karaka ... puketea. <i>(1892,Frontier Life,20</i>)



## bush kennel
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a makeshift shelter for a sheepdog at a mustering hut or camp.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> We were building bush kennels for our dogs, a few chains from the hut. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,42</i>)



## bush knife
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>COWAN</b> The Rangers' arms were ... in Von Tempsky's company, a bowie knife with a blade 10 inches or 12 inches long. ... `We find them long enough to rach our enemies with,' so the Rangers could have said of their bush-knives that were quite long enough for close quarters. <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,1/266</i>)



## bush lagoon
 
 <i>n.</i> a lagoon surrounded by, or in the, bush.

>  <b>ANDERSEN</b> [The birds] of the plains, swamps and bush-lagoons. <i>(1942,Maori Place Names,124</i>)



## bush lamp
 
 <i>n.</i> a slush lamp or a bush lantern (a candle stuck into the neck of an upturned bottle)

>  <b>cham</b> The bush-lamp had burned low. <i>(1891,Philosopher Dick,36</i>)



## bush land
 
 <i>n.</i> land covered by bush, as distinct from open country (contrast open land, open country; and in a different semantic area fern-land). [the form develops from an orig. loose combination of <i>bush</i> A1, `forest' and <i>land</i> with a sense (or implication) `land covered with bush', earlier forest-land; 1. land covered with native bush. 2. farmland developed from cleared bushland. [Cf 1835 Yate New Zealand 17-18 The forest-land is peculiarly rich; indeed, were it not so, it would be utterly impossible that the [18] immense vegetation constantly going on should be supported.] to a closer combination or compound with a sense `cleared bush-land, farmland once covered with bush', with the senses often hard to distinguish. (cf fernland]]

>  <b>CARRINGTON</b> Fern or Bush land. <i>(1841,Journal,12</i>)

>  <b>HEAPHY</b> There is also less general undergrowth [in the Nelson forest], and the bush land will be cleared with less attendant expense than at Wellington. ... [125] ... The expense attendant on clearing bush-land ... <i>(1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),103</i>)

>  Immediately behind it [the fern land] is a belt of bush land, as it is here called, composed of the most beautiful shrubs from five to twenty feet high ... This land is considered the best; behind this commences the timber district, which I have not seen. <i>(1843,Letters from New Plymouth,26</i>) [NOTES: (1842 Mar 2) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 26]

>  Bush land is best : it is all humbug what is said about fern land being so good. <i>(1843,Letters from New Plymouth,28</i>) [NOTES: (1842 Mar 12) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 28]

>  Fern and bush land. <i>(1842,Letters from New Plymouth,144,1843 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1842 W. Bayly in 1843 Letters from Settlers 144]

>  A belt of bush land as it is called here. <i>(1842,Letters from New Plymouth,154</i>) [NOTES: 1842 Stephen Gillingham in 1843 Letters fropm Settlers 154]

>  <b>HEAPHY</b> <i>(1842,Narrative of a Residence in  Various Parts of NZ,103</i>)

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> Beyond the bush land, that which is called grass land chiefly produces a very cutting wiry species, very similar to that which in swamps we call tree grass, but without the stem or trunk on which the former is elevated above the water surface; these plumes of grass on this dry land in burning diffuse a fragrant and aromatic odour, ... <i>(May 13, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1844 May 13 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 220]

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> Some provision might easily and justly be made [for the European residents] ...; about ten acres of <i>good</i>, bush land for each child would not be too much, ... <i>(Apr 19, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Apr 19 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 209]

>  <b>LANGDALE-HUNT</b> Frederick Hunt gave quite a nice piece of bushland to Isabella, just as he had given to his other two daughters, Elizabeth Gregory and Mary Anne Langdale, I presume as dowries when they married. <i>(1958,Last Entail Male,f42</i>)

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> ... cleared bushland ... <i>(May 23, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1844 May 23 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223]

>  <b>MONRO</b> The natives, as elsewhere in New Zealand, have cultivated the bush-land, ... <i>(1844,Notes of a Journey</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 242]

>  <b>PHARAZYN</b> ... taking one crop off the land, and that bush-land. <i>(1846,Journal,19</i>)

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> Fresh fern land is at first infertile through what we call `sourness'. ... Grass land is less subject to `sourness'; and Bush land not at all. ... Bush land, is the common forest land. <i>Ibid.</i> 331 Bush land is richer than either Fern or Grass land; <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/330</i>)

>  The Korari is the name of the flower stalk, often, but wrongly, used as the name of the plant. The edible root is the Aruhe. The word `Muka' is commonly applied to the dressed fibre; it is the correct name for the inner leaves. Cleared bush-land is suitable for the cultivation of the flax plant, and even swamp-land is improved by drainage. In the various flax swamps near nelson ...the finest plants grow upon the soil that has been thrown out of the ditch ... <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/117</i>) [NOTES: (Heaphy NZ Flax)]

>  <b>HAY</b> The Harakeke or Korati [sic](<i>Phormium tenax</i>) is the justly celebrated New Zealand flax. It is plentiful everywhere, on bush-land and open-land, rich soil and poor soil, hill and dale, from the Reinga to the Bluff. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,2/204</i>)

>  My meadow fescue sown on the 15 acre of bushland felled by Manuel is a perfect failure. <i>(Oct 6, 1886,Chudleigh Diary,348,1950 ed.</i>)

>  ... it takes from ten to fifteen years before the plough can be used in bush land, ... <i>(1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,13</i>)

>  Where bush land has not been sown with cocksfoot ... <i>(1919,TrNZI,51/366</i>) [NOTES: (Laing)]

>  <b>KEENE</b> b. A rural farming area (overtones of bushland 1. with bush) (does this however belong to 1b.). <i>(1967,Tang of The Bush,100</i>)

>  Arthur is going to make a clearing on our land this year, and ... [sic] after the burn would put up a slab house of two rooms which might serve afterwards for cowshed or kitchen or workshop ... `Bird's heart is in the bushland, his heart is not here.' <i>(Aug 8, 1855,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/172,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Jane M. Atkinson)]

>  <b>PYKE</b> [country district] ... they lighted a fire, and `slung the billy', - (Anglice[e-acute]: a tin vessel used for preparing tea) - the indispensable concomitant of all repasts, and the chief luxury of dwellers in bush land. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk III ch v 88</i>)

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> ... I recall his [the botanist-Inspector's] chuckle when we showed him ... the huge white caterpillar known throughout bushland [in North Auckland] as the `rata grub', so-called because it was always found at the foot of a rata and was supposed to be the origin [101] of the tree itself. It is a curious creature - a great caterpillar with a strange tree-like fungoid growth, growing sometimes to a height of several inches, from its body. I think everybody believed in the legend of the rata-tree caterpillar; ... <i>(1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,101</i>)

>  <b>FITTON</b> BUSH LAND AS COMPARED WITH FERN [heading] `Almost all the crops ... have been taken from what is called fern land ... But ... I know that when I left New Plymouth district ... the bush land crops of wheat were deemed inferior ... to those of open fern lands; ... <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),101</i>)

>  ... <i>Pterostylis graminea</i> is in flower on the ridges of steep bush-land hills. <i>(1884,TrNZI,16/389</i>) [NOTES: (Adams)]

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> It [sc. wheat] was in very good condition and heavy, grown on cleared bushland, a nice sandy loam, ... <i>(May 23, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1844 May 23 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223]

>  <b>WILLCOX</b> The `Bush' or forest land, although most difficult to reclaim, becomes most speedily productive; but `Fern' land, that is land covered with fern and shrubby plants is ... ultimately the most profitable. <i>(1860,Handbook of New Zealand,80</i>)

>  <b>HAY</b> We prefer bush-land to open-land for pioneer farming. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,207</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> <i>Bush</i>, or wooded land, is <i>cleared </i>at about 8l. or 110l. per acre; ... <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,187</i>)

>  Bush land can be cleared for about [pounds]6, that is, the bush burnt off; of course the stumps are left to rot out. <i>(Apr 16, 1849,Letters from Otago,31,1978 ed.</i>)

>  Some ...[sic] who wished to stop, intend proceeding to Auckland as they are frightened of bush land, and the block containing fern, which will be next opened, is hardly likely to be in the market for 6 months to come. <i>(Sep 24, 1853,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/131,1960 ed.</i>)

>  The land is cleared bush land full of stumps, only fit for grazing. -->1852 Jan 18 Nairn and Stephen Journal in 1947 Beattie Pioneers Explore Otago 27 Our day's travelling was over some high undulating land with flax tutu high grass and several blocks of bush land with very good timber. <i>(Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/81,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

>  <b>EARP</b> All reserves for townships or agricultural establishments shall have reserves marked off of one-twentieth of all bush-land within the limit of such block, or if there be no bush within such block, then a sufficient reserve of bush-land outside the block, ... shall be made. <i>(1858,Handbook Wellington,13</i>) [NOTES: [quoting Land Regulations]]

>  <b>FITTON</b> But we cannot say we have had [187] a fair trial of bush land. <i>Ibid.</i> 261 ... I have heard that in forest or `bush' land, where there were large trees to fell, ... the land has cost about [pounds]40.[sic.]an acre before the crop was in the ground. ... I have been told by settlers on small allotments of the cleared `bush' land ... <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),186</i>)

>  <b>WELCH</b> Bush land is common forest land. <i>(1863,NZ Guide,22</i>)

>  <b>BATEMAN</b> The forest, or what is colonially termed `bush-land' takes some time to clear. <i>(1881,Colonist, The,183</i>)

>  ... large areas of bush land being annually cleared. <i>(1899,TrNZI,31/7</i>) [NOTES: (Buller)]

>  HOMESTEAD SYSTEM. Under this system the settler makes no payment for the land, the only cost to him being the expenses of survey. On the fulfilment of conditions, which are five years' residence, the erection of a house, and the cultivation of one-third of the selection if open land, and one-fifth if bush-land, the Crown grant is issued. `Do you own any land?' `Yes, three hundred acres of bush land.' `Have you any cleared?' `Sixty acres'. [ca1900] <i>(1892,NZ Official Handbook,284</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> If I had a couple of hundred acres of good bush land, and a wife like that girl down there would make, I wouldn't call the Queen my aunt; and, by Jove! I mean to have a buck at some of those sections in the Whakatangi Block that'll be thrown open shortly, ... <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,84</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Soon came bushland with here and there a small clearing where a few houses and perhaps a store, huddled beside the railway. <i>(1955,Land of My Children,19</i>) [NOTES: [cf bush country]]

>  <b>JOHNSTON</b> ... their way still led through bush-land, and ... tiny birds began to appear: perky tomtits in immaculate suits of black and white, ... grey warblers trilling their lilting arias. <i>(1968,Turn of the Tide, The,69</i>)

>  The bush-land is the best land. <i>(1843,Letters from Settlers,153</i>) [NOTES: 1842 Paul Inch in 1843 Letters from Settlers 153]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) country that grows native bush or forest, or is undeveloped for farming.

>  <b>MARTIN</b> Bush land can be cleared for about GBP6, that is, the bush burnt off. <i>(Nov 1849,Letter,72</i>) [NOTES: in Otago Journal]

>  When a person takes up bush land without having experience or giving the undertaking great study, he runs a great risk of falling into grave errors. Bush land is not like the open. <i>(Jul 1887,NZ Farmer,196</i>)

>  For sale - 4470 acres bush land, rata, tawa, pukatea, and rimu timber ... <i>(Nov 28, 1903,Hawera Star,2</i>)

>  Near Tauranga, 5800 acres good bush land, ring-fenced. <i>(Aug 13, 1908,Weekly News,2</i>)

>  <b>TAIT</b> .. they literally hacked out their farms from cut-over bushland. <i>(1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,464</i>)

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> .. a huge white caterpillar known throughout bushland as the 'rata grub'. <i>(1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,101</i>)

>  <b>ROBSON</b> Bush land is a dangerous instrument for poor colonists. [bushland; bush-land] <i>(1967,Bits and Pieces,53</i>)

>  <b>PRATT</b> The piece of land I was preparing for cropping with potatoes was bush-land that had been cleared and planted by the Maories [sic]. <i>(1877,Colonial Experiences,93</i>)

>  Its [cocksfoot's] chief value lies in it being a strong, hardy grower, and especially adapted for surface sowing upon bushland, hillsides and other places ... <i>(May 1909,NZ Farmer,338</i>)



## bush language
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) basic, colourful language, possibly involving swear words.

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> [To our British teacher] a paddock was now a field, our tucker or crib bags (made out of sugar bags) became satchels or lunch bags and our oilskin coats became macs. We preferred to retain our bush language. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,38</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> With the bush language there comes a certain attitude to the hills, a conviction that the bush is a great place to be ... <i>(1988,Hills, The</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> To use an amusing phrase of that inimitable Bush language, it was country that was 'without a word of a lie, as steep as a hen's face.' <i>(1947,Wayleggo,59</i>)

>  <b>MARRIOTT</b> Dan told them in real bush language just what he thought of stupid townies and refused to give them the consignment notes. <i>(1981,Life in the Gorge,84</i>)



## bush lantern
 
 <i>n.</i> a makeshift lantern (cf. bush lamp, bush candlestick; joey, manrope lantern, West Coast lantern)

>  <b>PYKE</b> A bush lantern is constructed by placing a candle within the neck of a clear glass bottle, the bottom of which has either been knocked off by a sharp scientific tap from a practised hand, or more artistically removed by pouring in a little cold water, and then thrusting the bottle end-wise in a fire <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/xii/42,(1889, 1974) ed.</i>)



## bush larrikin
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  So long as the farmer persists in cutting down the native growth ..., or so long as the gum-digger and bush-larrikin are allowed to put a match into anything that will burn, there is not much hope for either prevention or restoration. <i>(1897,TrNZI,29/496</i>) [NOTES: (Walsh)]



## bush law
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MAY</b> ... sham, humbug, bush-law, vanity, and vexation of the spirit ... a gathering of quacks, where he who has the loudest voice and the greatest stock of impudent assurance will be listened to with most respect <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,252/3/1,1962 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [May quoting a correspondent]]



## bush lawyer
 
 <i>n.</i> a self-trained legal "expert"

>  I smirk every time I see the president-in-waiting's legal team described as "Bush lawyers." <i>(Dec 5, 2000,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  <b>BATISTICH</b> A man you could learn from. Clever, they said, a regular bush lawyer. <i>(1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,16</i>)

>  [Hdg] A Bush Lawyer <i>(Feb 15, 1890,NZ Observer,4</i>)

>  Mr Justice O'Regan remarked that bush lawyers were everywhere... "In fact, you will still find the typical bush lawyer right in the bush." <i>(Oct 18, 1943,NZEF Times,III/121</i>)

>  <b>BEARDSLEY</b> We have to have all our i's dotted and our t's crossed in case they put up a bush lawyer against us. <i>(1984,Blackball 08,129</i>)

>  <b>BATISTICH</b> A good boss, he paid well. A man you could learn from. Clever, they said, a regular bush lawyer. <i>(1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,16</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a thorny bush creeper



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) <i>Rubus cissoides</i>, a tenacious vine of the spp. Rosaceae notorious for trapping and starving sheep. [a tenacious indigenous bramble, ,<i>Rubus australis</i>, taramoa, or tataramoa, with small white flowers, renowned for forming barriers on bush paths. It was also well-known by the jocular sobriquet of taihoa, wait-a-while, or wait-a-bit.]

>  Bush lawyer berries, tree fuchsia berries and supplejack shoots were particularly welcome whenever I could find them. <i>(May 23, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),15</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> I'd been lassoed by a rope of bush lawyer, the vine tearing across my neck like barbed-wire. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,12</i>) [NOTES: 1994 edition]

>  There, his diet consisted of such things as bush lawyer berries (from the same genus, rubus, as blackberries)... <i>(Apr 30, 2005,Dominion Post,E12</i>)

>  <b>HOCHSTETTER</b> <i>Rubus Australis</i> [sic], the thorny strings of which scratch the hands and face, which the colonists, therefore, very wittily call the `bush lawyer'. <i>(1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles),135</i>)

>  The stringly tendrils of the aptly named taihoa, or 'wait-a-while native creeper, tough enough to trap and hold a horse. <i>(1948,Gumdigger, The,53</i>)

>  The next day I somehow get out of that difficult terrain and drop into the Waiau, wet through, cut-up by bush lawyer and totally knackered. <i>(Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32</i>)

>  Perhaps you know it better by the name Bush Lawyer or simply Lawyer; and if you are a botanist, as Rubus australis. The Maoris call it Tataramoa - a heap of prickles. <i>(Nov 20, 1907,Otago Witness,20</i>)

>  Shall I see the Ponga Fairy and the cross old Bush Lawyer? <i>(Dec 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> Hour after hour we toiled on, sometimes making our way through .. the long and clinging bramble, called by colonists the 'bush-lawyer'. <i>(1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,44</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> .. a bush lawyer had twined some of its long straggling prickly limbs through the scrub <i>(1881,Waitaruna,94</i>)

>  In the different species of bush-lawyers the prickles are well developed at an early stage. <i>(Sep 28, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Everywhere the self-asserting 'Bush Lawyer' which has gained its name from the tenacity of its prickly spikes <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,234</i>)

>  <b>MORELAND</b> The most reviled, and at the same time one of the most beautiful, of the climbers is the 'bush lawyer'. It is armed, on stalks and leaves alike, with barbed hooks, by which it climbs, clutching everything within reach. <i>(1911,Through South Westland,83</i>)



## bush level
 
 <i>n.</i> bushline (cf. also bush limit)

>  ... that there is a pass below bush-level, at the head of the Hauroto Burn ... <i>(1897,AJHR</i>) [NOTES: 1897 AJHR Wilmot Report of a Journey in 1950 Reed and Reed Farthest West 185]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> It took us three hours to reach the open basin above the bush level ...<i>Ibid.</i> 51 ... the large open faces above the bush level. <i>Ibid.</i> 71 The snow that was still on the tops above bush level was the main reason why the deer were so plentiful. <i>Ibid.</i> 121 The high `tops' are practically free from snow, and the `waps' will be out above bush level seeking the young tussock growth. <i>Ibid.</i> 123 The bush-covered mountains reached from the water's edge up to the natural bush level, about three and a half thousand feet up. <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,46</i>)



## bush licence
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a licence to serve alcohol in early European settlement days.

>  <b>MORGAN</b> Bush licenses in remote country districts do not answer the purpose for which the license is granted. <i>(Jun 17, 1857,Letter,I 278</i>) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers]

>  <b>MCGREGOR</b> .. Elmbranch had built a bush-licence accommodation house known as The Rest and Be Thankful. <i>(1973,Petticoat Pioneers,211</i>)

>  <b>KAY</b> The first 'bush license' at the Halfway was issued to John Lodge, who owned the third eight-acre strip of land there, alongside those of Anthony and John Whitehouse. Bush licenses were issued for the sale of liquor without any rules for accommodation. A Special Publican's License was issued to John McKain in 1849, followed by a 'bush license' a year later. <i>(1996,Anthony Wall, Settler of Porirua,39</i>)

>  A bush license has been refused to Mr Price, the owner of the accommodation house at the Mangawhero bridge. <i>(Jan 22, 1881,Hawera Star,2</i>)

>  The following applications for bush licenses were granted:- J H Noding, Waipori, accommodation house. <i>(Dec 6, 1862,Otago Witness,3</i>)

>  <b>BOLLINGER</b> Especially after the widespread granting of 'bush licences' in the 1860s, liquor was deliberately used by unscrupulous Pakehas as a means of debauching individual Maoris, especially chiefs, and swindling them of their tribal lands. <i>(1959,Grog's Own Country,17</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a licence to cut timber from native bush.

>  The interest that the bush licence or leasing system affords to the State is `nil'. <i>(1880,TrNZI,12/7</i>) [NOTES: (Lecoy)]

>  <b>JACOBSON</b> He took out a bush licence for splitting shingles and posts and rails. <i>(1893,Tales of Banks Peninsula,158</i>)

>  A number of questions have been asked within the last day or two about the issue of bush licenses. On and after the 1st January next, licenses will be issued to settlers, giving them the right to cut timber for their own use ... [bush license] <i>(Dec 15, 1880,Hawera Star,2</i>)



## bush life
 
 <i>n.</i> back blocks life; life as a pioneer farmer.

>  My youthful spirits are required ... to keep Bessie [Domett] from drooping under the depressing influence of bush-life. <i>(Jan 24, 1859,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/473,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Maria Richmond)]

>  The party returned to Kaihu, after the dancing, with entirely new ideas of bush-life. <i>(Oct 11, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> I saw plenty of bush life and was twelve months at one time up the Totara River ... without once going to Ross. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,110</i>)

>  He was a deserter from the colonial forces ... and had already lived a bush life with the Piri-Rakau ... Tribe <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,2/14,1983 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HODDER</b> Bush-life is just what you make it. <i>(1862,Memories of NZ Life,56</i>)

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> When we had no birds, a small piece of bacon went into the billy to give some taste to our `billsticker's paste' as a prosaic member of our party called it. He did not understand the poetry of bush life. <i>(1948,Julius Von Haast,283</i>) [NOTES: 1862 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 283]

>  <b>PRENTICE</b> The late proprietor [of the sheep-station] was particularly anxious to return to England without delay. The experience of one year's bush life as a pioneer not at all agreeing with his preconceived ideas of this land being a land flowing with milk and honey. <i>(1870,Tale of NZ,29</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> [He acquired] such a passion for a wandering bush life, that he afterwards threw up his billet at Mr Taylor's, and followed me all the way down the coast, ... <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,36</i>)

>  <b>TINNE</b> ... I had bragged a little too much of the `glorious liberty' of bush-life. <i>(1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,62</i>)

>  Bush life [in Dannevirke] is monotonous enough. <i>(Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/1/5</i>)



## bush lily
 
 <i>n.</i> one of the indigenous ground growing Astelia species. [also bush-lily]

>  The native fuchsia [fn <i> Fuchsia excorticata </i>.] - an exile from South America - and the fierce bush-nettle [fn <i> Urtica ferox </i>.] are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, together with the bush-lily [fn Astelia nervosa.], but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees [fn Species of <i> Olearia </i>.] or of the bushy Veronicas (koromiko), which are so conspicuous in other parts of these islands. <i>(1900,Canterbury Old & New,184</i>) [NOTES: Dendy]

>  <b>MOORE & IRWIN</b> <i> ASTELIA FRAGRANS </i>. Bush lily grows rather like flax in lowland to montane forest from about the latitude of Thames southwards ... <i>(1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,182</i>)

>  Astelia nervosa, kakaha or bush lily, has pronounced clear nerves running down the midribs of the silvery green leaves. These flaxy leaves may be up to 2.6m long and 10cm wide. <i>(Nov 27, 1997,Evening Post,C22</i>)

## bush lokey

>  <b>MAHONEY</b> The typical bush lokey of this early period was the four-wheel direct-drive type imported from England weighing between 5 and 10 onnes. <i>Ibid</i> 79 A special type of bush lokey was developed to operate over these newer lines which were built far beyond the alignment limits of 'normal' railways. ## bush people
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> The way in which the bush people - the bushmen and their wives - stuck to one another is shown by the way they rallied round in the case of a family that was in need. A common method of raising money was called a `basket social'. A hall would be used for the function, and the people of the district would be invited to bring along baskets. Now these baskets were made of any material at all at hand, and it was remarkable the ingenuity and workmanship shown in making them. ... In the basket its maker put a supper, the food cooked at home ... [151] Now on the night of the basket social, all the baskets would be handed in ... They would then be auctioned, and the purchaser of the basket would have the pleasure and the honour of having supper with the provider of the basket. ... Now I've seen them pay twelve ... pounds in those days for a basket, just to make sure that the girl of the boy's choice saw that he really meant business. ... Every penny of that would go to the family in need ... <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,150</i>) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]
