>  <b>WASWO</b> The proposed 40 acre bush plots posed problems since clearing such a large area was a major exercise. <i>(1996,Farming Progress in NZ 1814-1995,17</i>)



## bush poet
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an oral entertainer of verse in a rural setting.

>  The New Zealand bush poet - I speak of him in the singular, but his name is legion - is not dead, nor even seriously discouraged. <i>(Dec 18, 1890,Otago Witness,21</i>)

>  He is widely recognised and honoured as 'Hobnail Henry' the bush poet. <i>(Jun 2002,Growing Today,40</i>)



## bush poetry
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Another story is commemorated by a piece of rough bush poetry which still adorns the wall of the Glenthorne musterers' hut. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,105</i>)



## bush pole
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>PYKE</b> The bunks - rude structures of bush poles, with flour bag sacking - had been torn down; and clothing ... heaped pell-mell on the floor. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,3/iv/85,(1889,1974) ed.</i>)



## bush polo
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a casual game of polo. (See [Sunday polo](../S#sunday-polo))

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> With them, supplemented by three or four station hacks, we started playing 'bush polo' on Sundays in the summer. <i>(1974,Kingdom in the Hills,76</i>)



## bush pool
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a pond fringed by native vegetation.

>  <b>SALE</b> Below them, dragonflies dance over a bush pool ... <i>(1987,Country Diary,15</i>)



## bush pork
 
 <i>n.</i> wild pork

>  <b>MASTERS</b> I may here mention that bush pork, is superior to home fed, as the pigs live upon roots, berries ... <i>(1871,Autobiography,41</i>)

>  <b>LAMBERT</b> ... how thankful I was for a pannikin of tea and a slice of bush pork and damper ... <i>(1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,147</i>)



## bush porridge
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> She claimed to have built all her children up on smoky, burnt bush porridge. <i>(1965,Among the Cinders,91</i>)



## bush post-office
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a rural mailbox, situated far from civilisation.

>  <b>KENNEDY</b> In the middle of the [Canterbury] plains we drew up alongside a post, on which was nailed what looked like a small writing-desk. The driver leant out, lifted the lid, took out a small leather bag, and drove off. It was a bush post-office - a very private letter-box, belonging to some sheep-station. <i>(1876,Colonial Travel,196</i>)

>  <b>KENNEDY</b> It was a bush post-office - a very private letter-box, belonging to some sheep-station. <i>(1876,Colonial Travel,196</i>)



## bush pub
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a rural public house.

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> I travelled by rail as far as Mataroa and then by a special public works train to Ohakune, where I stopped the night at a bush pub. <i>(1962,Life's Roundabout, A,38</i>)

>  At 4 o'clock he had started with two two-gallon billies to fetch the beer from the nearest bush-pub. <i>(Mar 22, 1890,NZ Observer,9</i>)

>  At 4 o'clock he had started with two two-gallon billies to fetch beer from the nearest bush-pub. <i>(Mar 22, 1890,NZ Observer,9</i>)



## bush railway
 
 <i>n.</i> = bush tramway

>  I begin with an occasion when I had dinner in a house in the bush at Karekare on Auckland's west coast. We sat around a German coal range the couple had hauled by means of wood-track bush railway to the top of the hill on which they had built their house. On a nog in the unlined room was propped an old photograph. <i>(1979,Islands,25/267</i>) [NOTES: Stead (John Mulgan)]

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> In some cases steam engines were employed [to get logs out of bush], or locomotives running on a bush railway, or `tram'. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,161</i>) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]



## bush range(s)
 
 <i>n.</i> range(s) covered with bush (See [cf. bush country](../B#bush-country),[bush face](../B#bush-face))

>  <b>GUDGEON</b> The men did little but scout and forage ... allowing the Hauhaus to e a strong pah in the bush-ranges. <i>(1879,Reminiscences of the War in NZ,70</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> The floor and gently sloping sides were verdant with English and native grasses from the broad strath at our feet right up to where the cleared country narrowed and ran out in the higher ground of the bush range at the head. <i>(1953,Golden Bush, The,41,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <b>KEENE</b> This seemed to make him very happy, and he continued, `My farm extends right to the top of those bush ranges,' he said proudly, ... <i>(1982,Myrtle and Sophia,26</i>)



## bush ranger
 
 <i>n.</i> (historical) a member of the settlers' militia

>  Artillery including howitzers, rockets and mortars were used to assist infantry attacking from the north and east while a force of bush rangers attacked from the ridge line above... After the ambush, a force of bush rangers set out in pursuit of the Maori party... <i>(Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/25</i>)



## bush rat
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> the native or New Zealand rat (introduced by early Maori immigrants), kiore.

>  <b>MONEY</b> This I did by the light of a good bush-fire, that.. showed me the only living animals that formed my society - grey bush-rats. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,31 or 81</i>)

>  On the habits of the New Zealand Bush-rat (Mus maorium) ... <i>(1889,TrNZI,22/301</i>)

>  <i>Arboreal Nests of Bush-rat</i> (Mus maorium) [title] <i>(1895,TrNZI,27/258</i>)

>  On Great Barrier Island, bush rats kiore [sic] and feral cats threaten the small colony [of Cook's petrel]. <i>(1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,81</i>)

>  Arboreal Nests of Bush-rat (<i>Mus maorium</i>) [title] <i>(1895,TrNZI,27/258</i>)

>  On Great Barrier Island, bush rats kiore [sic] and feral cats threaten the small colony [of Cook's petrel]. <i>(1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,81</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> I have heard a bush rat run across the dry leaves <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,146</i>)

>  She can be as cunning as a bush rat sometimes. <i>(Aug 21, 1947,NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,3</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> found in the bush [the 1871 citation above may belong here]

>  <b>MONEY</b> ... I smoked my evening pipe. This I did by the light of a good bush-fire, that danced and flickered on the trees and scrub around me, and showed the only living animals that formed my society - grey bush rats. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,31</i>)

>  The bush-rats (<i>Mus rattus</i>), which depend for food ... on the ripe berries falling from the trees ... <i>(1889,TrNZI,21/207</i>)

>  The Bush Rat is a noted Egg Stealer. [caption] <i>(Nov 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,109</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> Two days after our arrival [at Hokitika in 1865] there was a flood, ... and bush rats were swimming in hundreds, to the fearsome delight of the youngsters. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,148</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSEN</b> [?Norway rats] The bush-rats are experts in extracting the kernels from the nuts [of the tawa]. <i>(1942,Maori Place Names,285</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> It is a pity if this [blue NZ] rat is extinct ... All the bush rats I have seen in the King Country, however, were the ordinary grey vermin. <i>(1950,My First 80 Years,107</i>)

>  <b>DEWAR</b> The bush rat, with its great round nest of holly-bark on holly-tree or scrub-top was observed without hurry; [Southland c1900] <i>(1953,Chaslands,94</i>)

>  <b>ELLIOT& ADSHEAD</b> Then came a plague of bush rats, huge brutes that were eaten by the moreporks. Mr Thomas Nix, now in his 80s, told me that when the men were out bushfelling it was standard practice to give the pungas a hearty whack and then leap back to dodge at least a couple of rats ... <i>(1967,Cowshed to Dog Collar,16</i>)

>  <b>HEND</b> Bush rats at night sometimes made their way into our schooners when they were loaded with general merchandise, or back-loaded with small quantities of farm produce. <i>(1961,Friends in Chains,122</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> anything to avoid the `Thirty-Mile Bush', a half-liquid marsh strewn with the skeletons of pack-horses, their bones picked clean by bush rats. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,118,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HILLIARD</b> ... Dad said seriously `I well remember in the timber camps, the bush-rats would come out at night so hungry they'd eat your toes.' <i>(1965,Power of Joy,173</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Those three [musterers] were `Bush Rats'. They came from the Alford Forest district, commonly known as `The Bush', and a district which has always been noted for the [27] good hill men it has produced. <i>(1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,26</i>)

## bush reserve
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) an area of native bush set aside for conservation and/or recreation purposes.

>  There's invariably a willing response to the 'all expenses paid trip to an island or bush reserve for a day', in exchange for manual labour. <i>(Jun 2006,Conservation Action,5</i>)



## bush ridge
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a bush-covered ridge in hill country.

>  <b>WESTMACOTT</b> Northward, the nearer view hidden by the bush ridge up which we had come [bushridge] <i>(1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,47</i>)

>  <b>MCCONOCHIE</b> The odd trail appeared on the bushridges, which were well back from our farm clearing. <i>(1966,You'll Learn No Harm from the Hills,32</i>)



## bush rigged
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of tractors or similar machinery] fitted with extra equipment for heavy work.

>  Farm equipment for sale: HD6 Bulldozer, bush rigged, manual, good farm machine. <i>(Mar 9, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,25</i>)



## bush road
 
 <i>n.</i> (often used spec. in sawmilling for a logging road).

>  <b>MACLEAN</b> A bush road, tolerably level for a mile. Then ... on to a small <i>kainga,</i> on the banks of the Otawao; ... <i>(Dec 6, 1850,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1850 Dec 6 Maclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 59]

>  There is what we call a<i> good </i>bush road to Rata Nui but beyond it there are two miles of bush walking along what is called `a line'; a line is made by cutting the supple jacks and small shrubs with a bill hook ... [sic] time bush walking takes is very surprising to me ... [sic] <i>(Nov 11, 1853,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/133,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (J. Maria Richmond)]

>  <b>ELWELL</b> Sledges were necessary for bush work, for the bush roads were too narrow and too full of stumps for a dray to be worked in them. <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,238</i>)

>  The bird in question was captured in the Tadmor Valley, in [Nelson], by a man who stated that he saw it walking on an unfrequented bush-road. <i>(1891,TrNZI,23/190</i>)

>  <b>VON TEMPSKY</b> Late on the evening of the 31st of August, after having waded through the bottomless bush road to Pukekohe, I stood before the Church of the settlement, now transformed into a fortress and garrisoned by the settlers. <i>(1864,Memoranda,23</i>)

>  <b>HAY</b> The Pihoi (<i>Anthus N.Z.</i>) is the so-called native `lark.' It is a ground pipit, and may often be seen fluttering and chirping about a bush road. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,2/224</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> Three grand days in the saddle, the last winding down the bush road that skirted the ... Ohura ... then `pikau' and foot-slog for the great roadless forest. <i>(1916,Bush Explorers,6</i>)

>  <b>SEDDON</b> ... the two men and the two boys in that dog cart went their way along the long bush road past Marsden township towards Kumara. <i>(1968,Seddons, The,23</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a packtrack or dray road cut through native bush.

>  We'll wander again up the bush road with the morning ... <i>(Feb 2, 1942,NZ Dairy Exporter,44</i>)

>  The bush road between Tauranga and Ohinemutu is in a bad state.. <i>(May 7, 1883,Hawera Star,2</i>)

>  <b>RICHMOND</b> There is what we call a good bush road to Rata Nui but there are two miles of bush walking along what is called a 'line' - a line is made by cutting the supplejacks and small shrubs ... <i>(Sep 24, 1851,Letter,I 133</i>) [NOTES: Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers]

>  Pigeons and pheasants are numerous in many parts of the bush, whilst there are a few to be obtained up any of the bush roads. <i>(May 19, 1888,Egmont Star,15</i>)

>  From different quarters we hear that the bush roads in this district are not nearly so bad this year as during winter months in past years. <i>(Jul 21, 1888,Egmont Star,7</i>)

>  <b>SCOTT</b> ... we set out for Tapanui, and after ploughing through some five miles of bush roads, up to our ankles in mud and slush ... <i>(1922,Reminiscences of a New Chum in Otago,34</i>)

>  <b>REA</b> .. my father was killed instantaneously being thrown from a dray when the horse bolted down a steep bush road. <i>(1991,Honey and Cheese,11</i>)

>  <b>EWERS</b> No, we'll all go and then walk down the old bush road and home that way. <i>(1993,Lifetime on the Land, A,56</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a back-country, rough road, by no means necessarily through bush

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Some of the bush runs in Western Southland had no choice in the matter, as the country was unsuitable for sheep, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 56 [?thru the bush] They were on the bush road, curved like a bow; half-way, they turned and struck up over the hills, into a clear crest of morning sultried with yellow gorse. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,40</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> To describe ... so strange an assortment ... as the labourers on the bush-roads in the colonies would require the pen of Dickens. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,115</i>)

>  <b>TROLLOPE</b> The road [to Wakatip was] fairly good - for a "bush" road. The name must be taken in a colonial sense. There was hardly a tree to be seen throughout the journey but the word has made its way over from Australia, and the traveller when he is out of town is in the bush. A country road which is merely formed and not metalled is a bush road, though it pass across an open plain, or up a treeless valley. <i>(1874,New Zealand (various authors/titles),47</i>)

>  Is the road difficult? And the answer was, Not as bush-roads, so called, go. <i>(1895,Pictorial NZ,2</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  <b>HYDE</b> <i>(1938,Godwits Fly, The,1</i>) [NOTES: incomplete]

>  <b>LOVELL-SMITH</b> Trollope states that `the road was fairly good for a bush road, i.e., a country road formed but not metalled; but there was hardly a tree to be seen on the whole journey.' <i>(1931,Old Coaching Days,112</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> At first he conducted business from his farm house, about a mile and a quarter up the little bush road at Puketitiri. [1880's] <i>(1959,Tales of the Mails,33</i>)



## bush robin
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) a small, round, tame and inquisitive little bird, one of the Petroica australis subspecies, known also as New Zealand robin. [<i>Petroica australis</i>, (SOUTH ISLAND) ROBIN]

>  No matter where anyone entered the forest he would have a bush robin as a mate and a friend. <i>(Dec 26, 1931,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> [They saw only] a wretched bush-robin, which Arthur insisted on shooting ... which was so close that it was actually blown to pieces. <i>(1881,Waitaruna,150</i>)

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> Tiffany, wooing bush robins, coteries of tiny wrens, swinging in supple-jack loops with a bellbird ringing its chime for her .. <i>(1938,Promenade,96</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> On our arrival back at Hollyford late that afternoon we found our former camp friends, the bush robins waiting to greet us. <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,286</i>)

>  <b>EVANS</b> Bush robins, parakeets, tomtits, grey warblers, riflemen, pigeons and the bush hawk are still to be seen. <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,129</i>)

>  <i>Robin Petroica australis</i> (SPARRMAN, 1788) ... <i>North Island Robin P.a. longpipes</i> (LESSON, 1828). <i>South Island Robin P.a. australis</i> (SPARRMAN, 1788). <i>Stewart Island Robin P.a. rakiura</i> FLEMING, 1950. OTHER NAMES: <i>Bush robin, toutouwai. </i> <i>(1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,282</i>)

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> The roots of the Rhipogonum are used by bushmen as a medicine and the plant is sometimes called "Bush Sarsaparilla". <i>(1906,Plants of NZ,93</i>)

>  <b>LAING  & BLACKWELL</b> The roots of the Rhipogonum are used by bushmen as a medicine, and the plant is sometimes called `Bush Sarsaparilla' <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,93</i>)



## bush sawyer
 
 <i>n.</i> ?one who saws timber in the bush; or ? one who falls or saws bush for timber (See [bushman; bushie](../B#bushman;-bushie))

## bush school
 
 <i>n.</i> a country or backblocks school

 <i>n.</i> a scone baked in the bush over the embers (See [cf. damper](../D#damper))

 <i>n.</i> (historical)

>  <b>COWAN</b> Soldiers and Maori warriors, missionaries, settlers, bush scouts, sailors, heroic women are the leading figures in these tales of true romance. <i>(1935,Hero Stories of NZ,xi</i>)



## bush section
 
 <i>n.</i> (historical) a parcel of forested land (See [cf. section](../S#section))

>  One great blessing in a bush section is the abundance of firewood. <i>(Apr 20, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/95,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> [title] A `Bush' Section on Green Island, Otago (Fox Lodge). <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/239</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> The early settlers of the Weber area, for a number of years after taking up their bush sections, had to rely on packhorse transport from Dannevirke for the delivery of mail and essential supplies. [1880's] <i>(1959,Tales of the Mails,141</i>)

>  He chose to pick his way back ... by way of the scrubby bush section down behind the sand dunes ... <i>(Nov 20, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34</i>) [NOTES: (File Mourning)]

>  It is a cosy ... home [in Titirangi] on a large bush section. <i>(Oct 29, 1989,Sunday Magazine (Auckland),8</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an allotted area of bush land available for farming development.

>  <b>RICHMOND</b> One great blessing in a bush section is the abundance of firewood. <i>(May 18, 1851,Letter,I  95</i>) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers]

>  54 acres bush section of which six are cleared and logged. <i>(Jun 23, 1880,Hawera Star,3</i>)

>  An industrious and steady man of experience could start on a 100 acre deferred payment bush section. <i>(Jul 1887,NZ Farmer,196</i>)

>  Why, one good bush section here would beat that hollow. <i>(Apr 7, 1888,Egmont Star,9</i>)

>  In 1858 he was attracted to Akaroa where he took up a bush section and became a settler, and married. The Norseman later on took up a 60-acre bush section up on the ranges <i>(1945,BLANK ENTRY,16</i>) [NOTES: in KEEGAN (1983) The First Generation]



## bush selection
 
 <i>n.</i> bush section (? an Aust. borrowing).

>  <b>GIPPS</b> ... on this spacious bush-selection. <i>(1907,Outward Bound,27</i>)



## bush sense
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [mustering, hunting, tramping] an instinct to take a correct route when none is obvious.

>  <b>PICKERING</b> Some people are attributed 'bush sense', which is supposed to be an instinct for the right direction. <i>(1988,Hills, The,29</i>)



## bush settlement
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a district settled by bush farmers or foresters and their families.

>  The New Zealand fungus known to commerce is found upon various kinds of decayed timber in the North island, in what are called new bush settlements. ... It is used by the Chinese for mixing with food, and for medicinal purposes. <i>(1892,NZ Official Handbook,151</i>)

>  The effect of the ... destructive elements may be seen on a wide scale in any of the larger bush-settlements. <i>(1897,TrNZI,29/493</i>) [NOTES: (Walsh)]

>  <b>BOREHAM</b> Whenever he came upon some rustic township, bush settlement or native <i>pa</i>, he at once pitched his tent, and threw all his energy into his ministration to the deepest needs of the people. <i>(1911,Selwyn,63</i>)

>  As a child I lived with my parents in a bush settlement, miles from the railway. <i>(Apr 29, 1932,NZ Dairy Exporter,72</i>)

>  <b>WASWO</b> The inner history of the bush settlements is one of hardship, isolation and privation unknown to the settlers of the open country. <i>(1996,Farming Progress in NZ 1814-1995,8</i>)



## bush settler
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a farmer who fells and farms bushland [usually in small holdings].

>  During late years the dairy industry has been one of the most popular ... industries of the bush settler. <i>(1911,TrNZI,43/440</i>)

>  Practically the whole of the 100 acres of bush-free country on the place had been infested with blackberry and gorse, with some fern ... <i>(Nov 21, 1927,NZ Journal of Agriculture,295</i>)



## bush-fringed
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>11</b> Two communities at the end of five kilometres of bush-fringed gravel road in Golden Bay are fed up with raids on their quiet valley by police squads searching for cannabis. <i>(Dec 10, 1985,Dominion</i>)

## bush-happy
 
 <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of bush workers and hunters] oppressed by isolation.

>  <b>SEVERINSEN</b> No wonder [the Wild Life Division's] cullers got bush-happy and once every month or so had to be carried off down to Poronui for a long weekend bombing up the sika [deer]. <i>(1970,Hunt the Far Mountain,42</i>)

>  <b>MARSHALL</b> The season had been bad - too much rain, too few possums and a 'mate' who to use his expression was going 'bush-happy.' <i>(1984,Possum Hunting in New Zealand,22</i>)



## bush-hiking
 
 <i>n.</i> bush-walking, tramping. [coinage from Eng. `hike' - NZ idiom now usu. tramp, but `bush-walking' was earlier used.]

>  [At Milford Sound] we were rewarded by some `bush-hiking' for quite a long stretch. ... It was a mixture of boulder-scrambling and `bush-hiking' interspersed with a few shingle-flats. <i>(1937,NZ Alpine Journal,7/24/57</i>)



## bush-like
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil....  <i>adj.</i> Sc. fed on leafage, karaka etc

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the traversing of bush-covered land.

>  <b>MONEY</b> They had neither of them seen much of real bush-roughing before ... <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,81</i>)

 <i>adj.</i>

## bush-scouring
 
 <i>n.</i> [1879 citation is of verb to scour (no entry)]

>  <b>FEATON</b> ... Captain Jackson's Forest Rangers ... The Rangers had most perilous duty to perform. If the troops advanced, the Rangers scoured the country in front. <i>(1879,Waikato War,72</i>)

>  <b>BELICH</b> At its fullest, the `bush-scouring' theory entailed a `flying column' of a few hundred men, untrammeled by a large supply train,hunting down the Maoris in the bush, and forcing them to fight by attacking their villages and cultivations. ... [214] Bush-scouring was not a panacea for all circumstances, based on the inherent abilities of settler-frontiersmen, but a military method appropriate only in a certain context ... One assumption behind the bush- scouring theory was that the Maoris were evasive guerilla fighters ... [215] Masking the <i>pa</i>, and bush-scouring against the Maori base areas ... would be a long and slow process. <i>(1986,NZ Wars, The,213</i>)

>  The scorched earth policy of stripping the land of Maori houses and crops that had been applied since the beginning of the war in 1863 was supplemented by 'bush-scouring'. This startegy aimed to take the fight to the Maori in the bush. <i>(1996,Waitangi Tribunal Report,143 : 97</i>)



## bush-scouting
 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>adj.</i>

## bush-shooting
 
 <i>n.</i> shooting in the bush A1 (as distinct from in the open) (See [cf. bush-stalking](../B#bush-stalking))

>  <b>THOMSON</b> Some say the open sight is better for snap or bush shooting and the aperture more suitable for long range shooting ...<i>Ibid.</i> 44 In bush shooting our range would vary from a few yards up to seventy or eighty depending on the thickness of the undergrowth ...<i>Ibid.</i> 47 Some days you may shoot several deer while bush-shooting, and at other times you may stalk for a full day and get none... When bush-shooting, you are usually sure of the locality of the deer, as the hill slopes give you an idea of his approximate location. Some days you may shoot several deer while bush-shooting, and at other times you may stalk for a full day and get none, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 119 When bush-shooting, one has [sic] to make sure of each shot, as the deer would be gone after the first shot was fired. <i>(1952,Deer Stalker,26</i>)

 <i>adj.</i>

 <i>adj.</i>

## bush-sick
 
 <i>adj.</i> of an animal

>  Today, Tokoroa farmland is in the same category as the lush pastures of the Waikato, but back then it was still deemed to be within the boundaries of the 'bush-sick' country, deficient in cobalt where pasture was poor and livestock failed to thrive. <i>(Aug 2004,NZ Memories,No. 49/39</i>)

>  The family dairy farm was on formerly bush-sick land near Putararu. <i>(Jan 2000,North & South,50</i>)

>  ... a steer ... was killed ... as being a typical bush-sick animal. <i>(1912,TrNZI,44/288</i>)

>  ... a steer ... was killed ... as being a typical bush-sick animal. <i>(1912,TrNZI,44/288</i>)

>  Development of former bush-sick areas in Tauranga county... The discovery that cobalt was a cure for bush sickness came at a most opportune moment. <i>(Jul 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,67</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of land and stock] suffering a lack of cobalt.

>  Lime .. has an injurious action on the feeding-quality of pasture on 'bush-sick' lands. <i>(Aug 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,123</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> The land was sick - 'bushsick,' they called it. <i>(1966,Sixty Million Muster,66</i>)

>  The amount of cobaltised fertiliser used .. would be sufficient to correct cobalt deficiency in 940,000 acres of bush-sick pasture. <i>(Jan 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,31</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Sixty Million Muster 66 Soon he noticed his bush-sick cattle crowding round the vehicle, licking the mud spattered along its sides with the eagerness of a youngster setting to work on an icecream sundae. <i>(1966,Sixty Million Muster,66</i>)

>  <b>ADDENBROOKE</b> My cousin Leo Addenbrooke had a six hundred acre farm at Lichfield in the area that was partly bush sick, and I was able to look around from there. <i>(1992,Home from the Hill,105</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) land lacking cobalt [that without top-dressing, will cause bush sickness in cattle and sheep.]

>  .. it affords a distinguishing difference between 'bush-sick' country and 'dopy' country. [bush-sickness country.] <i>(Aug 20, 1931,NZ Journal of Agriculture,121</i>)

## bushline
 
 <i>n.</i> the timber-line; the upper limit of the growth of bush A1 on a mountain; height at which bush ceases to grow (cf. timber-line (OED 1835) is occas. used in N.Z; cf. and cp. snow-line, which is more often used in the SI mountain-country. Whether one uses bush-line or snow-line depends upon the locality of the speaker, or the point of view of the speaker, e.g. a bushman would be more likely to speak of the bush-line, a mountaineer of the snow-line. bush-line and snow-line are only occas. synonymous. e.g. in mountain-country, in the summer, when snow is lying high or has disappeared, the bush-line stands out clearly, but is often called (locally and colloquially) `the snow-line': (cf. also scrub-line).

>  Although above the bush line, there will be abundance of wood within convenient distance. <i>(Feb 13, 1899,Taranaki Herald,3</i>)

>  To be considered a true alpine plant, a species must grow in a zone which lies between the bushline - the altitudinal limit beyond which no trees can grow - and the snowline. <i>(Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/43</i>)

>  South of Mt Hector the route crosses a series of other sub-alpine peaks, reaching the bushline near Alpha Hut. <i>(2008,NZ Geographic,94/28</i>)

>  There is any amount of bush all along this line. In fact, the line is generally referred to as the "bush line." <i>(Jan 15, 1924,Otago Witness,64</i>)

>  We may speak of kauri forest or beech forest, but we get lost in the bush, fight bush fires, and climb above the bushline. The kauri forest, like the mixed podocarp forest, the sub-tropical rain forest, ... and such-like are terms that come from the botanist and forester, not from the layman - or from the bushman. ... Even those later scientists who use <i>forest</i> as a general rule usually write of <i>bushmen, bush tracks, patches of bush</i>, and the <i>bushline. </i> <i>Ibid.</i> 24 <i>Bushline</i>, the upper limit of the bush, would be the <i>timberline</i> in North America. Hudson [G.V. Hudson 1890 TrNZI 2/181] used it in 1890 as if it were then well established. It does not seem to have been noted in any dictionary and is probably a word indigenous to New Zealand. <i>(1958,Tararua,23</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

>  <b>CRUMP</b> His place was spread against one side of a leading ridge, along the top of which was the bushline, with his boundary fence hard against the bush. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,82</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> <i>Bush-line</i> or sometimes [161] <i>forest-line</i> (for American<i> timber-line</i>, English <i> tree-line</i> and Australian <i> tree-line or forest-line), bush-clad, bush burns</i> (areas where the bush has recently been burnt off) are tramping as well as general terms, as is the use of <i> shingle</i> for angular as well as rounded stones in <i> shingle slide</i> , or (earlier) <i>shingle slip</i> , also recently called scree as in Scotland and northern England. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,160</i>)

>  <b>HALL-JONES</b> He followed the greenstone to his camp ..., keeping above the bushline, headed for the sea. <i>(1968,Early Fiordland,77</i>)

## bushman's staggers
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>ANNABELL</b> About an hour after the second boil up for the day the affected person would feel an unnatural weakness stealing over him, his axe would grow excessively heavy, every blow would be an effort and a feeling of unreality as if working in a dream and a faint tremnbling of the limbs would assail him. Usually he would sit down and sharpen his axe for a minute or two then carry on chopping, the feeling slowly fading away in about half an hour. Among ourselves, to give this affliction an important sounding name, we always called it "Hydrophobia" but it is more generally called "Bushman's staggers," and is supposed to be caused by overworking the stomach at the same time as overworking the muscles. <i>(1984,Ngamatapouri,51</i>)

## but
 
 <i>adv.</i> (at end of sentence) however

>  I've grown fond of the innovative Kiwi "but" meaning "I must admit" at the end of a sentence. TV watchers must have all seen that high-country musterer detailing the delights of a new girlfriend, then reassuring his mate with, "She doesn't drink Speights, but". Now we have test driver Greg Murphy judging a new four-wheel drive after a spectacular run: "She's tough. But." <i>(Aug 17, 2002,Dominion Post,F9</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> There is no local grammar. The local usage which comes to mind, and it is not widespread, is the use of <i>but</i> as an adverb at the end of a sentence, an equivalent of <i>however.</i> ... The man who took our luggage in the air terminal at Sydney ... agreed [the Sydney climate] was good, then added `We've got central heating, but'. I first heard this usage in 1945 in Auckland among students at a Teacher's College, where it was a bit of an affectation or craze rather than established unconscious usage, but. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,113</i>)

>  <b>C. CORNE</b> but - `though', sentence / clause finally. `Jeez, this is strong piss! Nice, but'. `X's are good cars, I wouldn't buy one, but' Whangarei, widely used in 50s and 60s. Also current in Hawaian Creole English [see also Beaton] <i>(Oct 14, 1983,Letter</i>) [NOTES: (Auckland)]

>  [(schoolchildren's) as a sentence ending] I didn't believe it first time a Whistler kid said he had two mothers. It's true but. ... Caleb still caught untold kutus that year but. <i>(1986,New Outlook,21/49</i>) [NOTES: Macrae (The Kingsland Kid)]

## butcher bats
 
 <i>n.</i> a game with insects (See [aka butcher boys](../A#aka-butcher-boys),[penny doctor beetles](../P#penny-doctor-beetles))

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> <i>Penny Doctor</i> beetles, also known as `Butcher bats' is a game widely reported by Wellington Training College students as being played in many parts of the North Island. In this game straws moistened by spittle are pushed down the hole of the appropriate beetle. The beetle seizes the end of the straw. When the player feels the straw moving he or she flicks out the beetle. The player who can catch the most beetles wins the game. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,328</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> The most widely known game with insects is a game named variously by T.C. students as Butcher Boys (Gisborne, New Plymouth, Kaponga, [405] Te Pohu, Newall, Sth. Wellington), Butcher Bats (Ohau, Takaka), Penny Doctor Beetles (Tauranga, Pipiriki, Rotorua), or Fishing (Morunui). It is a game in which straws which have been suitably moistened with spittle are placed in an insects [sic] hole and are flicked out when the insect bites the end of the straw. Most of the reports of this practice come from the North Island, though it was known in the South as early as 1900 (Waikouaiti). <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,405</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> A universal animal play in the North Island, but known also in the South Island, was a game variously termed Butcher Bats, Butcher Boys, or Penny Doctor Beetles. In this game, straws suitably moistened at the end with spittle were placed down insect holes and flicked out when the insect bit the end of the straw. The player won who could flick a beetle up first. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,128</i>)

## butcher's board
 
 <i>n.</i> a marble game

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

## butterfat
 
 <i>n.</i> The essential fats in milk, used in NZ since 1892 as the basis for calculating the monthly payment to dairy factory suppliers, hence of prime importance to the dairy farmer; now replaced by MILKFAT.

>  To counteract the present waste of butterfat sent into cheese factories, the logical issue seems to be more butter-making for Taranaki. <i>(Jun 27, 1928,NZ Free Lance,36</i>)

>  It was the sharemilker and dairy co-op director and its accountant revealed that next season their industry was facing an almost 50 per cent drop in payments to farmers on their production's butter fat content. <i>(Jul 12, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15</i>)

>  The paying for milk delivered at cheese- and butter-factories according to the amount of butter-fat contained is a question of great importance to the dairymen of New Zealand. <i>(1895,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,III/73</i>)

>  Butter-fat was only 7d per lb. <i>(Aug 28, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,11</i>)

>  "Butter fat" is a word that will be heard frequently in the House this session... <i>(Jul 3, 1917,Stratford Evening Post,4</i>)

>  It was resolved that 16d per lb be paid for butter-fat during the coming season. <i>(Oct 2, 1918,Otago Witness,23</i>)

>  A second payment.. would be made at the rate of 1d for 1lb. butter-fat. <i>(Sep 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,26</i>)

>  No other part of the world.. is producing so much butter-fat under the same conditions of dairying. <i>(Oct 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,31</i>)

>  Is [efficiency] to be determined on pounds of butterfat averaged per cow milked? <i>(Jan 5, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,65</i>)

>  <b>BELSHAW</b> The practice in New Zealand is to pay the dairy farmer on a butterfat basis, whether he is supplying a cheese, butter or any other factory, and it has, therefore, become general to speak in terms of butterfat production rather than gallons of milk. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,446</i>)

>  There appears to be little material change in the aggregate quantities of butterfat now being supplied to the factories. <i>(Nov 2, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,84</i>)

>  It was proved quite early by experiment that farmers could not pick the animals most productive of butter-fat in their own herds with anything approaching scientific accuracy. <i>(1941,Farmer in New Zealand, The,107</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [attrib. uses]

>  <b>19</b> Ken wants the butterfat price to be up in '97, and he hopes the government gives a good price for wool. <i>(Jan 18, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener)</i>)

>  [Farmers' representatives] are out for a refund of the butter-fat tax, which the Government says is not a tax. <i>(Jul 3, 1917,Stratford Evening Post,4</i>)

>  [Hdg] Butter-fat payments. <i>(Sep 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,26</i>)

>  Less hired labour is employed on Dominion dairy farms to-day than was the case when low butterfat prices and correspondingly lower wagers were ruling prior to the advent of the guaranteed price. <i>(Sep 28, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,78</i>)

>  <b>BELSHAW</b> The butterfat production for the month is calculated at the test recorded on the testing officer's monthly visit. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,347</i>)

>  <b>ALLEY & HALL</b> The butterfat production for the month is calculated at the test recorded on the testing officer's monthly visit. <i>(1941,Farmer in New Zealand, The,108</i>)

>  To get a fair test of a cow's capabilities in the cream of the butterfat line she must be milked dry. <i>(Oct 20, 1917,NZ Truth,1</i>)

>  From the Government viewpoint standardisation was viewed as probably lessening considerably the difficulties attendant on cheese-manufacture from high-butterfat-testing milk. <i>(Sep 23, 1931,Dominion,7</i>)

 <i>n.</i> any of a variety of fishes having a slippery coating of mucus ... 1880 Gunther.] A green-boned edible fish found most commonly in southern waters; also called greenbone, marari, and occasionally kelp-fish; greenbone, (southern) kelpfish, kelp-salmon, koaea, marari (marare). Any of several fishes having a slippery (`buttery') coating of mucus of the families Odacidae (the main use), Labridae (wrasses), and Centrolophidae (raftfishes). a. (i) [Name poss. reinforced in NZ by the light buttery (NZ butter is of a very light whitish yellow) colour and softness of the flesh.]Odax pullus, also listed as <i>Coridodax pullus, Odax vittatus</i> (juveniles), a seaweed-eating fish of rocky coasts, larger and more common in s. NZ; a fine food-fish; also called greenbone, kelp-fish, kelpie, kelp salmon, marari (marare).

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> GREENBONE, BUTTERFISH, KELP SALMON, or KELPIE (MARARI) <i>Coridodax pullus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) ... The name Greenbone is given on account of the bones being a bright green colour, which is so permanent as to with-stand boiling or bleaching. ... The name kelp-fish is given on account of its habit of feeding on kelp or seaweed, and also because it likes to make its home among kelp. In such a habitat it has both food and a favourite home. Kelp-salmon is given for two reasons. The first part, kelp, is explained in the last paragraph, while the second half, salmon, is because the fish is not unlike a Salmon in shape, so much so that new chums who caught this fish have been under the impression they had caught the protected introduced Salmon, but of that later in this chapter. But why this dark coloured fish should receive the name Butterfish I am unable to say. It is certainly not as some people suggest because it needs butter with it when cooked or eaten. In Auckland the fish known to South Islanders as Spotty (<i>Pseudolabrus celidotus</i>) is called Butterfish on account of its bright golden colouring on the lower parts of the body and fins fancifully resembling the colour of butter. The name Kelpie, of course, is derived from its habit of living amidst kelp and it is easily understood how the `ie' was tacked on by fishermen. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,261</i>)

>  <b>PARROTT</b> The Butterfish is very similar in form, and is related to, the Kelpfish (<i>Odax vittatus</i>), which is also a brightly-coloured species and found in similar situations, feeding on kelp and other marine plants in rocky localities. <i>Ibid.</i> 130 It is unfortunate that the Butterfish has been given a variety of local names which have originated either from their habit of associating with kelp, their body form, or from the colour of their bones, as for example, Kelpfish, Kelp-salmon, Greenbone, and several other names not so easy to explain. Butterfish or Greenbone are possibly the more generally used names for this fish but it should be remembered that in the North Island the Spotty (<i>Pseudolabrus celidotus</i>), a very different fish, is related to the Butterfish there is superficially little resemblance between the two species. <i>Ibid.</i> 169 Butterfish Coridodax pullus Greenbone; Kelp Salmon; Kelpi; Kelpfish <i>(1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,129</i>)

 <i>abbr.</i> bring your own: the usual notice at restaurants not fully licensed to sell liquor.

>  Most of our cities and even small towns have restaurants that offer and wine service and / or allow patrons to bring their own wine. Not many diners know that the BYO concept originated in Australia and New Zealand during the 1960s and 70s and is rarely found elsewhere. The antipodean origin is acknowledged in the authoritative Oxford Companion to Wine. <i>(Apr 25, 1999,NZ Catholic,17</i>)

>  The interior recalls an almost vanished era - that of the BYO bistro. <i>(Nov 30, 1999,Evening Post,19</i>)

>  We stopped BYO for larger groups two years ago. All they were interested in doing was bringing in a couple of cases of booze and having a party at our expense... You want BYO, he says, then you go to a restaurant, probably an ethnic restaurant or cafe, where you get good cheap food that doesn't take a great deal of preparation and few staff. That's the sort of restaurant that can afford to do BYO. <i>(Dec 18, 1999,Dominion,23</i>)

>  They had that BYO sort of look about them and let me bare all. It's that sort of place. <i>(Jul 19, 2003,Dominion Post,F6</i>)

>  I don't want to buy into a punch-up over the BYO syndrome, but this tell-tale brown-bag routine is something I shy away from. It's pretty much an Australian and New Zealand thing to ferry our own drinkies into restaurants, sometimes even transporting them in a designer bag, suitably labelled, and drawing attention to the fact that l'il ole me is bringing my own. <i>(Mar 24, 2001,Dominion,23</i>)

>  Inside, on the walls, are black and white photographs of early Plimmerton, and the cafe is one of the last of a species fast facing extinction in central Wellington - the BYO restaurant. Twenty-five years ago, "BYO restaurant" had exciting, avant-garde connotations of a new breed of restauranteur, intent on providing a hip, casual alternative to the handful of stiff, expensive, fully licensed fine dining restaurants which, aspart from hotels and a scattering of tired old steak and chip grill-roomns, previously comprised the sum total of the New Zealand dining-out experience. <i>(Jun 5, 2003,Dominion Post,D4</i>)

>  <b>WILKINS</b> "What is it, Henry?" she said. "Irene and her b.y.o. handbag?" <i>(1990,Veteran Perils,139</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> There was a BYO restaurant, but [152] I had not brought my own booze. <i>(1985,G'day Country,151</i>)

>  BYO ad functions illegal, police say ... Senior Sergeant Max Moore said this when commenting on recent advertisements on radio and newspapers in Oamaru advertising functions as `bring your own liquor.' <i>Ibid.</i> 14 Dining with members of the Collard family at Chatterleys byo restaurant in Auckland recently was a truly gastronomic and vinous experience. <i>(Jul 11, 1986,Evening Post,11</i>)

>  <b>HILL</b> A ute boot sale, BYO gumboot throwing, raffles ... [at School Gala day]. <i>(1988,More from Moaville,45</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>BYO</i> acronym for bring your own, usually meaning the wine you take to an unlicensed restaurant. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,24</i>)

>  FED UP. 244 Ponsonby Rd. BYO. No bookings. Small, crowded with drabbies. Menu long overdue for a change, but still good value. <i>(Jul 1986,Metro,20</i>)

>  On 22 February at 11 am the Victoria Child Care Centre is holding a party brunch at the Centre to farewell Maggie Haggerty ... All past and present children and adults welcome. Please B.Y.O. and a plate of nibbles. <i>(Feb 13, 1987,Victoria Univ. Weekly Staff Circular</i>)

The Chairman of the Licensing Committee.. may at any time grant to any person conducting the business of a restaurateur in any unlicensed restaurant.. a permit authorising the consumption of liquor in the restaurant by any person who is there for the purpose of partaking of a meal and who brings the liquor with him into the restaurant. <i>(1978,NZ Statutes,I 53/681</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a BYO restaurant

## BYOG
 
 <i>abbr.</i> Bring Your Own Grog

>  <i>B.Y.O.(G.) n. Austral. & N.Z.</i> an unlicensed restaurant at which diners may drink their own wine, etc. [C20: <i>bring your own (grog)] </i> <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,150</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 98; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 65]]

>  The need for a provision of this nature - sometimes known as BYOG, "bring your own grog" - has been widely recognised and provides a clear enough example of a case where the present law has fallen into disrepute because of its unreasonableness. <i>(1976,NZ Parliamentary Debates,407 : 3561</i>)
